paragraphs.original: Enter SLY and HOSTESS
paragraphs.translated: SLY and HOSTESS enter.

paragraphs.original: I'll pheeze you, in faith.
paragraphs.translated: I'll fix you, I swear.

paragraphs.original: A pair of stocks, you rogue!
paragraphs.translated:
You thug! I'll call for a pair of
stocks!
stocks

paragraphs.original:
Y'are a baggage, the Slys are no rogues. Look in the chronicles - we came in with Richard Conqueror. Therefore paucas pallabris: let the world slide. Sessa!
paucas pallabris
paragraphs.translated:
There are no thugs in my family, whore! Read your history! We
Slys came over with Richard the Conqueror. Oh, the hell with it. I can't be bothered. Shut up!
Slys

paragraphs.original: You will not pay for the glasses you have burst?
paragraphs.translated: You won't pay for the glasses you smashed?

paragraphs.original: No, not a denier. Go by, Saint Jeronimy. Go to thy cold bed and warm thee.
paragraphs.translated: No, not a penny. Get out of my face. Go play with yourself.

paragraphs.original: I know my remedy. I must go fetch the thirdborough.
paragraphs.translated: I know my rights. I'll call a policeman.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: She exits.

paragraphs.original:
Third, or fourth, or fifth borough, I'll answer him by law.
I'll not budge an inch, boy. Let him come, and kindly.
paragraphs.translated: Call them all! I have a legal right to be here. I'm not moving an inch, pal. Let them come - I don't care.

paragraphs.original: Falls asleep
paragraphs.translated: He falls asleep.

paragraphs.original: Wind horns Enter a LORD from hunting, with his train
paragraphs.translated: A hunting horn is heard. A LORD who has been hunting enters with his hunstmen.

paragraphs.original:
Huntsman, I charge thee, tender well my hounds.
Breathe Merriman, the poor cur is embossed,
And couple Clowder with the deep-mouthed brach.
Saw'st thou not, boy, how Silver made it good
At the hedge corner, in the coldest fault?
I would not lose the dog for twenty pound.
paragraphs.translated:
Huntsman, look after my hounds. Let Merriman catch his breath - the poor dog's foaming at the mouth. And tie up Clowder together with the long-mouthed bitch. (to his page) Did you see, boy, how Silver picked up the scent at the hedge corner, where it was weakest? I wouldn't part with that dog for twenty pounds.
(to his page)

paragraphs.original:
Why, Belman is as good as he, my lord.
He cried upon it at the merest loss,
And twice today picked out the dullest scent.
Trust me, I take him for the better dog.
paragraphs.translated: I think Belman is just as good, my lord. He set up a howl when the scent was lost completely and twice picked it up where it was weakest. I swear he's the better dog.

paragraphs.original:
Thou art a fool. If Echo were as fleet,
I would esteem him worth a dozen such.
But sup them well and look unto them all.
Tomorrow I intend to hunt again.
paragraphs.translated: You're a fool. If Echo were as fast, he would be worth a dozen like Belman. But give them all a good dinner and look after them well. I'll go hunting again tomorrow, I think.

paragraphs.original: I will, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: I will, my lord.

paragraphs.original: What's here? One dead, or drunk? See, doth he breathe?
paragraphs.translated: What's this? A drunkard or a corpse? Check and see if he's breathing.

paragraphs.original:
He breathes, my lord. Were he not warmed with ale,
This were a bed but cold to sleep so soundly.
paragraphs.translated: He is, my lord. But this would be too cold a place to sleep if he hadn't warmed himself with ale.

paragraphs.original:
O monstrous beast, how like a swine he lies!
Grim death, how foul and loathsome is thine image!
Sirs, I will practice on this drunken man.
What think you: if he were conveyed to bed,
Wrapped in sweet clothes, rings put upon his fingers,
A most delicious banquet by his bed,
And brave attendants near him when he wakes,
Would not the beggar then forget himself?
paragraphs.translated: It's disgusting, sleeping that way - like a pig in the gutter! Alas, grim death, how vile and ugly your near-twin, sleep, is! Gentlemen, I think I'll play a trick on this lout. What do you think? Say we were to carry him to one of the bedrooms, put fresh clothes on him and rings on his fingers, lay out a wonderful feast by his bed, and have servants in fancy dress near him when he wakes up - wouldn't the poor tramp be confused?

paragraphs.original: Believe me, lord, I think he cannot choose.
paragraphs.translated: I don't think he'd have any choice, my lord.

paragraphs.original: It would seem strange unto him when he waked.
paragraphs.translated: When he woke, he wouldn't know where he was.

paragraphs.original:
Even as a flatt'ring dream or worthless fancy.
Then take him up and manage well the jest.
Carry him gently to my fairest chamber
And hang it round with all my wanton pictures.
Balm his foul head in warm distilled waters
And burn sweet wood to make the lodging sweet.
Procure me music ready when he wakes,
To make a dulcet and a heavenly sound.
And if he chance to speak, be ready straight
And with a low submissive reverence
Say, "What is it your Honor will command?"
Let one attend him with a silver basin
Full of rose-water and bestrewed with flowers,
Another bear the ewer, the third a diaper,
And say, "Will 't please your Lordship cool your hands?"
Someone be ready with a costly suit
And ask him what apparel he will wear.
Another tell him of his hounds and horse,
And that his lady mourns at his disease.
Persuade him that he hath been lunatic,
And when he says he is, say that he dreams,
For he is nothing but a mighty lord.
This do, and do it kindly, gentle sirs.
It will be pastime passing excellent
If it be husbanded with modesty.
paragraphs.translated:
It would be just like a nice daydream or fantasy. Well, take him on up and we'll try to pull it off. Carry him to my best room - gently, so he doesn't wake - and hang all my erotic paintings around him. Bathe his filthy head with warm, scented water. Burn fragrant wood to give the room a pleasant smell, and have musicians at hand, ready to produce sweet, soothing sounds when he awakes. You want to be ready in case he speaks. If he does, bow low and say deferentially, "What would your Honor have us do?" Have one servant wait on him with a basin of rosewater (throw in some petals), have another servant carry a pitcher, and a third a cloth. Say, "Would your Lordship care to freshen up?" Have someone standing by with expensive clothes, and ask him what he'd care to wear. Have another servant tell him about the dogs and horses that he owns and that his wife is grief-stricken over his illness. Convince him that he has been out of his mind - and when he says he's out of his mind now, tell him he's mistaken and that he is in fact a mighty lord. Do this - make it convincing - and we'll have fun. It could work if it's done subtly.
now,

paragraphs.original:
My lord, I warrant you we will play our part
As he shall think by our true diligence
He is no less than what we say he is.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, I promise we will play our parts so skillfully that he will believe everything we tell him.

paragraphs.original:
Take him up gently, and to bed with him,
And each one to his office when he wakes.
paragraphs.translated: Carry him gently to bed, and every man be ready at his post when he awakes.

paragraphs.original: Some servants carry out SLY. Sound trumpets
paragraphs.translated: Several servants carry SLY out. Trumpets sound.

paragraphs.original: Sirrah, go see what trumpet 'tis that sounds.
paragraphs.translated: Go, lad, and find out what the trumpet's sounding for.

paragraphs.original: Exit Servingman
paragraphs.translated: A servant exits.

paragraphs.original:
Belike some noble gentleman that means,
Traveling some journey, to repose him here.
paragraphs.translated: It's probably some noble gentleman stopping off in mid-journey, thinking to spend the night here.

paragraphs.original: Enter SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: A SERVANT enters.

paragraphs.original: How now! who is it?
paragraphs.translated: Well, who is it?

paragraphs.original:
An't please your Honor, players
That offer service to your Lordship.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, it's a troupe of actors who want to perform for your Lordship.

paragraphs.original: Bid them come near.
paragraphs.translated: Have them come in.

paragraphs.original: Enter PLAYERS
paragraphs.translated: The PLAYERS(actors) enter.

paragraphs.original: Now, fellows, you are welcome.
paragraphs.translated: You are welcome here, my friends.

paragraphs.original: We thank your Honor.
paragraphs.translated: We thank your Honor.

paragraphs.original: Do you intend to stay with me tonight?
paragraphs.translated: Were you thinking of spending the night here?

paragraphs.original: So please your Lordship to accept our duty.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, if that would be all right with your Lordship.

paragraphs.original:
With all my heart. This fellow I remember
Since once he played a farmer's eldest son.
'Twas where you wooed the gentlewoman so well.
I have forgot your name, but sure that part
Was aptly fitted and naturally performed.
paragraphs.translated: By all means. I remember this fellow - he once played the eldest son of a farmer. It was the play in which you wooed the gentlewoman so successfully. I have forgotten your name, but you were well cast in the role and played it convincingly.

paragraphs.original: I think 'twas Soto that your Honor means.
paragraphs.translated: I believe your Honor is thinking of a character called Soto.

paragraphs.original:
'Tis very true. Thou didst it excellent.
Well, you are come to me in happy time,
The rather for I have some sport in hand
Wherein your cunning can assist me much.
There is a lord will hear you play tonight;
But I am doubtful of your modesties,
Lest over-eyeing of his odd behavior - 
For yet his Honor never heard a play - 
You break into some merry passion
And so offend him. For I tell you, sirs,
If you should smile, he grows impatient.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, that was it. You gave an excellent performance. Well, this is very fortunate, your arriving just at this moment. I happen to be planning a little entertainment and could really use your services. There is a particular lord who will watch you perform tonight. I'm a little worried, though - because his Honor has never seen a play before - that his odd behavior may strike you as funny. You might not be able to control your laughter and you might offend him. I warn you, he's sensitive. The slightest smile provokes him.

paragraphs.original:
Fear not, my lord, we can contain ourselves
Were he the veriest antic in the world.
paragraphs.translated: Don't worry. We'll restrain ourselves - no matter how bizarrely he behaves.

paragraphs.original:
Go, sirrah, take them to the buttery
And give them friendly welcome every one.
Let them want nothing that my house affords.
paragraphs.translated: Go, lad, and take them to the pantry. Make them feel welcome and see to it that they have everything they require.

paragraphs.original: Exit one with the PLAYERS
paragraphs.translated: A servant exits with the PLAYERS.

paragraphs.original:
Sirrah, go you to Barthol'mew, my page,
And see him dressed in all suits like a lady.
That done, conduct him to the drunkard's chamber
And call him "madam," do him obeisance.
Tell him from me, as he will win my love,
He bear himself with honorable action,
Such as he hath observed in noble ladies
Unto their lords, by them accomplishèd.
paragraphs.translated: You, fellow, go fetch my page, Bartholomew, and dress him up like a noble lady. When you've finished, bring him to the drunkard's room, address him as "madam," bow to him and treat him with all-round respect and deference, as though he were the lady of the house. Give him this message: if he wants to please me, he will conduct himself like a member of the aristocracy, mimicking the kind of behavior he's seen noble ladies use toward their husbands.

paragraphs.original:
Such duty to the drunkard let him do
With soft low tongue and lowly courtesy,
And say, "What is 't your Honor will command,
Wherein your lady and your humble wife
May show her duty and make known her love?"
And then with kind embracements, tempting kisses,
And with declining head into his bosom,
Bid him shed tears, as being overjoyed
To see her noble lord restored to health,
Who for this seven years hath esteemed him
No better than a poor and loathsome beggar.
And if the boy have not a woman's gift
To rain a shower of commanded tears,
An onion will do well for such a shift,
Which in a napkin being close conveyed
Shall in despite enforce a watery eye.
See this dispatched with all the haste thou canst:
Anon I'll give thee more instructions.
paragraphs.translated: That's just how I want him to behave toward the drunkard, speaking in a low, soft voice and in humble, courteous tones and saying fancy stuff like, "What does your Honor wish to command your lady, your humble wife, to do to show her devotion and demonstrate her love?" Tell him to give the drunkard fond embraces and alluring kisses, and lay his head on the other man's breast, weeping like a woman overjoyed to see a husband restored to health who for the last seven years has imagined he was no better than a poor, pathetic beggar. The boy may lack a woman's gift for weeping at will, so it might be good to have an onion handy, hidden in a handkerchief. That'll make his eyes stream. Get this done as quickly as you can. I'll give you more instructions later.

paragraphs.original: Exit a servingman
paragraphs.translated: A servant exits.

paragraphs.original:
I know the boy will well usurp the grace,
Voice, gait, and action of a gentlewoman.
I long to hear him call the drunkard "husband,"
And how my men will stay themselves from laughter
When they do homage to this simple peasant.
I'll in to counsel them. Haply my presence
May well abate the over-merry spleen
Which otherwise would grow into extremes.
paragraphs.translated: I know the boy will be a convincing gentlewoman, taking up her exact walk and talk and gentle gestures. I can't wait to hear him call the drunkard "husband," and to watch my men smother their laughter as they pay their respects to this simple peasant. I'll go and coach them. My presence may put a damper on their high spirits, which might otherwise get out of control.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter aloft SLY, the drunkard, with Attendants, some with apparel, others with basin and ewer and other appurtenances, and LORD dressed as an attendant.
paragraphs.translated: SLY appears above the stage. He is attended by several servants, some carrying clothing and others a basin, pitcher, and other accessories. The LORD also enters disguised as a servant.

paragraphs.original: For God's sake, a pot of small ale.
paragraphs.translated: For God's sake, would someone bring me a mug of beer!

paragraphs.original: Will 't please your Lordship drink a cup of sack?
paragraphs.translated: Wouldn't your Lordship prefer some imported wine?

paragraphs.original: Will 't please your Honor taste of these conserves?
paragraphs.translated: Would your Honor like to try this dried fruit?

paragraphs.original: What raiment will your Honor wear today?
paragraphs.translated: What garment would your Honor like to wear today?

paragraphs.original: I am Christophero Sly. Call not me "Honor" nor "Lordship." I ne'er drank sack in my life. An if you give me any conserves, give me conserves of beef. Ne'er ask me what raiment I'll wear, for I have no more doublets than backs, no more stockings than legs, nor no more shoes than feet, nay sometime more feet than shoes, or such shoes as my toes look through the over-leather.
paragraphs.translated:
I'm Christopher Sly. Don't call me "your Honor" and "your Lordship." I've never had imported wine in my life, and if you want to bring me something "dried," try beef jerky. Why ask me what "garment" I'll wear? I have no more jackets than I have backs, no more leggings than I have legs, and no more shoes than I have feet - in fact, sometimes I have fewer shoes than feet, as I'm not sure the ones where my toes stick out can be called "shoes."
fewer

paragraphs.original:
Heaven cease this idle humor in your Honor!
Oh, that a mighty man of such descent,
Of such possessions and so high esteem,
Should be infusèd with so foul a spirit!
paragraphs.translated: May Heaven put an end to this foolish fantasy of your Honor's! How terrible that a man of your influence and noble family, with so much wealth and an excellent reputation, should be infected with such a horrible illness!

paragraphs.original: What, would you make me mad? Am not I Christopher Sly, old Sly's son of Burton Heath, by birth a peddler, by education a cardmaker, by transmutation a bearherd, and now by present profession a tinker? Ask Marian Hacket, the fat alewife of Wincot, if she know me not! If she say I am not fourteen pence on the score for sheer ale, score me up for the lying'st knave in Christendom. What! I am not bestraught! Here's -
paragraphs.translated:
What, are you trying to make me crazy? I'm Christopher Sly, son of old Sly of Barton-on-Heath, a peddler by birth, a
cardmaker by trade, a keeper of trained bears by bad luck, and now, by present profession, a tinker. Go ask Marian Hacket, the fat innkeeper of Wincot. She knows me! She'll tell you about the tab I've run up - fourteen pence just for ale. If she doesn't, call me the biggest liar in Christendom. I'm not crazy! Just look at how - 
cardmaker

paragraphs.original: Oh, this it is that makes your lady mourn!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, this is why your poor wife is mourning!

paragraphs.original: Oh, this is it that makes your servants droop!
paragraphs.translated: And this is why your servants hang their heads in sorrow!

paragraphs.original:
Hence comes it that your kindred shuns your house,
As beaten hence by your strange lunacy.
O noble lord, bethink thee of thy birth,
Call home thy ancient thoughts from banishment,
And banish hence these abject lowly dreams.
Look how thy servants do attend on thee,
Each in his office ready at thy beck.
Wilt thou have music? Hark! Apollo plays,
paragraphs.translated:
And this is why your relatives never visit, frightened away by this unnatural insanity of yours. Oh noble lord, consider your lineage. Try to recall your former state of mental health and forget these crass, lowly desires. Look how your servants wait on you, each one ready to do whatever you command. Would you care to hear some music? Listen! That's
Apollo playing.
Apollo

paragraphs.original: Music
paragraphs.translated: Music plays.

paragraphs.original:
And twenty cagèd nightingales do sing:
Or wilt thou sleep? We'll have thee to a couch
Softer and sweeter than the lustful bed
On purpose trimmed up for Semiramis.
Say thou wilt walk, we will bestrew the ground.
Or wilt thou ride? Thy horses shall be trapped,
Their harness studded all with gold and pearl.
Dost thou love hawking? Thou hast hawks will soar
Above the morning lark. Or wilt thou hunt?
Thy hounds shall make the welkin answer them
And fetch shrill echoes from the hollow earth.
paragraphs.translated:
And those birds you hear - twenty caged nightingales. Do you want to sleep? We'll have a couch made up that's softer and more fragrant even than the bed of lustful
Semiramis. Say you want to take a walk, and we'll sprinkle the ground with flowers. Or do you want to go horseback riding? Your horses will be adorned with harnesses decorated in gold and pearls. Do you like hawking? You have hawks that can soar higher than the morning lark. Or do you want to hunt? Your hounds will make the sky echo with their high-pitched voices.
Semiramis

paragraphs.original:
Say thou wilt course. Thy greyhounds are as swift
As breathed stags, ay, fleeter than the roe.
paragraphs.translated: If you care to hunt rabbits, your greyhounds are as swift as healthy stags and faster than young deer.

paragraphs.original:
Dost thou love pictures? We will fetch thee straight
Adonis painted by a running brook
And Cytherea all in sedges hid,
Which seem to move and wanton with her breath,
Even as the waving sedges play with wind.
paragraphs.translated:
Do you like pictures? We'll be right back with one of
Adonis stretched out beside a rushing brook, with Venus spying on him, hidden in rushes that seem to move and undulate with her lustful sighs, like grass waving in the wind.
Adonis

paragraphs.original:
We'll show thee Io as she was a maid
And how she was beguileèd and surprised,
As lively painted as the deed was done.
paragraphs.translated:
There's one that shows Io as a maid, before she was turned into a cow, in which
Jupiter tricks and takes her. It's so realistic, it seems to be happening right before your eyes.
Jupiter

paragraphs.original:
Or Daphne roaming through a thorny wood,
Scratching her legs that one shall swear she bleeds,
And at that sight shall sad Apollo weep,
So workmanly the blood and tears are drawn.
paragraphs.translated:
There's one of
Daphne running through the woods, her legs so scratched by thorns that Apollo himself would weep at the sight. You'll swear the blood and tears are real.
Daphne

paragraphs.original:
Thou art a lord, and nothing but a lord.
Thou hast a lady far more beautiful
Than any woman in this waning age.
paragraphs.translated: You are nothing less than a lord. You have a noble wife who is much more beautiful than any other woman in this declining age.

paragraphs.original:
And till the tears that she hath shed for thee
Like envious floods o'errun her lovely face,
She was the fairest creature in the world - 
And yet she is inferior to none.
paragraphs.translated: Before she began shedding tears all over her lovely face, she was the fairest creature in the world - and even now she has no equal.

paragraphs.original:
Am I a lord, and have I such a lady?
Or do I dream? Or have I dreamed till now?
I do not sleep: I see, I hear, I speak.
I smell sweet savors and I feel soft things.
Upon my life, I am a lord indeed
And not a tinker, nor Christopher Sly.
Well, bring our lady hither to our sight,
And once again, a pot o' the smallest ale.
paragraphs.translated:
I'm really a lord? And do I really have a wife like that? Is this a dream? Or has everything up till now been a dream? I don't seem to be asleep: I can see and hear and speak. I can smell sweet smells and feel things that are soft to the touch. I'll be damned! I guess I really am a lord and not a tinker, and not Christopher Sly, either. Well, bring my wife to me. Oh, and don't forget the beer.
this

paragraphs.original:
Will 't please your Mightiness to wash your hands?
O, how we joy to see your wit restored!
O, that once more you knew but what you are!
These fifteen years you have been in a dream
Or, when you waked, so waked as if you slept.
paragraphs.translated: Would your Mightiness care to wash his hands? We're overjoyed to see you sane again. If only you had a clearer memory of who you are! These past fifteen years you have been living in a dream, and even when you were awake, it was as though you slept.

paragraphs.original:
These fifteen years! By my fay, a goodly nap.
But did I never speak of all that time?
paragraphs.translated: Fifteen years! That's some nap. But I never spoke the whole time?

paragraphs.original:
O, yes, my lord, but very idle words.
For though you lay here in this goodly chamber,
Yet would you say ye were beaten out of door;
And rail upon the hostess of the house,
And say you would present her at the leet,
Because she brought stone jugs and no sealed quarts.
Sometimes you would call out for Cicely Hacket.
paragraphs.translated:
Oh yes, you spoke, my lord, but total nonsense. For instance, you'd be lying here in this comfortable room, but you'd say that you were being thrown out of some tavern and would shout at a landlady about how you were going to take her to court for cheating you. Sometimes you would call out for one Cicely Hacket.
say

paragraphs.original: Ay, the woman's maid of the house.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, the landlady's maid.

paragraphs.original:
Why, sir, you know no house nor no such maid,
Nor no such men as you have reckoned up,
As Stephen Sly and old John Naps of Greece,
And Peter Turph and Henry Pimpernell,
And twenty more such names and men as these,
Which never were, nor no man ever saw.
paragraphs.translated: But sir, there is no such house, no such maid, and no such men as you have dreamed up, like a certain Stephen Sly and one old John Naps of Greece, a Peter Turph, one "Henry Pimpernell," and twenty more men of this sort - who never actually existed.

paragraphs.original: Now Lord be thanked for my good amends!
paragraphs.translated: Well, thank God I'm cured!

paragraphs.original: Amen.
paragraphs.translated: Amen.

paragraphs.original: I thank thee. Thou shalt not lose by it.
paragraphs.translated: I thank you all. You won't regret this.

paragraphs.original: Enter the PAGE as a lady, with attendants
paragraphs.translated: The PAGE enters, disguised as a noble lady and accompanied by servants.

paragraphs.original: How fares my noble lord?
paragraphs.translated: How is my noble lord?

paragraphs.original:
Marry, I fare well,
For here is cheer enough. Where is my wife?
paragraphs.translated: Not bad, actually. This is all quite pleasant. Where is my wife?

paragraphs.original: Here, noble lord. What is thy will with her?
paragraphs.translated: Here, noble lord. What is your wish with regard to her?

paragraphs.original:
Are you my wife and will not call me "husband"?
My men should call me "lord." I am your goodman.
paragraphs.translated: You call yourself my wife, yet you don't call me "husband"? It's my men who should call me "lord." I'm your man, your fellow.

paragraphs.original:
My husband and my lord, my lord and husband,
I am your wife in all obedience.
paragraphs.translated:
My husband is my lord and my lord is my husband. For I am your all-obedient wife.
is

paragraphs.original: I know it well. - What must I call her?
"Madam."
paragraphs.translated: "Madam."

paragraphs.original: "Alice Madam," or "Joan Madam"?
paragraphs.translated:
"
Madam Alice?" Or "Madam Joan?"
Madam

paragraphs.original: "Madam," and nothing else. So lords call ladies.
paragraphs.translated: Just "madam." That's how noblemen address their wives.

paragraphs.original:
Madam wife, they say that I have dreamed
And slept above some fifteen year or more.
paragraphs.translated: Madam wife, they say I've been dreaming or asleep for more than fifteen years.

paragraphs.original:
Ay, and the time seems thirty unto me,
Being all this time abandoned from your bed.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, and it seemed twice as long to me, having been kept from your bed that whole time.

paragraphs.original:
'Tis much. - Servants, leave me and her alone.
Madam, undress you and come now to bed.
paragraphs.translated: That's too long. - Servants, leave her and me alone. Now, madam, undress and come to bed.

paragraphs.original:
Thrice noble lord, let me entreat of you
To pardon me yet for a night or two,
Or if not so, until the sun be set.
For your physicians have expressly charged,
In peril to incur your former malady,
That I should yet absent me from your bed.
I hope this reason stands for my excuse.
paragraphs.translated: Thrice noble lord, I beg you to excuse me for another night or two - or at least until nightfall. Your doctors have expressly forbidden me to sleep with you, as there's a risk that you might have a relapse. I hope this explanation will stand as my excuse.

paragraphs.original: Ay, it stands so that I may hardly tarry so long. But I would be loath to fall into my dreams again. I will therefore tarry in despite of the flesh and the blood.
paragraphs.translated:
Well, something's standing up. I'm not sure I can wait that long. Still, I'd hate to see my former dreams return. So I will wait, however
flesh and blood may feel about it.
will
flesh and blood

paragraphs.original: Enter a MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A MESSENGER.

paragraphs.original:
Your Honor's players, hearing your amendment,
Are come to play a pleasant comedy,
For so your doctors hold it very meet,
Seeing too much sadness hath congealed your blood,
And melancholy is the nurse of frenzy.
Therefore they thought it good you hear a play
And frame your mind to mirth and merriment,
Which bars a thousand harms and lengthens life.
paragraphs.translated: Your Honor's actors, hearing of your recovery, have come to perform a pleasing comedy for you - and your doctors approve wholeheartedly. They say that too much suffering has made your blood coagulate, and that sadness leads to madness. So they think it's a good idea for you to watch a play and direct your thoughts toward laughter and merriment - two strong preventive medicines that foster long life.

paragraphs.original:
Marry, I will. Let them play it. Is not a comonty a
Christmas gambold or a tumbling-trick?
paragraphs.translated:
Okay, bring on the play. But what's a "
comonty?" Some sort of Christmas skit or display of acrobatics?
comonty

paragraphs.original: What, household stuff?

paragraphs.original: Well, we'll see 't. Come, madam wife, sit by my side and let the world slip. We shall ne'er be younger.
paragraphs.translated: Well, let's watch it. Come, madam wife, sit here beside me. Let's forget our cares. We're not getting any younger.

paragraphs.translated: The sound of trumpet fanfare. LUCENTIO and his servant TRANIO enter.

paragraphs.original:
Tranio, since for the great desire I had
To see fair Padua, nursery of arts,
I am arrived for fruitful Lombardy,
The pleasant garden of great Italy,
And by my father's love and leave am armed
With his goodwill and thy good company.
My trusty servant, well approved in all,
Here let us breathe and haply institute
A course of learning and ingenious studies.
Pisa, renownèd for grave citizens,
Gave me my being and my father first,
A merchant of great traffic through the world,
Vincentio, come of the Bentivolii.
Vincentio's son, brought up in Florence,
It shall become to serve all hopes conceived
To deck his fortune with his virtuous deeds.
And therefore, Tranio, for the time I study
Virtue, and that part of philosophy
Will I apply that treats of happiness
By virtue specially to be achieved.
Tell me thy mind, for I have Pisa left
And am to Padua come, as he that leaves
A shallow plash to plunge him in the deep
And with satiety seeks to quench his thirst.
paragraphs.translated:
Well, Tranio, here we are in fertile Lombardy, garden of Italy, about to fulfill my lifelong dream. You know how I've always longed to see the fair city of Padua, famous for its arts and letters, and now, thanks to my father's generosity, here I am - with his blessing and your good company. So, my trusty servant - and you've never let me down - why don't we settle here for a time to institute a course of study, a really rigorous curriculum. I was born in Pisa, famous for its serious citizens, like my father before me; my father, Vincentio, a successful, world-traveled merchant, was one of the
Bentivolii. It's only fitting that I, his son, reared in Florence, should concentrate on adding more virtuous deeds to my father's own, stacking them on top of his wealth. For this reason, Tranio, I'll study ethics and - for the time being, anyway - pursue those areas of
philosophy that teach a man how to achieve happiness through virtue. What do you think of all this? Leaving Pisa for Padua,
I feel a little like a thirsty man who turns from a puddle to a vast lake he can drink from.
Bentivolii



philosophy



I feel

paragraphs.original:
Mi perdonato, gentle master mine.
Mi perdonato,
I am in all affected as yourself,
Glad that you thus continue your resolve
To suck the sweets of sweet philosophy.
Only, good master, while we do admire
This virtue and this moral discipline,
Let's be no stoics nor no stocks, I pray,
Or so devote to Aristotle's checks
As Ovid be an outcast quite abjured.
Balk logic with acquaintance that you have,
And practice rhetoric in your common talk;
Music and poesy use to quicken you;
The mathematics and the metaphysics - 
Fall to them as you find your stomach serves you.
No profit grows where is no pleasure ta'en.
In brief, sir, study what you most affect.
paragraphs.translated:
Pardon me, gentle master. As usual, I'm in complete agreement with you about everything, and glad that you still relish the idea of studying philosophy - and let me add that I admire your virtue and your moral discipline. That said, let's not become total
stoics or unfeeling blocks of wood and give up all thought of pleasure. We don't want to become so focused on
Aristotle that we forget to read Ovid. Here's my thought: practice your logic as you chat with your friends, and your rhetoric in ordinary conversation. Use music and poetry to excite your senses. Math and metaphysics - well, I'd play them by ear, spending only as much time on them as you can stand. There's nothing to be gained from things we take no pleasure in. What I'm saying, sir, is this: study what you most enjoy.
stoics



Aristotle

paragraphs.original:
Gramercies, Tranio, well dost thou advise.
If, Biondello, thou wert come ashore,
We could at once put us in readiness
And take a lodging fit to entertain
Such friends as time in Padua shall beget.
But stay awhile. What company is this?
paragraphs.translated: Thanks, Tranio. That's good advice. Now if only Biondello would get here, we could find a nice place to stay where the friends we'll make here in Padua could visit us. Wait! Who are all these people?

paragraphs.original: Master, some show to welcome us to town.

paragraphs.translated: BAPTISTA enters with his elder daughter, KATHERINE, the younger daughter, BIANCA, and two suitors to BIANCA, an old man named GREMIO and a younger man named HORTENSIO.

paragraphs.original:
Gentlemen, importune me no farther,
For how I firmly am resolved you know - 
That is, not to bestow my youngest daughter
Before I have a husband for the elder.
If either of you both love Katherina,
Because I know you well and love you well
Leave shall you have to court her at your pleasure.
paragraphs.translated: Enough, gentlemen! You can't influence me on this point. You know how I feel. I'm determined not to permit my younger daughter to marry until I have a husband for the elder one. I've long regarded you both as good friends. Therefore, if either of you is partial to Katherina, he shall have my permission to court her freely.

paragraphs.original:
To cart her, rather. She's too rough for me. - 
There, there, Hortensio, will you any wife?
paragraphs.translated:
Cart her, you mean. She's too much for me. How about you, Hortensio? Are you still interested in marrying?
Cart

(to
)

"Mates," maid? how mean you that? No mates for you
Unless you were of gentler, milder mold.
paragraphs.translated: We're not your suitors, that's for sure! Not until you improve your temper, girl!

paragraphs.original:
I' faith, sir, you shall never need to fear.
I wis it is not halfway to her heart.
But if it were, doubt not her care should be
To comb your noddle with a three-legged stool
And paint your face and use you like a fool.
paragraphs.translated: Don't worry, I couldn't care less. The only possible interest I could take in you would be to hit you on the head with a stool, paint your face with blood, and make a fool out of you.

paragraphs.original: From all such devils, good Lord, deliver us!
paragraphs.translated: May the good Lord keep me safe from all women like her!

)

(speaking so that only LUCENTIO can hear) Wow! This'll be fun to watch! This girl is either completely crazy or incredibly willful.

)

(speaking so that only
can hear)

and
)

What I have said - Bianca, get you in,

(to GREMIO and HORTENSIO) Gentlemen, since I'd like to make good on what I've said - Bianca, go inside. And don't be unhappy, my dear. Whatever happens, you know I'll never love you less.
(to
and
)

A pretty peat! It is best
Put finger in the eye, an she knew why.
paragraphs.translated: What a spoiled little brat. She'd make herself cry now, if she could think of a reason.

Sister, content you in my discontent. - 
Sir, to your pleasure humbly I subscribe.
My books and instruments shall be my company,
On them to look and practice by myself.
paragraphs.translated: Sister, be happy in my unhappiness. - Sir, I will humbly obey you. I'll take comfort in my books and music, reading and practicing my instruments.

Listen Tranio! That's

Minerva's

Signior Baptista, will you be so strange?
Sorry am I that our goodwill effects
Bianca's grief.
paragraphs.translated: Signior Baptista, will you really be this cruel? I regret that our goodwill should cause Bianca unhappiness.

paragraphs.original:
Why will you mew her up,
Signior Baptista, for this fiend of hell
And make her bear the penance of her tongue?
paragraphs.translated: Why are you locking her away because of this fiend from hell, Signor Baptista? Why does the one daughter have to be punished for the other's mouth?

paragraphs.original:
Gentlemen, content ye. I am resolved. - 
Go in, Bianca.
paragraphs.translated: Gentlemen, I've made my decision. That's all there is to it. Go inside, Bianca.

paragraphs.original: Exit BIANCA
paragraphs.translated: BIANCA exits.

paragraphs.original:
And for I know she taketh most delight
In music, instruments, and poetry,
Schoolmasters will I keep within my house,
Fit to instruct her youth. If you, Hortensio,
Or, Signior Gremio, you know any such,
Prefer them hither, for to cunning men
I will be very kind, and liberal
To mine own children in good bringing up.
And so farewell. - Katherina, you may stay,
For I have more to commune with Bianca.
paragraphs.translated: And because I know how fond she is of music, playing her instruments, and poetry, I plan to hire live-in tutors for her. If either of you gentlemen knows anyone who would be suitable for the job, send him to me. I'll pay well for good teachers. I don't stint when it comes to educating my children. Goodbye, gentlemen. Katherina, you may stay. I have things to discuss with Bianca.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Why, and I trust I may go too, may I not? What, shall I be appointed hours as though, belike, I knew not what to take and what to leave, ha?
paragraphs.translated: Stay out here? I don't think so! Am I to be dictated to, like a child? Told when to come and where to go? No.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: She exits.

paragraphs.original: You may go to the devil's dam! Your gifts are so good here's none will hold you. - Their love is not so great, Hortensio, but we may blow our nails together and fast it fairly out. Our cake's dough on both sides. Farewell. Yet for the love I bear my sweet Bianca, if I can by any means light on a fit man to teach her that wherein she delights, I will wish him to her father.
paragraphs.translated: You can go straight to hell! What you have to offer is nothing anyone wants. Hortensio, our desire to be married isn't so great that we can't wait this out patiently. It's tough on both of us, but I guess we'll live. So long. But to prove my love for Bianca, I'm going to see if I can find a good tutor to give her lessons in the things she enjoys. If I do, I'll send him to her father.

paragraphs.original: So will I, Signior Gremio. But a word, I pray. Though the nature of our quarrel yet never brooked parle, know now upon advice, it toucheth us both, that we may yet again have access to our fair mistress and be happy rivals in Bianca's love, to labor and effect one thing specially.
paragraphs.translated: I'll do the same. But wait - don't go just yet, Signior Gremio. I know we've never exactly been allies, but it might be in both our interests, if you think about it, to put our heads together about one particular thing. That is, if we ever want to return to being rivals for Bianca's love.

paragraphs.original: What's that, I pray?
paragraphs.translated: And that would be - ?

paragraphs.original: Marry, sir, to get a husband for her sister.
paragraphs.translated: To find a husband for her sister.

paragraphs.original: A husband? A devil!
paragraphs.translated: A husband? You mean a devil!

paragraphs.original: I say a husband.
paragraphs.translated: I mean a husband.

paragraphs.original: I say a devil. Think'st thou, Hortensio, though her father be very rich, any man is so very a fool to be married to hell?
paragraphs.translated: I say a devil. Do you really think there's a man fool enough to marry into hell - however rich the father is?

paragraphs.original: Tush, Gremio. Though it pass your patience and mine to endure her loud alarums, why, man, there be good fellows in the world, an a man could light on them, would take her with all faults, and money enough.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, I don't know. Just because we wouldn't want to put up with her tantrums, that doesn't mean there aren't guys who would, if we could find them. Guys who'd take her with all her faults, provided there were enough money involved.

paragraphs.original: I cannot tell. But I had as lief take her dowry with this condition: to be whipped at the high cross every morning.
paragraphs.translated:
I don't know. All I know is I'd rather endure a public whipping every morning than put up with her - even with a big dowry.
I'd

paragraphs.original: Faith, as you say, there's small choice in rotten apples. But come, since this bar in law makes us friends, it shall be so far forth friendly maintained till by helping Baptista's eldest daughter to a husband we set his youngest free for a husband, and then have to 't afresh. Sweet Bianca! Happy man be his dole! He that runs fastest gets the ring. How say you, Signior Gremio?
paragraphs.translated: The two choices are about equal, it's true. But come, since we must be friends in the face of this new obstacle, let's work together to find a husband for Baptista's elder daughter, and thus free his younger daughter to have a husband, too. Then we can go back to fighting with each other. Happy the man that claims you, sweet Bianca! And may the best man win. What do you say, Signior Gremio?

paragraphs.original: I am agreed, and would I had given him the best horse inv Padua to begin his wooing that would thoroughly woo her, wed her, and bed her, and rid the house of her! Come on.
paragraphs.translated: Agreed. This imaginary suitor for Katherina - I'd buy him the best horse in Padua if he'd get here quickly, woo her, marry her, take her to bed, and rid the house of her. Let's go.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt GREMIO and HORTENSIO
paragraphs.translated: GREMIO and HORTENSIO exit.

paragraphs.original:
I pray, sir, tell me, is it possible
That love should of a sudden take such hold?
paragraphs.translated: Sir, is it possible that a person could fall in love so suddenly?

paragraphs.original:
O Tranio, till I found it to be true,
I never thought it possible or likely.
But see, while idly I stood looking on,
I found the effect of love in idleness
And now in plainness do confess to thee
That art to me as secret and as dear
As Anna to the Queen of Carthage was,
Tranio, I burn, I pine, I perish, Tranio,
If I achieve not this young modest girl.
Counsel me, Tranio, for I know thou canst.
Assist me, Tranio, for I know thou wilt.
paragraphs.translated:
Oh, Tranio, until it happened to me, I never would have thought it possible. But now I confess it openly to you, Tranio. You are to me what Anna,
Dido's sister, was to the Queen of Carthage. I confide in you. I tell you, Tranio, I'm on fire, in agony. I'll die if I can't have this modest young girl for my wife. Advise me, Tranio - I know you can. Help me, Tranio - I know you will.
Dido's

paragraphs.original:
Master, it is no time to chide you now.
Affection is not rated from the heart.
If love have touched you, naught remains but so:
Redime te captum quam queas minimo.
Redime te captum quam queas minimo.
paragraphs.translated: Master, this is no moment to lecture you. The heart won't be reasoned with. If love has touched you, love has touched you - end of story. But, as the Roman Terence advises, now that you're a captive, it's time to buy back your freedom at the lowest possible cost.

paragraphs.original:
Gramercies, lad, go forward. This contents.
The rest will comfort, for thy counsel's sound.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, you're right. Please go on. I feel better already, and I know there's more good advice where that came from.

paragraphs.original:
Master, you looked so longly on the maid,
Perhaps you marked not what's the pith of all.
paragraphs.translated: Master, you were so focused on the girl herself, I wonder if you missed the main point here.

paragraphs.original:
Oh yes, I saw sweet beauty in her face
Such as the daughter of Agenor had,
That made great Jove to humble him to her hand
When with his knees he kissed the Cretan strand.
paragraphs.translated:
Oh no! I saw sweetness and beauty in her face of the kind that humbled great
Jove. He saw it in Europa that time she brought him to his knees in Crete.
Jove

paragraphs.original:
Saw you no more? Marked you not how her sister
Began to scold and raise up such a storm
That mortal ears might hardly endure the din?
paragraphs.translated: That's all you noticed? You missed the part where her sister began to scold her and made such a ruckus that human ears could hardly stand it?

paragraphs.original:
Tranio, I saw her coral lips to move
And with her breath she did perfume the air.
Sacred and sweet was all I saw in her.
paragraphs.translated: Tranio, I saw her coral-pink lips move and perfume the air with her breath. I saw nothing in her except what is virtuous and lovely.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) Nay, then, 'tis time to stir him from his trance. - 
(aside)
I pray, awake, sir! If you love the maid,
Bend thoughts and wits to achieve her. Thus it stands:
Her eldest sister is so curst and shrewd
That till the father rid his hands of her,
Master, your love must live a maid at home,
And therefore has he closely mewed her up,
Because she will not be annoyed with suitors.
paragraphs.translated:
(to the audience) I think it's time to rouse him from his trance. - Wake up, sir! If you love the girl, it's time to figure out how to win her. The way things stand, her older sister is so bitchy and difficult that the father can't wait to get rid of her. But until he does, your sweetheart is grounded, locked up at home and not allowed any suitors.
(to the audience)

paragraphs.original:
Ah, Tranio, what a cruel father's he!
But art thou not advised, he took some care
To get her cunning schoolmasters to instruct her?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, Tranio, what a cruel father he is. Still, did you notice how ready he was to hire good tutors for her?

paragraphs.original: Ay, marry, am I, sir; and now 'tis plotted!
paragraphs.translated: I did - and now I've got it!

paragraphs.original: I have it, Tranio!
paragraphs.translated: Tranio, I think I've got it!

paragraphs.original:
Master, for my hand,
Both our inventions meet and jump in one.
paragraphs.translated: I'll bet we're both thinking the same thing, master.

paragraphs.original: Tell me thine first.
paragraphs.translated: Tell me your idea first.

paragraphs.original:
You will be schoolmaster
And undertake the teaching of the maid:
That's your device.
paragraphs.translated: You will pretend to be a schoolmaster and offer to teach the girl. Is that your plan?

paragraphs.original: It is. May it be done?
paragraphs.translated: It is. Do you think it would work?

paragraphs.original:
Not possible. For who shall bear your part
And be in Padua here Vincentio's son,
Keep house and ply his book, welcome his friends,
Visit his countrymen and banquet them?
paragraphs.translated: No, not a chance. You're supposed to be here in Padua studying. So who would fill in for you - pretend to be Vincentio's son, live in his house, pore over his books, welcome his friends, and wine and dine his fellow expatriates from Pisa?

paragraphs.original:
Basta, content thee, for I have it full.
Basta,
We have not yet been seen in any house,
Nor can we be distinguished by our faces
For man or master. Then it follows thus:
Thou shalt be master, Tranio, in my stead,
Keep house and port and servants as I should.
I will some other be, some Florentine,
Some Neapolitan, or meaner man of Pisa.
'Tis hatched, and shall be so. Tranio, at once
Uncase thee. Take my colored hat and cloak.
paragraphs.translated:
Enough! Don't worry, I have it all figured out. No one has seen us yet, and no one knows what we look like - which of us is master and which servant. It's obvious: You will be me, Tranio - live in my house, instruct the servants and do everything in my place just as I would. I, meanwhile, will impersonate some other made-up fellow - some guy from Florence or Naples, or some poor guy from Pisa. There! That's a plan. Take off what you're wearing and put on my hat and cloak.
You
me,

Where have I been? Where are you? Has Tranio stolen your clothes, master? Or have you stolen his? Have you both stolen each other's? Please, what's going on?

you?

Your fellow Tranio here, to save my life,
Puts my apparel and my countenance on,

paragraphs.original:
Aye, sir. (aside) Ne'er a whit.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:

(to the audience)

paragraphs.original:
And not a jot of "Tranio" in your mouth.

paragraphs.original: The better for him. Would I were so too.
paragraphs.translated: Lucky for him. Wish I could say the same.

paragraphs.original:

That Lucentio indeed had Baptista's youngest daughter.
But, sirrah, not for my sake, but your master's, I advise
You use your manners discreetly in all kind of companies.
When I am alone, why then I am Tranio;
But in all places else, your master Lucentio.
paragraphs.translated: I'd second your wish if it automatically meant that Lucentio could have Baptista's youngest daughter. This is for your master's sake, not mine. So watch your step when there are other people around. When we're by ourselves you can call me "Tranio." Everywhere else, address me as your master Lucentio.

paragraphs.original: Tranio, let's go. One thing more rests, that thyself execute, to make one among these wooers. If thou ask me why, sufficeth my reasons are both good and weighty.
paragraphs.translated: Tranio, let's go. One last thing, and this is up to you. You'll have to woo Bianca like the rest. Don't ask why. Just trust me - I know what I'm doing.

paragraphs.translated: No, no. I am. Really. Very impressive. Is there any more, or is that it?

paragraphs.translated: PETRUCHIO enters with his servant GRUMIO.

paragraphs.original:
Verona, for a while I take my leave,
To see my friends in Padua, but of all
My best belovèd and approvèd friend,
Hortensio. And I trow this is his house.
Here, sirrah Grumio. Knock, I say.
paragraphs.translated: Farewell, Verona! I'm off to visit my friends in Padua - particularly my best friend Hortensio. And I think this is his house. Here, you there, Grumio. Knock.

paragraphs.original: Knock, sir? Whom should I knock? Is there any man has rebused your Worship?
paragraphs.translated: Knock, sir? Whom should I knock? Has anyone offended your Worship?

paragraphs.original: Villain, I say, knock me here soundly.
paragraphs.translated: Moron! I'm telling you to make a fist and pound.

paragraphs.translated:
Really, sir, I hardly think it would be appropriate for me to
pound you.
pound

Villain, I say, knock me at this gate
And rap me well, or I'll knock your knave's pate.
paragraphs.translated: Moron, here we are at the gate. Now put your fists to work, or I'll put mine to work on your head!

paragraphs.original:
My master is grown quarrelsome. I should knock you first,
And then I know after who comes by the worst.
paragraphs.translated: My master is being difficult. If I do as he asks I think I know which one of us will be sorrier - and it's not going to be him!

paragraphs.original:
Will it not be?
Faith, sirrah, an you'll not knock, I'll ring it.
I'll try how you can sol, fa, and sing it.
sol, fa,
paragraphs.translated: What are you standing there for! If you won't knock, I'll ring - and you'll be singing along in falsetto!

paragraphs.original: He wrings him by the ears
paragraphs.translated: He grabs him by the ears.

paragraphs.original: Help, mistress, help! My master is mad.
paragraphs.translated:
(to the unseen mistress or master of the house) Help, mistress, help! My master has gone mad.
(to the unseen mistress or master of the house)

paragraphs.original: Now knock when I bid you, sirrah villain.
paragraphs.translated: Next time maybe you'll knock when I tell you, punk kid!

paragraphs.translated: HORTENSIO enters.

paragraphs.original: How now, what's the matter? My old friend Grumio and my good friend Petruchio? How do you all at Verona?
paragraphs.translated: Say, what's the trouble? If it isn't my old friend Grumio - and my dear friend Petruchio! How's everyone in Verona?

paragraphs.original:
Signior Hortensio, come you to part the fray?
Con tutto il cuore, ben trovato, may I say.
Con tutto il cuore, ben trovato,
paragraphs.translated:
Hortensio, have you come to break up the fight?
Con tutto il cuore ben trovato, if I may say so.
Con tutto il cuore ben trovato,
Con tutto il cuore ben trovato

paragraphs.original:
Alla nostra casa ben venuto, molto honorato signor mio
Petruchio. - Rise, Grumio, rise. We will compound this quarrel.
paragraphs.translated:
Alla nostra casa ben venuto, molto honorato signor mio Petruchio! Get up, Grumio. We'll settle this quarrel.
Alla nostra casa ben venuto, molto honorato signor mio Petruchio!
Alla nostra casa ben venuto, molto honorato signor mio Petruchio!

paragraphs.original:
Nay, 'tis no matter, sir, what he 'leges in Latin. If this be not a lawful case for me to leave his service - look you, sir: he bid me knock him and rap him soundly, sir. Well, was it fit for a servant to use his master so, being perhaps, for aught I see, two-and-thirty, a pip out?
Whom, would to God, I had well knocked at first,
Then had not Grumio come by the worst.
paragraphs.translated:
I don't care what he told you in Latin. If this isn't legal justification for me to leave his service, I don't know what is. He tells me to knock him, pound him, and put my fists to work on him. Well, I ask you, was that any way for a servant to behave toward his master - especially when he's clearly a bit crazy. I wish I had hit him. I think I'd feel a lot better.
had

paragraphs.original:
A senseless villain, good Hortensio.
I bade the rascal knock upon your gate
And could not get him for my heart to do it.
paragraphs.translated: He's a worthless dog, Hortensio. I told him to knock at your gate and for the life of me could not get him to do it.

paragraphs.original: Knock at the gate? O heavens! Spake you not these words plain: "Sirrah, knock me here, rap me here, knock me well, and knock me soundly"? And come you now with "knocking at the gate"?
paragraphs.translated: Knock at the gate? Oh, for Pete's sake! Didn't you clearly say "Knock," "pound," and "put your fists to work"? Now you say it was "Knock at the gate"?

paragraphs.original: Sirrah, begone or talk not, I advise you.
paragraphs.translated: Grumio, either leave or shut up. I'm warning you.

paragraphs.original:
Petruchio, patience. I am Grumio's pledge.
Why, this' a heavy chance 'twixt him and you,
Your ancient, trusty, pleasant servant Grumio.
And tell me now, sweet friend, what happy gale
Blows you to Padua here from old Verona?
paragraphs.translated: Easy, Petruchio. I'll vouch for Grumio. It's terrible - you two fighting! Faithful, funny old Grumio! You guys go way back! Now, my dear friend, what lucky wind blows you in from Verona?

paragraphs.original:
Such wind as scatters young men through the world
To seek their fortunes farther than at home,
Where small experience grows. But in a few,
Signior Hortensio, thus it stands with me:
Antonio, my father, is deceased,
And I have thrust myself into this maze,
Happily to wive and thrive as best I may.
Crowns in my purse I have and goods at home,
And so am come abroad to see the world.
paragraphs.translated: The wind that scatters young men throughout the world, encouraging them to seek their fortunes some place other than home, where there's little to be found in the way of experience. But to be brief, Hortensio, the situation is that my father, Antonio, is dead, and I have set off into this crazy world to see if I can marry well and make a good life for myself. I have money in my purse and property at home, so I'm off to see the world.

paragraphs.original:
Petruchio, shall I then come roundly to thee
And wish thee to a shrewd, ill-favored wife?
Thou'dst thank me but a little for my counsel;
And yet I'll promise thee she shall be rich,
And very rich. But thou'rt too much my friend,
And I'll not wish thee to her.
paragraphs.translated: Petruchio, shall I be frank? I know where you can find a shrewish and unpleasant wife. I doubt you'd thank me in the end, but she's rich, all right, very rich. But you're too good a friend for me to wish her on you.

paragraphs.original:
Signior Hortensio, 'twixt such friends as we
Few words suffice. And therefore, if thou know
One rich enough to be Petruchio's wife,
As wealth is burden of my wooing dance,
Be she as foul as was Florentius' love,
As old as Sibyl and as curst and shrewd
As Socrates' Xanthippe, or a worse,
She moves me not, or not removes at least
Affection's edge in me, were she as rough
As are the swelling Adriatic seas.
I come to wive it wealthily in Padua;
If wealthily, then happily in Padua.
paragraphs.translated:
Hortensio, good friends like us can get by on a few words. If you can find a woman rich enough for me - because money is all I look for in a wife - let her be as ugly as
Flotentius's love, as old as the Sibyl, and as bad-tempered as Xanthippe. It wouldn't matter one way or the other. I've come here in search of a rich wife. If I find a rich wife in Padua, I'll have found a good wife in Padua.
Flotentius's

paragraphs.original:
Petruchio, since we are stepped thus far in,
I will continue that I broached in jest.
I can, Petruchio, help thee to a wife
With wealth enough, and young and beauteous,
Brought up as best becomes a gentlewoman.
Her only fault, and that is faults enough,
Is that she is intolerable curst,
And shrewd and froward, so beyond all measure
That, were my state far worser than it is,
I would not wed her for a mine of gold.
paragraphs.translated: Petruchio, since the conversation's gone this far, I may as well carry on with what I mentioned purely as a joke. I can help you find a wife who's rich, young, beautiful, and reared in a manner fit for a gentlewoman. Her only flaw - and it's a big one - is that she's unbearable, a total witch, so much so that I wouldn't think of marrying her myself, not even if I were in a worse fix than I am, not for a whole goldmine.

paragraphs.original:
Hortensio, peace. Thou know'st not gold's effect.
Tell me her father's name, and 'tis enough;
For I will board her, though she chide as loud
As thunder when the clouds in autumn crack.
paragraphs.translated: Hush, Hortensio. You don't know what money can buy. Tell me her father's name - that's all I need. I will go after her even if her scolding is as deafening as thunder in an autumn rainstorm.

paragraphs.original:
Her father is Baptista Minola,
An affable and courteous gentleman.
Her name is Katherina Minola,
Renowned in Padua for her scolding tongue.
paragraphs.translated: Her father is Baptista Minola, a pleasant and courteous gentleman. Her name is Katherina Minola, famous throughout Padua for her scolding tongue.

paragraphs.original:
I know her father, though I know not her,
And he knew my deceasèd father well.
I will not sleep, Hortensio, till I see her,
And therefore let me be thus bold with you
To give you over at this first encounter,
Unless you will accompany me thither.
paragraphs.translated: I don't know her, but I know her father and he knew mine well. I won't sleep until I see her, Hortensio. So I hope you'll forgive my cutting short this first conversation of ours - unless you want to come with me.

paragraphs.original:
Tarry, Petruchio, I must go with thee,
For in Baptista's keep my treasure is.
He hath the jewel of my life in hold,
His youngest daughter, beautiful Bianca,
And her withholds from me and other more,
Suitors to her and rivals in my love,
Supposing it a thing impossible,
For those defects I have before rehearsed,
That ever Katherina will be wooed.
Therefore this order hath Baptista ta'en,
That none shall have access unto Bianca
Till Katherine the curst have got a husband.
paragraphs.translated: Wait, Petruchio, I should go with you. My own "wealth" is in Baptista's keeping. His youngest daughter, the beautiful Bianca, is the jewel of my life, and he keeps her hidden away from me and other rivals for her hand. Because he finds it so incredible - owing to those character deficiencies I mentioned before - that any man will ever come courting Katherina, Baptista has therefore issued this edict: that none shall be permitted to court Bianca until that Katherine the shrew finds a husband.

paragraphs.original:
"Katherine the curst!"
A title for a maid of all titles the worst.
paragraphs.translated: "Katherine the shrew!" That's the worst thing you can call a young woman.

paragraphs.original:
Now shall my friend Petruchio do me grace,
And offer me disguised in sober robes
To old Baptista as a schoolmaster
Well seen in music, to instruct Bianca,
That so I may, by this device at least,
Have leave and leisure to make love to her
And, unsuspected, court her by herself.
paragraphs.translated: Now my friend Petruchio will help me out, presenting me to old Baptista as a schoolmaster for Bianca well-versed in music. I'll disguise myself in somber robes. In this costume, I'll be able to spend time with her alone, which will give me plenty of opportunity to court her.

paragraphs.original: Here's no knavery! See, to beguile the old folks, how the young folks lay their heads together!
paragraphs.translated:
Oh, very nice! See how the young folks conspire to fool the old folks!
very

paragraphs.original: Enter GREMIO and LUCENTIO disguised as CAMBIO
paragraphs.translated: GREMIO enters with LUCENTIO, disguised as CAMBIO.

paragraphs.original: Master, master, look about you. Who goes there, ha?
paragraphs.translated: Master, master, look! Who are these people?

paragraphs.original:
Peace, Grumio. It is the rival of my love.
Petruchio, stand by a while.
paragraphs.translated: Hush, Grumio. It is my rival for Bianca. Petruchio, let's stand over here awhile.

paragraphs.original: PETRUCHIO, HORTENSIO, and GRUMIO stand aside
paragraphs.translated: PETRUCHIO, HORTENSIO, and GRUMIO stand off to the side.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) A proper stripling, and an amorous.
(aside)

(to LUCENTIO) O, very well, I have perused the note.
(to
)
Hark you, sir: I'll have them very fairly bound,
All books of love. See that at any hand,
And see you read no other lectures to her.
You understand me. Over and beside
Signior Baptista's liberality,
I'll mend it with a largess. Take your paper too.
And let me have them very well perfum'd
For she is sweeter than perfume itself
To whom they go to. What will you read to her?

(as CAMBIO) Whate'er I read to her, I'll plead for you
(as
)
As for my patron, stand you so assured,
As firmly as yourself were still in place,
Yea, and perhaps with more successful words
Than you, unless you were a scholar, sir.
O this learning, what a thing it is!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, what an excellent thing this learning is!

paragraphs.original:
(aside) O this woodcock, what an ass it is!
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
(speaking to the audience) Oh, what an asinine thing this moron is!
(speaking to the audience)

paragraphs.original:
(aside) Peace, sirrah!
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
(speaking so that only GRUMIO can hear) Silence, boy!
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
(aside) Grumio, mum! God save you, Signior Gremio.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
(speaking so that only GRUMIO can hear) Grumio, hush! (to GREMIO, who can't hear him) God save you, Signior Gremio.
(speaking so that only
can hear)
(to
, who can't hear him)

paragraphs.original:
And you are well met, Signior Hortensio.
Trow you whither I am going? To Baptista Minola.
I promised to enquire carefully
About a schoolmaster for the fair Bianca,
And by good fortune I have lighted well
On this young man, for learning and behavior
Fit for her turn, well read in poetry
And other books - good ones, I warrant ye.
paragraphs.translated: Good to see you, Signior Hortensio. Do you know where I'm going? To Baptista Minola's house. I promised to look into schoolmasters for Miss Bianca, and luck has led me to this young man, perfectly suited in learning and fine manners, well read in poetry and other books - all of them good, I assure you.

paragraphs.original:
'Tis well. And I have met a gentleman
Hath promised me to help me to another,
A fine musician to instruct our mistress.
So shall I no whit be behind in duty
To fair Bianca, so beloved of me.
paragraphs.translated: That's great. And I have met a gentleman who promises to help me find a good music tutor to instruct our lady love. I wouldn't want to fall behind in my devotion to my beloved Bianca.

paragraphs.original: Beloved of me, and that my deeds shall prove.
paragraphs.translated:
My beloved - as my actions will prove.
My

paragraphs.original:
(aside) And that his bags shall prove.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
(speaking to the audience) As his moneybags will prove.
(speaking to the audience)

paragraphs.original:
Gremio, 'tis now no time to vent our love.
Listen to me, and if you speak me fair,
I'll tell you news indifferent good for either.
paragraphs.translated: Gremio, this is no time to compete over how deeply we love Bianca. Be nice and listen to me a moment, and I'll give you a piece of news that's equally good for both of us.

paragraphs.original:
(presenting PETRUCHIO)
(presenting
)
Here is a gentleman whom by chance I met,
Upon agreement from us to his liking,
Will undertake to woo curst Katherine,
Yea, and to marry her, if her dowry please.

So said, so done, is well.
Hortensio, have you told him all her faults?
paragraphs.translated: That's good, if he'll really do it. Have you told him all her faults, Hortensio?

paragraphs.original:
I know she is an irksome brawling scold.
If that be all, masters, I hear no harm.
paragraphs.translated: I know she is a hateful, brawling scold. If that's all, gentlemen, I see no problem.

paragraphs.original: No? Say'st me so, friend? What countryman?
paragraphs.translated: No? Tell me, friend. Where are you from?

paragraphs.original:
Born in Verona, old Antonio's son.
My father dead, my fortune lives for me.
And I do hope good days and long to see.
paragraphs.translated: Born in Verona. I'm old Antonio's son. My father's dead, and his fortune is mine now. I hope to see good days - and many of them.

paragraphs.original:
O sir, such a life with such a wife were strange!
But if you have a stomach, to 't, i' God's name:
You shall have me assisting you in all.
But will you woo this wildcat?
paragraphs.translated: Sir, such a life with such a wife is unlikely! But if you have the stomach for it, you'll have all the help from me you need. Do you really mean to go after this wildcat?

paragraphs.original: Will I live?
paragraphs.translated: Do I mean to go on breathing?

paragraphs.original: Will he woo her? Ay, or I'll hang her.
paragraphs.translated: He'll woo her or I'll hang her.

paragraphs.original:
Why came I hither but to that intent?
Think you a little din can daunt mine ears?
Have I not in my time heard lions roar?
Have I not heard the sea, puffed up with winds,
Rage like an angry boar chafèd with sweat?
Have I not heard great ordnance in the field,
And heaven's artillery thunder in the skies?
paragraphs.translated: Why did I come here if not for that? Do you think a little burst of noise can intimidate me - I, who have heard lions roar? I, who have survived storms at sea where the winds raged like wild animals? I, who have heard the rumble of guns in battle - and thunder in the sky (heaven's version of artillery).

paragraphs.original:
Have I not in a pitchèd battle heard
Loud 'larums, neighing steeds, and trumpets' clang?
And do you tell me of a woman's tongue
That gives not half so great a blow to hear
As will a chestnut in a farmer's fire?
Tush, tush! Fear boys with bugs.
paragraphs.translated:
Have I not stood in the middle of a battle, with loud calls to arms, horses neighing, and trumpets sounding all around me? And you worry how I'll react to a woman's tongue, which isn't even as loud as the pop! of a chestnut roasting in some farmer's oven? Please. Scare children with your bugaboos.
pop!

paragraphs.original: For he fears none.
paragraphs.translated: Because he's not afraid of them.

paragraphs.original:
Hortensio, hark.
This gentleman is happily arrived,
My mind presumes, for his own good and ours.
paragraphs.translated: Listen, Hortensio. I think this gentleman's arrival could be most fortunate - both for himself and for us.

paragraphs.original:
I promised we would be contributors
And bear his charge of wooing, whatsoe'er.
paragraphs.translated: I promised him that we would all chip in and take care of the wooing expenses, whatever they come to.

paragraphs.original: And so we will, provided that he win her.
paragraphs.translated: Absolutely - so long as he gets the girl.

paragraphs.original: I would I were as sure of a good dinner.
paragraphs.translated: I wish I could be as certain of a good dinner.

paragraphs.original: Enter TRANIO brave and BIONDELLO
paragraphs.translated: TRANIO enters, lavishly dressed in gentlemen's clothes; he is accompanied by BIONDELLO.

paragraphs.original:
(as LUCENTIO) Gentlemen, God save you. If I may be bold,
(as
)
Tell me, I beseech you, which is the readiest way
To the house of Signior Baptista Minola?
He that has the two fair daughters - is 't he you mean?
paragraphs.translated: The old man with the two pretty daughters? Is that the man you want?

paragraphs.original: Hark you, sir, you mean not her to -
paragraphs.translated: Pardon, sir, I hope you're not looking for the daughter -

paragraphs.original:
(as LUCENTIO)
(as
)
Perhaps him and her, sir. What have you to do?
Not her that chides, sir, at any hand, I pray.
paragraphs.translated: But not the woman who scolds, anyway, I hope.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) Well begun, Tranio.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
(speaking quietly) Nice work, Tranio!
(speaking quietly)

paragraphs.original:
Sir, a word ere you go.
Are you a suitor to the maid you talk of, yea or no?
paragraphs.translated: Sir, a word before you go. Are you a suitor to the girl we speak of, yes or no?

paragraphs.original: An if I be, sir, is it any offense?
paragraphs.translated: What if I am? Is there a problem?

paragraphs.original: No, if without more words you will get you hence.
paragraphs.translated: Not if you go away, there isn't.

paragraphs.original: But so is not she.
paragraphs.translated:
But she isn't.
she

paragraphs.original: For what reason, I beseech you?
paragraphs.translated: And why is that, please?

paragraphs.original:
For this reason, if you'll know:
That she's the choice love of Signior Gremio.
paragraphs.translated: Because, if you must know, she's been chosen by Signior Gremio.

paragraphs.original: That she's the chosen of Signior Hortensio.
paragraphs.translated: Because she's been chosen by Signior Hortensio.

paragraphs.original:
Softly, my masters. If you be gentlemen,
Do me this right: hear me with patience.
Baptista is a noble gentleman,
To whom my father is not all unknown,
And were his daughter fairer than she is,
She may more suitors have, and me for one.
paragraphs.translated: Wait a minute, gentlemen. Be good enough to hear me out. Baptista is a noble gentleman - one to whom my father is not completely unknown - and lovely as his daughter is, she is entitled to any number of suitors - myself among them.

paragraphs.original:
Fair Leda's daughter had a thousand wooers;
Then well one more may fair Bianca have.
And so she shall. Lucentio shall make one,
Though
Paris came in hope to speed alone.
Paris
paragraphs.translated: The beautiful Helen of Troy had a thousand suitors. Let Bianca have one more - anyway, she's got one. Lucentio shall join the ranks, even if Paris himself comes to woo her.

paragraphs.original: What! This gentleman will out-talk us all.
paragraphs.translated: This fellow will out-talk us all.

paragraphs.original: Hortensio, to what end are all these words?
paragraphs.translated: Hortensio, what's all this about?

paragraphs.original:
(to TRANIO) Sir, let me be so bold as ask you,
(to
)
Did you yet ever see Baptista's daughter?

(as LUCENTIO) No, sir, but hear I do that he hath two,
(as
)
The one as famous for a scolding tongue
As is the other for beauteous modesty.
Sir, sir, the first's for me; let her go by.
paragraphs.translated: The first one's mine, so hands off!

paragraphs.original:
Yea, leave that labor to great Hercules,
And let it be more than Alcides' twelve.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, leave that labor to great Hercules - it's worse than the previous twelve put together.

paragraphs.original:
(to TRANIO) Sir, understand you this of me, in sooth:
(to
)
The youngest daughter, whom you hearken for,
Her father keeps from all access of suitors
And will not promise her to any man
Until the elder sister first be wed.
The younger then is free, and not before.

(as LUCENTIO) If it be so, sir, that you are the man
(as
)
Must stead us all, and me amongst the rest,
And if you break the ice and do this feat,
Achieve the elder, set the younger free
For our access, whose hap shall be to have her
Will not so graceless be to be ingrate.

Sir, you say well, and well you do conceive.
And since you do profess to be a suitor,
You must, as we do, gratify this gentleman,
To whom we all rest generally beholding.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, that's well said and well thought out. Now, since you count yourself among Bianca's suitors, you must - as we already have - pay this gentlemen to whom we are all so indebted.

paragraphs.original:
(as LUCENTIO) Sir, I shall not be slack; in sign whereof,
(as
)
Please ye we may contrive this afternoon
And quaff carouses to our mistress' health
And do as adversaries do in law,
Strive mightily, but eat and drink as friends.
O excellent motion! Fellows, let's be gone.
paragraphs.translated: An excellent motion. Let's go.

paragraphs.original:
The motion's good indeed and be it so. - 
Petruchio, I shall be your ben venuto.
ben venuto.
paragraphs.translated:
I second that
motion. So be it. Petruchio, I'm buying.
motion

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter KATHERINE and BIANCA, her hands bound
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE and BIANCA enter. BIANCA'S hands are tied.

paragraphs.original:
Good sister, wrong me not nor wrong yourself,
To make a bondmaid and a slave of me.
That I disdain. But for these other goods - 
Unbind my hands, I'll pull them off myself,
Yea, all my raiment to my petticoat,
Or what you will command me will I do,
So well I know my duty to my elders.
paragraphs.translated:
Dear sister, it's unfair to me - and unfair to yourself - to turn me into a slave. That I won't stand for. But if you want my things - untie my hands and I'll give them to you myself, everything, even down to my slip. Or anything else you order me to do. I know I should obey my elders.
things

paragraphs.original:
Of all thy suitors here I charge thee tell
Whom thou lovest best. See thou dissemble not.
paragraphs.translated: What I want is for you to tell me which of your suitors you like best. And don't lie.

paragraphs.original:
Believe me, sister, of all the men alive
I never yet beheld that special face
Which I could fancy more than any other.
paragraphs.translated: I swear, dear sister, I have not yet encountered that special face I might prefer to any other.

paragraphs.original: Minion, thou liest. Is 't not Hortensio?
paragraphs.translated: You lying brat. It's Hortensio, isn't it?

paragraphs.original:
If you affect him, sister, here I swear
I'll plead for you myself, but you shall have him.
paragraphs.translated: If you want him, dear sister, he's yours. I swear I'll woo him for you myself.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, then belike you fancy riches more.
You will have Gremio to keep you fair.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, I see. You're more interested in money. You'll live in luxury with Gremio.

paragraphs.original:
Is it for him you do envy me so?
Nay, then you jest, and now I well perceive
You have but jested with me all this while.
I prithee, sister Kate, untie my hands.
paragraphs.translated:
Is it because of him that you envy me? You must be kidding! And now I see that you've been joking all the while. Please, Kate, untie my hands.
him

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE strikes her
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE strikes her.

paragraphs.original: If that be jest, then all the rest was so.
paragraphs.translated:
If that's a joke, I guess the rest was, too.
that's

paragraphs.original: Enter BAPTISTA
paragraphs.translated: BAPTISTA enters.

paragraphs.original:
Why, how now, dame! whence grows this insolence? - 
Bianca, stand aside. - Poor girl, she weeps!
(to BIANCA) Go ply thy needle; meddle not with her.
(to
)
(to KATHERINE) For shame, thou hilding of a devilish spirit!
(to
)
Why dost thou wrong her that did ne'er wrong thee?
When did she cross thee with a bitter word?
Her silence flouts me, and I'll be revenged.
paragraphs.translated: She mocks me with her silence, and I'll get my revenge on her.

paragraphs.original: Flies after BIANCA
paragraphs.translated: She runs at BIANCA as if she's going to strike her.

paragraphs.original: What, in my sight? - Bianca, get thee in.
paragraphs.translated: What, in my presence? How dare you! - Bianca, go inside.

paragraphs.original: Exit BIANCA
paragraphs.translated: BIANCA exits.

paragraphs.original:
What, will you not suffer me? Nay, now I see
She is your treasure, she must have a husband,
I must dance barefoot on her wedding day
And, for your love to her, lead apes in hell.
Talk not to me. I will go sit and weep
Till I can find occasion of revenge.
paragraphs.translated: You mean you don't even want to hear my side? Of course! She's your treasure. She must have a husband and I must dance barefoot on her wedding day. You like her best and so I'll die an old maid. Don't talk to me. I'll just go cry myself sick and think of some way to get back at all of you.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: She exits.

paragraphs.original:
Was ever gentleman thus grieved as I?
But who comes here?
paragraphs.translated: Has any man ever had to put up with what I do? Now what?

paragraphs.original: Enter GREMIO, LUCENTIO in the habit of a mean man; PETRUCHIO, with HORTENSIO as a musician; and TRANIO, with BIONDELLO bearing a lute and books
paragraphs.translated: GREMIO enters with LUCENTIO, dressed as a poor man; PETRUCHIO enters with HORTENSIO, disguised as a musician; TRANIO, disguised as LUCENTIO, enters with BIONDELLO, who is carrying a lute and books.

paragraphs.original: Good morrow, neighbor Baptista.
paragraphs.translated: Good morning, neighbor Baptista.

paragraphs.original: Good morrow, neighbor Gremio. - God save you, gentlemen!
