paragraphs.translated: Good morning, neighbor Gremio. Greetings, gentlemen.

paragraphs.original:
And you, good sir. Pray, have you not a daughter
Called Katherina, fair and virtuous?
paragraphs.translated: And to you, good sir. Tell me, don't you have a virtuous and lovely daughter named Katherina?

paragraphs.original: I have a daughter, sir, called Katherina.
paragraphs.translated: I have a daughter named Katherina, sir.

paragraphs.original:
You wrong me, Signior Gremio. Give me leave. - 
I am a gentleman of Verona, sir,
That hearing of her beauty and her wit,
Her affability and bashful modesty,
Her wondrous qualities and mild behavior,
Am bold to show myself a forward guest
Within your house, to make mine eye the witness
Of that report which I so oft have heard.
And, for an entrance to my entertainment,
I do present you with a man of mine,
(presenting HORTENSIO, disguised as LITIO)
(presenting
, disguised as
)
Cunning in music and the mathematics,
To instruct her fully in those sciences,
Whereof I know she is not ignorant.
Accept of him, or else you do me wrong.
His name is Litio, born in Mantua.
paragraphs.translated:
Please, Signior Gremio. Allow me to continue. - I am a gentleman of Verona, sir, who, hearing of your daughter's beauty and wit, her friendly disposition and bashful modesty, her uncommon virtues and her mild behavior, have taken the liberty of presenting myself as a guest at your house in the hope of seeing for myself if what I've heard is true. And, as the price of admission for being received by you, I here present you with a servant of mine. (he presents HORTENSIO, disguised as LITIO). He is expert in the fields of music and mathematics. I thought he might instruct her in those branches of knowledge - of which she is, I gather, no beginner. Be good enough to accept this gift - I'll be offended if you don't. His name is Litio, and he comes from Mantua.
he presents
, disguised as
)

paragraphs.original:
You're welcome, sir, and he for your good sake.
But for my daughter Katherine, this I know,
She is not for your turn, the more my grief.
paragraphs.translated: You and he are both welcome, sir. As for my daughter Katherine, this much I know: she's not for you - more's the pity.

paragraphs.original:
I see you do not mean to part with her,
Or else you like not of my company.
paragraphs.translated: I see you don't intend to part with her - or perhaps you don't like my company.

paragraphs.original:
Mistake me not. I speak but as I find.
Whence are you, sir? What may I call your name?
paragraphs.translated: Don't misunderstand me, sir. I'm just stating the facts as I see them. Where are you from? What's your name?

paragraphs.original:
Petruchio is my name, Antonio's son,
A man well known throughout all Italy.
paragraphs.translated: My name is Petruchio, son of Antonio, a man well known throughout Italy.

paragraphs.original: I know him well. You are welcome for his sake.
paragraphs.translated: I know him well. You are welcome for his sake.

paragraphs.original:
Saving your tale, Petruchio, I pray
Let us that are poor petitioners speak too.
Bacare, you are marvelous forward.
Bacare,
paragraphs.translated:
With all due respect, Petruchio, give someone else a chance to speak. You're so aggressive!
so

paragraphs.original: Oh, pardon me, Signior Gremio, I would fain be doing.
paragraphs.translated: Forgive me, Signior Gremio, but I'm anxious to get things moving.

paragraphs.original:
I doubt it not, sir, but you will curse your wooing. - 
Neighbor, this is a gift very grateful, I am sure of it. To express the like kindness, myself, that have been more kindly beholding to you than any, freely give unto you this young scholar (presenting LUCENTIO, disguised as CAMBIO) that hath been long studying at Rheims, as cunning in Greek, Latin, and other languages as the other in music and mathematics. His name is Cambio. Pray accept his service.
(presenting
, disguised as
)
paragraphs.translated:
No doubt, but you may be going about it the wrong way - Neighbor, this gift is very gracious, I'm sure. I myself, who am more indebted to you than anyone, have brought you this young scholar (presenting LUCENTIO, disguised as CAMBIO) who has long studied at
Rheims. He is as expert in Greek, Latin, and other languages as that other man is in music and mathematics. His name is Cambio. Please accept his services.
(presenting
, disguised as
)
Rheims

paragraphs.original:
A thousand thanks, Signior Gremio. Welcome, good Cambio. (to TRANIO as LUCENTIO) But, gentle sir, methinks you walk like a stranger. May I be so bold to know the cause of your coming?
(to
as
)
paragraphs.translated:
Many thanks, Signior Gremio. Welcome, good Cambio. (to TRANIO as LUCENTIO) As for you, sir, you would appear to be a stranger. May I be so bold as to ask your reason for coming?
(to
as
)

paragraphs.original:
(as LUCENTIO) Pardon me, sir, the boldness is mine own,
(as
)
That being a stranger in this city here
Do make myself a suitor to your daughter,
Unto Bianca, fair and virtuous.
Nor is your firm resolve unknown to me,
In the preferment of the eldest sister.
This liberty is all that I request,
That, upon knowledge of my parentage,
I may have welcome 'mongst the rest that woo
And free access and favor as the rest.
And toward the education of your daughters,
I here bestow a simple instrument
And this small packet of Greek and Latin books.
BIONDELLO brings the gifts forward
brings the gifts forward
If you accept them, then their worth is great.
paragraphs.translated:
(as LUCENTIO) Pardon me, sir, the boldness is all mine in seeking to court your fair and virtuous daughter, Bianca. I am indeed a stranger in this city. I'm aware of your firm decision regarding her older sister. I only ask that when you know who my parents are, I may be made as welcome as her other suitors and given the same freedom and favor. My contribution toward the education of your daughters is a lute and this small package of Greek and Latin books. (BIONDELLO brings the gifts forward) You would add to their value by accepting them.
(as
)
(
brings the gifts forward)

paragraphs.original: Lucentio is your name. Of whence, I pray?
paragraphs.translated: Your name is Lucentio, you say. Of what city, may I ask?

paragraphs.original:
A mighty man of Pisa. By report
I know him well. You are very welcome, sir.
(to HORTENSIO as LITIO) Take you the lute,
(to
as
)
(to LUCENTIO as CAMBIO) and you the set of books.
(to
as
)
You shall go see your pupils presently.
Holla, within!
paragraphs.translated:
A man of great influence. I know him well by reputation. You are very welcome here, sir. (to HORTENSIO as LITIO) You take the lute (to LUCENTIO as CAMBIO), and you, the set of books. I'll send you to your pupils right away. You there in the house!
(to
as
)
(to
as
)

paragraphs.original: Enter a Servant
paragraphs.translated: A servant enters.

paragraphs.original:
Sirrah, lead these gentlemen
To my daughters, and tell them both
These are their tutors. Bid them use them well.
paragraphs.translated: Boy, take these gentlemen to my daughters, and tell them both they are to be their teachers and to be courteous to them.

paragraphs.original: Exit Servant with LUCENTIO and HORTENSIO, BIONDELLO following
paragraphs.translated: The servant exits with LUCENTIO and HORTENSIO, followed by BIONDELLO.

paragraphs.original:
We will go walk a little in the orchard,
And then to dinner. You are passing welcome,
And so I pray you all to think yourselves.
paragraphs.translated: Let's take a little walk in the orchard before dinner. You are all most welcome here; please make yourselves at home.

paragraphs.original:
Signior Baptista, my business asketh haste,
And every day I cannot come to woo.
You knew my father well, and in him me,
Left solely heir to all his lands and goods,
Which I have bettered rather than decreased.
Then tell me, if I get your daughter's love,
What dowry shall I have with her to wife?
paragraphs.translated: Signior Baptista, I'm actually in a bit of a hurry. I can't make this wooing into a daily thing. You knew my father well; therefore, you know me, the sole heir to all his property and possessions, which I have added to rather than depleted. So, tell me, assuming I win your daughter's love, what dowry would she bring to the marriage?

paragraphs.original:
After my death, the one half of my lands,
And, in possession, twenty thousand crowns.
paragraphs.translated: Twenty thousand crowns now, and half my lands after my death.

paragraphs.original:
And, for that dowry, I'll assure her of
Her widowhood, be it that she survive me,
In all my lands and leases whatsoever.
Let specialties be therefore drawn between us,
That covenants may be kept on either hand.
paragraphs.translated: Fair enough. And on my side, I'll guarantee that if I die before she does, she shall inherit all my land and the rent from any property I own. Let's have explicit contracts drawn up to ensure that both sides keep their promises.

paragraphs.original:
Ay, when the special thing is well obtained,
That is, her love, for that is all in all.
paragraphs.translated: Certainly, as soon as you've gotten the most important thing - her love. That counts for everything.

paragraphs.original:
Why, that is nothing. For I tell you, father,
I am as peremptory as she proud-minded;
And where two raging fires meet together,
They do consume the thing that feeds their fury.
Though little fire grows great with little wind,
Yet extreme gusts will blow out fire and all.
So I to her and so she yields to me,
For I am rough and woo not like a babe.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, that's nothing, believe me, sir. I'm as commanding as she is proud, and when two raging fires meet, they end up consuming the very thing that kindled them. Blow on a fire and all you do is fan the flames. But a great gust of wind will blow the fire out completely. I'm that great gust to her fire. I'm rough, and I don't woo like a little boy.

paragraphs.original:
Well mayst thou woo, and happy be thy speed.
But be thou armed for some unhappy words.
paragraphs.translated: Well, good luck! I hope you're successful. But prepare yourself for some unpleasantness.

paragraphs.original:
Ay, to the proof, as mountains are for winds,
That shakes not, though they blow perpetually.
paragraphs.translated: I'll be completely prepared. Mountains don't tremble, however much the wind may blow!

paragraphs.original: Enter HORTENSIO as LITIO, with his head broke
paragraphs.translated: Enter HORTENSIO as LITIO, with his head cut and bleeding

paragraphs.original: How now, my friend, why dost thou look so pale?
paragraphs.translated: Gracious! Why so pale, my friend?

paragraphs.original: What, will my daughter prove a good musician?
paragraphs.translated: Will my daughter be a good musician, do you think?

paragraphs.original:
I think she'll sooner prove a soldier.
Iron may hold with her, but never lutes.
paragraphs.translated: I think she'll be a better soldier. She may be good with firearms. Never lutes.

paragraphs.original: Why, then thou canst not break her to the lute?
paragraphs.translated: You don't think you can teach her?

paragraphs.original:
Why, no, for she hath broke the lute to me.
I did but tell her she mistook her frets,
And bowed her hand to teach her fingering,
When, with a most impatient devilish spirit,
"'Frets' call you these?" quoth she. "I'll fume with them!"
And with that word she struck me on the head,
And through the instrument my pate made way,
paragraphs.translated: No, but she's taught me a thing or two! All I said was that she was using the wrong frets and tried to adjust her fingering. And she jumps up and says, "Frets? I'll give you frets!" With that, she clobbers me with the lute so that my head goes right through,

paragraphs.original:
And there I stood amazèd for a while
As on a pillory, looking through the lute,
While she did call me "rascal fiddler"
And "twangling Jack"; with twenty such vile terms,
As had she studied to misuse me so.
paragraphs.translated: and there I am, dazed, strings around my neck, looking through the sound hole like I was in the stocks, while she calls me "worthless fiddler," "twanging twerp," and twenty more hateful names, as though she'd prepared for me by composing a long list of insults to use on my behalf.

paragraphs.original:
Now, by the world, it is a lusty wench.
I love her ten times more than e'er I did.
Oh, how I long to have some chat with her!
paragraphs.translated: I like this girl! She has real character! Now I want her more than ever. I can't wait to meet her!

paragraphs.original:
(to HORTENSIO as LITIO)
Well, go with me and be not so discomfited.
Proceed in practice with my younger daughter.
She's apt to learn and thankful for good turns.
Signior Petruchio, will you go with us,
Or shall I send my daughter Kate to you?
paragraphs.translated:
(to HORTENSIO, disguised as LITIO) All right, come with me. Don't be discouraged. Continue your lessons with my younger daughter. She's quick to learn and responsive. Signior Petruchio, will you come with us, or shall I send my daughter Kate to you?
(to
, disguised as
)

paragraphs.original: I pray you do.
paragraphs.translated: Please do.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but PETRUCHIO
paragraphs.translated: Everyone but PETRUCHIO exits.

paragraphs.original:
I'll attend her here
And woo her with some spirit when she comes.
Say that she rail; why then I'll tell her plain
She sings as sweetly as a nightingale.
Say that she frown; I'll say she looks as clear
As morning roses newly washed with dew.
Say she be mute and will not speak a word;
Then I'll commend her volubility,
And say she uttereth piercing eloquence.
If she do bid me pack, I'll give her thanks,
As though she bid me stay by her a week.
If she deny to wed, I'll crave the day
When I shall ask the banns and when be marrièd.
But here she comes - and now, Petruchio, speak.
paragraphs.translated: I'll wait for her here and when she comes I'll take a novel approach with her. If she rants, I'll tell her that she sings as sweetly as a nightingale. If she glares, I'll say her brow is as clear as roses newly washed with morning dew. If she is silent and won't speak at all, I'll praise her chattiness and say she speaks with piercing eloquence. If she orders me to go, I'll thank her warmly as if she'd just offered to put me up for a week. If she refuses my proposal, I'll tell her how much I'm looking forward to the announcement and the wedding. But here she comes. Here goes!

paragraphs.original: Enter KATHERINE
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE enters.

paragraphs.original: Good morrow, Kate - for that's your name, I hear.
paragraphs.translated: Good morning, Kate, for I hear that's what you're called.

paragraphs.original:
Well have you heard, but something hard of hearing.
They call me Katherine that do talk of me.
paragraphs.translated: Is that what you've heard? Then you'd better get your ears checked. I am called Katherine by those who have any business using my name.

paragraphs.original:
You lie, in faith, for you are called plain Kate,
And bonny Kate, and sometimes Kate the curst,
But Kate, the prettiest Kate in Christendom,
Kate of Kate Hall, my super-dainty Kate - 
For dainties are all Kates - and therefore, Kate,
Take this of me, Kate of my consolation:
Hearing thy mildness praised in every town,
Thy virtues spoke of, and thy beauty sounded - 
Yet not so deeply as to thee belongs - 
Myself am moved to woo thee for my wife.
paragraphs.translated: Liar. In fact, you're called Kate, plain Kate - and pretty Kate, and sometimes Kate the shrew. But it's definitely Kate - the prettiest Kate in the world, Katie, Kitty, Kat-woman, the Kate-ster - and so, Kate, here's my pitch: that having heard your charming disposition praised - not to mention your beauty and your virtues, though none of them as richly as you deserve - I find myself driven to propose. I want you for my wife.

paragraphs.original:
"Moved," in good time. Let him that moved you hither
Remove you hence. I knew you at the first
You were a moveable.
paragraphs.translated: "Driven?" Really? Well, let whoever drove you here drive you back again. I had you figured for a piece of furniture.

paragraphs.original: Why, what's a moveable?
paragraphs.translated: What do you mean by "furniture"?

paragraphs.original: A joint stool.
paragraphs.translated: A nice stool.

paragraphs.original: Thou hast hit it. Come, sit on me.
paragraphs.translated: You're right, actually. Come sit on me.

paragraphs.original: Asses are made to bear, and so are you.
paragraphs.translated: Asses are made for bearing, and so are you.

paragraphs.original: Women are made to bear, and so are you.
paragraphs.translated:
Women are made for
bearing, and so are you.
bearing

paragraphs.original: No such jade as you, if me you mean.
paragraphs.translated: Not by the likes of you!

paragraphs.original:
Alas, good Kate, I will not burden thee,
For knowing thee to be but young and light -
paragraphs.translated:
Oh heavens, Kate, I wouldn't think of burdening you. I know how
light and carefree you are.
light

paragraphs.original:
Too light for such a swain as you to catch,
And yet as heavy as my weight should be.
paragraphs.translated: Too light for a lout like you to catch - though no lighter than I should be.

paragraphs.original: "Should be" - should buzz!
paragraphs.translated:
Should be? Maybe you should be the subject of some buzz!
should be

paragraphs.original: Well ta'en, and like a buzzard.
paragraphs.translated:
Buzz off,
buzzard.
buzzard

paragraphs.original: O slow-winged turtle, shall a buzzard take thee?
paragraphs.translated:
If I'm a buzzard, you're a
turtledove.
turtledove

paragraphs.original: Ay, for a turtle, as he takes a buzzard.
paragraphs.translated: Only a buzzard would think so.

paragraphs.original: Come, come, you wasp. I' faith, you are too angry.
paragraphs.translated: Come, my little wasp - you're too angry.

paragraphs.original: If I be waspish, best beware my sting.
paragraphs.translated: If I'm a wasp, look out for my stinger.

paragraphs.original: My remedy is then to pluck it out.
paragraphs.translated: All I have to do is remove it.

paragraphs.original: Ay, if the fool could find it where it lies.
paragraphs.translated: True, if a fool such as yourself could find it.

paragraphs.original:
Who knows not where a wasp does wear his sting?
In his tail.
paragraphs.translated: Everyone knows where a wasp wears its stinger. In its tail.

paragraphs.original: In his tongue.
paragraphs.translated: No, in its tongue.

paragraphs.original: Whose tongue?
paragraphs.translated: Whose tongue?

paragraphs.original: Yours, if you talk of tales. And so farewell.
paragraphs.translated:
Yours, if we're talking about
tales.
tales



I'm leaving.

paragraphs.original:
What, with my tongue in your tail? Nay, come again,
Good Kate. I am a gentleman.
paragraphs.translated: You're leaving with my tongue in your tail? No, come back, Kate. I'm too much of a gentleman.

paragraphs.original: That I'll try.
paragraphs.translated: A gentleman? We'll see about that!

paragraphs.original: She strikes him
paragraphs.translated: She strikes him.

paragraphs.original: I swear I'll cuff you if you strike again.
paragraphs.translated: I swear I'll smack you if you hit me again.

Not if you want to keep your arms! If you hit me, that proves you're not a
gentleman. And if you're not a gentleman, you don't have any arms.
gentleman

paragraphs.original: A herald, Kate? Oh, put me in thy books!
paragraphs.translated:
Are you a
herald, Kate? Put me in your books!
herald

paragraphs.original: What is your crest? A coxcomb?
paragraphs.translated:
What is your
crest? A
coxcomb?
crest



coxcomb

paragraphs.original: A combless cock, so Kate will be my hen.
paragraphs.translated:
I'll give up my
comb, if you'll be my hen.
comb

paragraphs.original: No cock of mine. You crow too like a craven.
paragraphs.translated: Your cock is not for me. It has no fighting spirit.

paragraphs.original: Nay, come, Kate, come. You must not look so sour.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, come on now, Kate. Don't look so sour.

paragraphs.original: It is my fashion, when I see a crab.
paragraphs.translated: That's my way, when I see a crab-apple.

paragraphs.original: Why, here's no crab, and therefore look not sour.
paragraphs.translated: There's no crab-apple here, so don't look sour.

paragraphs.original: There is, there is.
paragraphs.translated: There is a crab-apple here.

paragraphs.original: Then show it me.
paragraphs.translated: Show me.

paragraphs.original: Had I a glass, I would.
paragraphs.translated: I would, if I had a mirror.

paragraphs.original: What, you mean my face?
paragraphs.translated: What, you mean my face looks like a crab-apple?

paragraphs.original: Well aimed of such a young one.
paragraphs.translated: What a clever child he is!

paragraphs.original: Now, by Saint George, I am too young for you.
paragraphs.translated: You know, you're right. I probably am too young for you.

paragraphs.original: Yet you are withered.
paragraphs.translated: Maybe, but you're wrinkled all the same.

paragraphs.original: 'Tis with cares.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, that's with worry.

paragraphs.original: I care not.
paragraphs.translated: Well, that doesn't worry me.

paragraphs.original: Nay, hear you, Kate: in sooth you 'scape not so.
paragraphs.translated: Listen, Kate! You won't get away like that.

paragraphs.original: I chafe you, if I tarry. Let me go.
paragraphs.translated: Let me go. I'll make you angry if I stay.

paragraphs.original:
No, not a whit. I find you passing gentle.
'Twas told me you were rough and coy and sullen,
And now I find report a very liar.
For thou are pleasant, gamesome, passing courteous,
But slow in speech, yet sweet as springtime flowers.
Thou canst not frown, thou canst not look askance,
Nor bite the lip as angry wenches will,
Nor hast thou pleasure to be cross in talk.
But thou with mildness entertain'st thy wooers,
With gentle conference, soft and affable.
Why does the world report that Kate doth limp?
paragraphs.translated: No, not a bit. I find you quite gentle. I was told that you were violent, proud, and sullen. But now I see that people have been lying about you, for you are funny, playful, and beautifully behaved, not sharp-tongued, but as sweet as flowers in springtime. You haven't got it in you to frown or look displeased or bite your lip as angry women do. You don't take pleasure in bitter conversation. No, you entertain your suitors with mild and gentle conversation, quiet and pleasant. Why does the world report that Kate is lame?

paragraphs.original:
O slanderous world! Kate like the hazel-twig
Is straight and slender and as brown in hue
As hazel nuts, and sweeter than the kernels.
Oh, let me see thee walk! Thou dost not halt.
paragraphs.translated: The world's a liar. Kate is as straight and slender as a hazel-twig, her hair as brown as hazelnut shells, and she herself sweeter than the kernels. Take a few steps - I want to see you walk. You don't limp at all!

paragraphs.original: Go, fool, and whom thou keep'st command.
paragraphs.translated: Get out of here, fool, and give orders to your servants, not me.

paragraphs.original:
Did ever Dian so become a grove
As Kate this chamber with her princely gait?
Oh, be thou Dian, and let her be Kate,
And then let Kate be chaste and Dian sportful.
paragraphs.translated: Did Diana ever beautify a grove as much as Kate beautifies this room with her queenly movements? You be Diana, and let Diana be Kate. Then let Kate be the chaste one, while Diana plays with me.

paragraphs.original: Where did you study all this goodly speech?
paragraphs.translated: Where do you memorize all this smart talk?

paragraphs.original: It is extempore, from my mother wit.
paragraphs.translated:
I make it up as I go. It's born of my
mother wit.
mother wit

paragraphs.original: A witty mother! Witless else her son.
paragraphs.translated: A witty mother! Too bad about the son!

paragraphs.original: Am I not wise?
paragraphs.translated: Am I not wise?

paragraphs.original: Yes, keep you warm.
paragraphs.translated:
Enough to keep yourself warm.
Enough to keep yourself warm.

paragraphs.original:
Marry, so I mean, sweet Katherine, in thy bed.
And therefore, setting all this chat aside,
Thus in plain terms: your father hath consented
That you shall be my wife, your dowry 'greed on,
And, will you, nill you, I will marry you.
Now, Kate, I am a husband for your turn,
For, by this light, whereby I see thy beauty,
Thy beauty that doth make me like thee well,
Thou must be married to no man but me.
For I am he am born to tame you, Kate,
And bring you from a wild Kate to a Kate
Conformable as other household Kates.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, I intend to keep myself warm, sweet Katherine - in your bed. So let's cut to the chase: your father has consented for you to become my wife. Your dowry is agreed upon, and whether you like it or not, I will marry you. I tell you, I'm the man for you, Kate. I swear by this light, which shows me your beauty - the beauty that makes me love you - that you must be married to no man but me. I'm the man who was born to tame you and change you from a wildcat Kate into a Kate as gentle and domestic as other household Kates.

paragraphs.original: Enter BAPTISTA, GREMIO, and TRANIO
paragraphs.translated: BAPTISTA, GREMIO, and TRANIO enter.

paragraphs.original:
Here comes your father. Never make denial.
I must and will have Katherine to my wife.
paragraphs.translated: Here comes your father. Don't even think about refusing. I must and will have Katherine for my wife.

paragraphs.original: Now, Signior Petruchio, how speed you with my daughter?
paragraphs.translated: Now, Signior Petruchio, how are you getting on with my daughter?

paragraphs.original:
How but well, sir? How but well?
It were impossible I should speed amiss.
paragraphs.translated: Beautifully, sir, beautifully! It couldn't go any other way.

paragraphs.original: Why, how now, daughter Katherine? In your dumps?
paragraphs.translated: Now, daughter Katherine? Are you down in the dumps?

paragraphs.original:
Call you me daughter? Now, I promise you
You have showed a tender fatherly regard
To wish me wed to one half lunatic,
A mad-cup ruffian and a swearing Jack,
That thinks with oaths to face the matter out.
paragraphs.translated: You have the nerve to call me daughter? Is this a father's loving care - wanting to marry me off to a total madman, a worthless, irresponsible louse who thinks if he swears enough, he'll get his way?

paragraphs.original:
Father, 'tis thus: yourself and all the world
That talked of her have talked amiss of her.
If she be curst, it is for policy,
For she's not froward, but modest as the dove.
She is not hot, but temperate as the morn.
For patience she will prove a second Grissel,
And Roman Lucrece for her chastity.
And to conclude, we have 'greed so well together,
That upon Sunday is the wedding day.
paragraphs.translated:
Sir, this is the truth: you and the rest - all the people who have ever talked about her - have all been wrong. If she seems fierce, it's for a reason. She's not obstinate but gentle as the dove, not high-strung but peaceful as the morning. She has the patience of a
Griselda and the modesty of Rome's Lucrece. In short, we've gotten along so well that Sunday is our wedding day.
Griselda

paragraphs.original: I'll see thee hanged on Sunday first.
paragraphs.translated: I'll see you hanged on Sunday first!

paragraphs.original: Hark, Petruchio: she says she'll see thee hanged first.
paragraphs.translated: Listen to that Petruchio: she says she'll see you hanged first.

paragraphs.original: Is this your speeding? Nay, then, good night our part.
paragraphs.translated: Is this your idea of success? So much for our plan.

paragraphs.original:
Be patient, gentlemen. I choose her for myself.
If she and I be pleased, what's that to you?
'Tis bargained 'twixt us twain, being alone,
That she shall still be curst in company.
I tell you, 'tis incredible to believe
How much she loves me. O, the kindest Kate!
She hung about my neck, and kiss on kiss
She vied so fast, protesting oath on oath,
That in a twink she won me to her love.
O, you are novices! 'Tis a world to see,
How tame, when men and women are alone,
A meacock wretch can make the curstest shrew. - 
Give me thy hand, Kate. I will unto Venice
To buy apparel 'gainst the wedding day.
Provide the feast, father, and bid the guests.
I will be sure my Katherine shall be fine.
paragraphs.translated: Relax, gentlemen. I've made my choice. If she and I are happy, what's it to you? When we were alone, we agreed that in public she would go on being unpleasant. I tell you, though, it's incredible how much she loves me. Darling Kate! She hung about my neck, smothering me with kisses, making vow after vow. In this way, she won my heart lickety-split! You men are rank beginners! It's amazing how even a timid wretch can tame the most dreadful shrew, if the two are left alone together. Give me your hand, Kate. I'm off to Venice to buy outfits for the wedding. Plan the feast, sir, and invite the guests. I want my Katherine decked out in the finest clothes.

paragraphs.original:
I know not what to say, but give me your hands.
God send you joy, Petruchio. 'Tis a match.
paragraphs.translated:
I don't know what to say. Well, give me your hands.
God give you joy, Petruchio. Call it a match!

paragraphs.original: Amen, say we. We will be witnesses.
paragraphs.translated: Amen to that! We'll be your witnesses.

paragraphs.original:
Father, and wife, and gentlemen, adieu.
I will to Venice. Sunday comes apace.
We will have rings, and things, and fine array,
And kiss me, Kate. We will be married o' Sunday.
paragraphs.translated: Father, wife, friends - farewell! I'm off to Venice. Sunday is just around the corner. We will have rings and things and fancy dress! So kiss me, Kate. We're to be married on Sunday.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt PETRUCHIO and KATHERINE severally
paragraphs.translated: PETRUCHIO and KATHERINE exit in different directions.

paragraphs.original: Was ever match clapped up so suddenly?
paragraphs.translated: Was there ever a match put together so quickly?

paragraphs.original:
Faith, gentlemen, now I play a merchant's part,
And venture madly on a desperate mart.
paragraphs.translated: Truly, gentlemen, this is a chancy piece of business. I've made a risky investment.

paragraphs.original:
(as LUCENTIO) 'Twas a commodity lay fretting by you.
(as
)
'Twill bring you gain or perish on the seas.
The gain I seek is quiet in the match.
paragraphs.translated: The only profit I seek is a peaceful match.

paragraphs.original:
No doubt but he hath got a quiet catch.
But now, Baptista, to your younger daughter.
Now is the day we long have lookèd for.
I am your neighbor, and was suitor first.
paragraphs.translated: There's no doubt that Petruchio's got quite a catch. Now, Baptista, let's turn to your younger daughter. We've been waiting a long time for this day. I'm your neighbor and came courting first.

paragraphs.original:
(as LUCENTIO) And I am one that love Bianca more
(as
)
Than words can witness or your thoughts can guess.
Youngling, thou canst not love so dear as I.
paragraphs.translated: Callow youth, you don't yet know how to love!

paragraphs.original:
(as LUCENTIO)
(as
)
Graybeard, thy love doth freeze.

But thine doth fry.
Skipper, stand back. 'Tis age that nourisheth.
paragraphs.translated: And you're all sizzle. Stand back, boy. Age is the thing that nourishes.

paragraphs.original:
Content you, gentlemen. I will compound this strife.
'Tis deeds must win the prize, and he of both
That can assure my daughter greatest dower
Shall have my Bianca's love.
Say, Signior Gremio, what can you assure her?
paragraphs.translated:
Enough, gentlemen. I will settle this matter.
Deeds will determine the winner here. Whichever of you can promise Bianca the greatest dower shall have my daughter's love. Tell me, Signior Gremio, what can you offer her?
Deeds

paragraphs.original:
First, as you know, my house within the city
Is richly furnishèd with plate and gold,
Basins and ewers to lave her dainty hands;
My hangings all of Tyrian tapestry,
In ivory coffers I have stuffed my crowns,
In cypress chests my arras counterpoints,
Costly apparel, tents, and canopies,
Fine linen, Turkey cushions bossed with pearl,
Valance of Venice gold in needlework,
Pewter and brass, and all things that belong
To house or housekeeping. Then, at my farm
I have a hundred milch-kine to the pail,
Six score fat oxen standing in my stalls,
And all things answerable to this portion.
Myself am struck in years, I must confess,
And if I die tomorrow this is hers,
If whilst I live she will be only mine.
paragraphs.translated: First of all, my house in the city, as you know, is filled with expensive furniture and household articles, china and gold, basins and pitchers for her to wash her dainty hands in. All my wall hangings are tapestries from Tyre. My ivory strongboxes are stuffed with gold, my wooden trunks filled with elegant rugs, expensive clothing, hangings and bed curtains, fine linens, Turkish cushions trimmed with pearls, Venetian draperies, pewter and brass, and everything else a household could possibly want. Then, at my farm I have a hundred milk cows, a hundred and twenty fat oxen in my stables, and all the equipment necessary to maintain them. I'm getting on in years, and if I died tomorrow, all this will belong to Bianca - if only while I live she'll belong solely to me.

paragraphs.original:
(as LUCENTIO)
(as
)
That "only" came well in. (to BAPTISTA) Sir, list to me:
(to
)
I am my father's heir and only son.
If I may have your daughter to my wife,
I'll leave her houses three or four as good,
Within rich Pisa walls, as any one
Old Signior Gremio has in Padua,
Besides two thousand ducats by the year
Of fruitful land, all which shall be her jointure. - 
What, have I pinched you, Signior Gremio?

Two thousand ducats by the year of land!
(aside) My land amounts not to so much in all. - 
(aside)
That she shall have, besides an argosy
That now is lying in Marcellus' road.
(to TRANIO) What, have I choked you with an argosy?
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
Two thousand ducats a year from his land! (to himself) All my land together isn't worth that much! - Aha! I forgot to mention the merchant ship that lies in Marseilles harbor. (to TRANIO) Sorry - have I caught you choking on a merchant ship?
(to himself)
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
(as LUCENTIO) Gremio, 'tis known my father hath no less
(as
)
Than three great argosies, besides two galliasses,
And twelve tight galleys. These I will assure her,
And twice as much whate'er thou offer'st next.

Nay, I have offered all, I have no more,
And she can have no more than all I have.
(to BAPTISTA) If you like me, she shall have me and mine.
(to
)

(as LUCENTIO)
(as
)
Why, then the maid is mine from all the world,
By your firm promise. Gremio is outvied.

I must confess your offer is the best,
And, let your father make her the assurance,
She is your own; else, you must pardon me.
If you should die before him, where's her dower?
paragraphs.translated: I must admit your offer is the best. And provided that your father will be your guarantor, she shall be yours. Otherwise - forgive me, but if you should die before him, what becomes of her dowry?

paragraphs.original: And may not young men die as well as old?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, and young men never die?

paragraphs.original:
Well, gentlemen, I am thus resolved:
On Sunday next, you know
My daughter Katherina is to be married.
(to TRANIO as LUCENTIO)
(to
as
)
Now, on the Sunday following, shall Bianca
Be bride to you, if you make this assurance.
If not, to Signior Gremio.
And so I take my leave, and thank you both.
paragraphs.translated:
Well, gentlemen, that's my decision. As you know, next Sunday my daughter Katherina is to be married. (to TRANIO as LUCENTIO) Therefore, the Sunday after, Bianca shall be married to you - if you obtain that guarantee. If not, she'll be married to Signior Gremio. And so I thank you both and bid you goodbye.
(to
as
)

paragraphs.original: Adieu, good neighbor.
paragraphs.translated: Farewell, good neighbor.

paragraphs.original: Exit BAPTISTA
paragraphs.translated: BAPTISTA exits.

paragraphs.original:
Now I fear thee not.
Sirrah young gamester, your father were a fool
To give thee all and in his waning age
Set foot under thy table. Tut, a toy!
An old Italian fox is not so kind, my boy.
paragraphs.translated: Now I'm not worried. You there, young sport! Your father would be a fool to give you all his wealth and spend his declining years as a guest in your house. It's absurd. An old Italian fox is never that generous, my boy.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original:
A vengeance on your crafty withered hide!
Yet I have faced it with a card of ten.
'Tis in my head to do my master good.
I see no reason but supposed Lucentio
Must get a father, called "supposed Vincentio" - 
And that's a wonder. Fathers commonly
Do get their children. But in this case of wooing,
A child shall get a sire, if I fail not of my cunning.
paragraphs.translated: Sneaky, dried-up old coot! We'll see who gets the upper hand! I've already bluffed pretty well - and without even a face card. I have a mind to help my master. Clearly, the fake Lucentio will have to produce a father - call him "fake Vincentio" - and it will be a miracle. Usually fathers produce children, not the other way around. But in this case of wooing, a child shall father his own father - if my wits don't fail me.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter LUCENTIO disguised as CAMBIO, HORTENSIO disguised as LITIO, and BIANCA
paragraphs.translated: BIANCA enters with LUCENTIO disguised as CAMBIO, and HORTENSIO disguised as LITIO

paragraphs.original:
(as CAMBIO) Fiddler, forbear. You grow too forward, sir.
(as
)
Have you so soon forgot the entertainment
Her sister Katherina welcomed you withal?

(as LITIO) But, wrangling pedant, this is
(as
)
The patroness of heavenly harmony.
Then give me leave to have prerogative,
And when in music we have spent an hour,
Your lecture shall have leisure for as much.

(as CAMBIO) Preposterous ass, that never read so far
(as
)
To know the cause why music was ordained.
Was it not to refresh the mind of man
After his studies or his usual pain?
Then give me leave to read philosophy
And, while I pause, serve in your harmony.
paragraphs.translated:
(as CAMBIO) Ridiculous ass! You're not even educated enough to know why music was created. Wasn't it to refresh the mind of man after his studies and daily toil? Therefore allow me to read philosophy with her, and then, when I am finished, indulge in your harmony.
(as
)
after

paragraphs.original:
Why, gentlemen, you do me double wrong
To strive for that which resteth in my choice.
I am no breeching scholar in the schools.
I'll not be tied to hours nor 'pointed times
But learn my lessons as I please myself.
And, to cut off all strife, here sit we down.
paragraphs.translated: Gentlemen, it seems to me you're both out of line to be laying down the law about things that are really up to me. I am no schoolboy, and I won't be dictated to with hours and schedules. I'll have my lessons in the order and manner I prefer. So to cut short this argument, let's figure this out.

paragraphs.original:
(to HORTENSIO)
(to
)
Take you your instrument, play you the whiles.
His lecture will be done ere you have tuned.

(aside) That will be never. (to HORTENSIO) Tune your instrument.
(aside)
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) That will be never. (to HORTENSIO) Tune your instrument.
(to himself)
(to
)

paragraphs.original: Where left we last?
paragraphs.translated: Where did we leave off?

paragraphs.original:
Here, madam:
Hic ibat Simois, hic est Sigeia tellus,
Hic ibat Simois, hic est Sigeia tellus,
Hic steterat Priami regia celsa senis.
Hic steterat Priami regia celsa senis.
paragraphs.translated:
Here, madam:
Hic ibat Simois, hic est Sigeia tellus,
Hic ibat Simois, hic est Sigeia tellus,
Hic ibat Simois, hic est Sigeia tellus



Hic steterat Priami regia celsa senis.
Hic steterat Priami regia celsa senis.

paragraphs.original: Conster them.
paragraphs.translated: Translate.

paragraphs.original:
Hic ibat, as I told you before, Simois, I am Lucentio, hic est, son unto Vincentio of Pisa, Sigeia tellus, disguised thus to get your love, Hic steterat, and that "Lucentio" that comes a-wooing, Priami is my man Tranio, regia, bearing my port, celsa senis, that we might beguile the old pantaloon.
celsa senis,
paragraphs.translated:
Hic ibat, as I told you before,
Simois, I am Lucentio, hic est, son of Vincentio of Pisa, Sigeia tellus, disguised as a teacher so as to win your love, Hic steterat, and the fellow who comes to court you calling himself "Lucentio," Priami, is my servant Tranio, regia, pretending to be me, celsa senis, so we can get the better of the foolish old man.
Hic ibat,
Simois



hic est,
Sigeia tellus,
Hic steterat,
Priami,
regia,
celsa senis,

paragraphs.original:
Let's hear. (he plays) O fie! The treble jars.
(he plays)
paragraphs.translated:
Let's hear. (he plays) Oooh, no! The high note's off.
(he plays)

paragraphs.original:
Now let me see if I can conster it. Hic ibat Simois, I know you not, hic est Sigeia tellus, I trust you not, Hic steterat Priami, take heed he hear us not, regia, presume not, celsa senis, despair not.
senis,
paragraphs.translated:
Now let me see if I can translate it. Hic ibat Simois, I don't know you, hic est Sigeia tellus, I don't trust you, Hic steterat Priami, don't let him hear you, regia, don't take anything for granted, celsa senis, don't give up.
Hic ibat Simois,
hic est Sigeia tellus,
Hic steterat Priami,
regia,
celsa senis,

paragraphs.original:
(as LITIO) The base is right; 'tis the base knave that jars.
(as
)
(aside) How fiery and forward our pedant is!
(aside)
Now, for my life, the knave doth court my love.
Pedascule, I'll watch you better yet.
Pedascule
paragraphs.translated:
(as LITIO) The low note's fine; it's this low-minded dog that's out of tune! (to himself) How touchy and insistent this fellow is! I'm beginning to think he's wooing my darling. Little professor! I'll have to keep an eye on you.
(as
)
(to himself)

paragraphs.original:
Mistrust it not, for sure Aeacides
Was Ajax, called so from his grandfather.
paragraphs.translated:
There's no need to be, really, for -  (he breaks off, seeing that HORTENSIO is listening, and pretends to go back to the Latin lesson) - "Aeacides" is just another name for Ajax. He gets it from his grandfather.
(he breaks off, seeing that
is listening, and pretends to go back to the Latin lesson)

paragraphs.original:
I must believe my master; else, I promise you,
I should be arguing still upon that doubt.
But let it rest. - Now, Litio, to you.
Good master, take it not unkindly, pray,
That I have been thus pleasant with you both.
paragraphs.translated: You're my teacher, so I must believe you. Otherwise, I would have to argue the point with you. But let it go. - Now, Litio, it's your turn. I hope, sir, that you're not angry that I've been equally attentive to you both!

paragraphs.original:
(as LITIO, to LUCENTIO)
(as
, to
)
You may go walk, and give me leave awhile.
My lessons make no music in three parts.
paragraphs.translated:
(as LITIO, to LUCENTIO) You can take a break. Leave us alone, why don't you? I don't teach music for a threesome.
(as
, to
)

paragraphs.original:
(as CAMBIO) Are you so formal, sir? Well, I must wait.
(as
)
(aside) And watch withal, for, but I be deceived,
(aside)
Our fine musician groweth amorous.
paragraphs.translated:
(as CAMBIO) Well, aren't we strict! Okay, I guess I'll have to wait. (to himself) And watch, too. For unless I'm very much mistaken, our fancy musician is turning romantic!
(as
)
(to himself)

paragraphs.original:
(as LITIO) Madam, before you touch the instrument,
(as
)
To learn the order of my fingering
I must begin with rudiments of art,
To teach you gamut in a briefer sort,
More pleasant, pithy, and effectual
Than hath been taught by any of my trade.
And there it is in writing, fairly drawn.
Why, I am past my gamut long ago.
paragraphs.translated: I think I know my scales by now!

paragraphs.original: Yet read the gamut of Hortensio.

(reads)
(reads)
"Gamut I am, the ground of all accord:
Gamut
A re, to plead Hortensio's passion;
A re,
B mi, Bianca, take him for thy lord,
B mi,
C fa ut, that loves with all affection;
C fa ut,
D sol re, one clef, two notes have I;
D sol re,
E la mi, show pity, or I die."
E la mi,
Call you this "gamut"? Tut, I like it not.
Old fashions please me best. I am not so nice
To change true rules for old inventions.
paragraphs.translated:
(reading) "I am the scale, the basis of all harmony.
(reading)
A re, Im here to argue for Hortensio's love;
A re,
B mi, Bianca, take him for your husband,
B mi,
C fa ut, he loves you with all affection;
C fa ut,
D sol re, I have one clef but only two notes;
D sol re,
E la mi, have pity on me, or I'll die."
E la mi,
You call this a scale? I don't like it. I don't go in for these new-fangled methods. I like doing things the old-fashioned way.

paragraphs.original: Enter a SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: A SERVANT enters.

paragraphs.original:
Mistress, your father prays you leave your books
And help to dress your sister's chamber up.
You know tomorrow is the wedding day.
paragraphs.translated: Mistress, your father requests that you leave your books and come help decorate your sister's room. You know tomorrow is her wedding day.

paragraphs.original: Farewell, sweet masters both. I must be gone.
paragraphs.translated: Farewell to both of you, dear teachers. I have to go.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt BIANCA, the SERVANT, and LUCENTIO
paragraphs.translated: BIANCA, the SERVANT, and LUCENTIO exit.

paragraphs.original:
But I have cause to pry into this pedant.
Methinks he looks as though he were in love.
Yet if thy thoughts, Bianca, be so humble
To cast thy wand'ring eyes on every stale,
Seize thee that list! If once I find thee ranging,
Hortensio will be quit with thee by changing.
paragraphs.translated: But there's reason for me to look more closely at this schoolmaster. He acts like a man in love. But if Bianca is so vulgar as to stoop for any man she sees, the hell with her. Whoever wants her can have her. The first time I catch her straying, it's over. End of story.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter BAPTISTA, GREMIO, TRANIO as LUCENTIO, KATHERINE, BIANCA, LUCENTIO, and others, attendants
paragraphs.translated: BAPTISTA and GREMIO enter, followed by TRANIO disguised as LUCENTIO, KATHERINE, BIANCA, LUCENTIO, and servants.

paragraphs.original:
(to TRANIO) Signior Lucentio, this is the 'pointed day
(to
)
That Katherine and Petruchio should be married,
And yet we hear not of our son-in-law.
What will be said? What mockery will it be,
To want the bridegroom when the priest attends
To speak the ceremonial rites of marriage?
What says Lucentio to this shame of ours?
paragraphs.translated:
(to TRANIO as LUCENTIO) Signior Lucentio, this is the day appointed for Katherine and Petruchio's wedding, but there's no sign of the groom. What will people say? To have the priest right here, ready to perform the marriage ceremony, and be missing a bridegroom! What do you think about our humiliation, Lucentio?
(to
as
)

paragraphs.original:
No shame but mine. I must, forsooth, be forced
To give my hand, opposed against my heart,
Unto a mad-brain rudesby, full of spleen,
Who wooed in haste and means to wed at leisure.
I told you, I, he was a frantic fool,
Hiding his bitter jests in blunt behavior,
And, to be noted for a merry man,
He'll woo a thousand, 'point the day of marriage,
Make friends, invite, and proclaim the banns,
Yet never means to wed where he hath wooed.
Now must the world point at poor Katherine
And say, "Lo, there is mad Petruchio's wife,
If it would please him come and marry her!"
paragraphs.translated: The humiliation is all mine. You forced me to accept this man against my will, this fancy con artist who was in such a hurry to get engaged. He has no intention of marrying me. I knew it - I told you. The whole thing was a joke. He pretends to be this simple, backward guy, but it's all a gag to amuse his witty friends. He goes around proposing to women - they set a date, he gets introduced around, they send out the invitations and make a public announcement, but he has no intention of going through with it. So now everyone will point at me and say, "Look, there goes the wife of that comedian Petruchio - if he could be bothered to marry the pathetic thing!"

paragraphs.original:
(as LUCENTIO) Patience, good Katherine, and Baptista too.
(as
)
Upon my life, Petruchio means but well,
Whatever fortune stays him from his word:
Though he be blunt, I know him passing wise;
Though he be merry, yet withal he's honest.
Would Katherine had never seen him, though!
paragraphs.translated: Maybe, but I wish I'd never laid eyes on him.

paragraphs.original: Exit weeping, followed by BIANCA and others
paragraphs.translated: She exits weeping, followed by BIANCA and others.

paragraphs.original:
Go, girl. I cannot blame thee now to weep,
For such an injury would vex a very saint,
Much more a shrew of thy impatient humor.
paragraphs.translated: Go, daughter. I cannot blame you now for weeping. An insult like this would try the patience of a saint, let alone a hot-tempered shrew like you!

paragraphs.original: Enter BIONDELLO
paragraphs.translated: BIONDELLO enters.

paragraphs.original: Master, master! News, old news, and such news as you never heard of!
paragraphs.translated: Master, master! I have news - old news such as you never heard before!

paragraphs.original: Is it new and old too? How may that be?
paragraphs.translated: You say you have news that's old? How can that be?

paragraphs.original: Why, is it not news to hear of Petruchio's coming?
paragraphs.translated: Well, is it not news that Petruchio's coming?

paragraphs.original: Is he come?
paragraphs.translated: Is he here?

paragraphs.original: Why, no, sir.
paragraphs.translated: Why, no, sir.

paragraphs.original: What then?
paragraphs.translated: What then?

paragraphs.original: He is coming.
paragraphs.translated: He is coming.

paragraphs.original: When will he be here?
paragraphs.translated: When will he be here?

paragraphs.original: When he stands where I am and sees you there.
paragraphs.translated: When he stands where I am and sees you there.

(as LUCENTIO) So what's the old news?
(as
)
old

paragraphs.original: Why, Petruchio is coming in a new hat and an old jerkin, a pair of old breeches thrice turned, a pair of boots that have been candle cases, one buckled, another laced; an old rusty sword ta'en out of the town armory, with a broken hilt and chapeless; with two broken points; his horse hipped, with an old mothy saddle and stirrups of no kindred, besides possessed with the glanders and like to mose in the chine, troubled with the lampass, infected with the fashions, full of wingdalls, sped with spavins, rayed with yellows, past cure of the fives, stark spoiled with the staggers, begnawn with the bots, swayed in the back and shoulder-shotten, near-legged before and with a half-checked bit and a headstall of sheeps leather, which, being restrained to keep him from stumbling, hath been often burst, and now repaired with knots, one girth six times pieced, and a woman's crupper of velour, which hath two letters for her name fairly set down in studs, and here and there pieced with packthread.
paragraphs.translated: Well, Petruchio is coming in a new hat and an old vest, a pair of old pants turned inside out, unmatched boots that have been used as spittoons, one buckled, the other laced; a rusty old sword from the town armory with a broken hilt and no scabbard. He's got on worn-out garters and is riding a swayback old horse with a moth-eaten saddle, stirrups from two different sets, a bad hip, swollen glands, lockjaw, leg ulcers, bedsores, arthritis, jaundice, a hernia, hives, worms, cancer, a mossy overbite, and post-nasal drip. He's knock-kneed too. His bit's lopsided and his cardboard bridle, which breaks when you pull on it, is taped in a few places. The saddle strap is made out of patchwork, and the strap that goes under his tail to keep the saddle in place is velvet, with the initials of some woman written in studs.

paragraphs.original: Who comes with him?
paragraphs.translated: Who comes with him?

paragraphs.original: O, sir, his lackey, for all the world caparisoned like the horse; with a linen stock on one leg and a kersey boot-hose on the other, gartered with a red and blue list; an old hat and the humor of forty fancies pricked in 't for a feather. A monster, a very monster in apparel, and not like a Christian footboy or a gentleman's lackey.
paragraphs.translated: Just his servant, sir - pretty much got up like the horse, with a linen stocking on one leg and a big woolen booty on the other, a pair of red and blue garters, and an old hat with something no one's ever seen before where the feather should be. He's dressed like a freak, a total freak, and not at all like a proper footman or a gentleman's valet.

paragraphs.original:
(as LUCENTIO)
(as
)
'Tis some odd humor pricks him to this fashion,
Yet oftentimes he goes but mean-appareled.
paragraphs.translated:
(as LUCENTIO) He must be in a strange mood to go in for this fashion - though from time to time he has been known to dress down.
(as
)
has

paragraphs.original: I am glad he's come, howsoe'er he comes.
paragraphs.translated: I am glad he's coming, however he's dressed.

paragraphs.original: Why, sir, he comes not.
paragraphs.translated: Why, sir, he's not coming.

paragraphs.original: Didst thou not say he comes?
paragraphs.translated: Didn't you just say he was?

paragraphs.original: Who? That Petruchio came?
paragraphs.translated: Who? Petruchio?

paragraphs.original: Ay, that Petruchio came.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, Petruchio.

paragraphs.original: No, sir, I say his horse comes, with him on his back.
paragraphs.translated: No, I said his horse is coming, with him on its back.

paragraphs.original: Why, that's all one.
paragraphs.translated: Well, that's the same thing.

paragraphs.original:
Nay, by Saint Jamy,
I hold you a penny,
A horse and a man
Is more than one
And yet not many.
paragraphs.translated:
No, by Saint Jamy,
I'll bet you a penny!
A man and his horse
Aren't the same person - 
Not that there's much difference.

paragraphs.original: Enter PETRUCHIO and GRUMIO
paragraphs.translated: PETRUCHIO and GRUMIO enter.

paragraphs.original: Come, where be these gallants? Who's at home?
paragraphs.translated: Whoa! Where is everybody?

paragraphs.original: You are welcome, sir.
paragraphs.translated: You are welcome, sir.

paragraphs.original: And yet I come not well.
paragraphs.translated:
I don't feel well.
feel

paragraphs.original: And yet you halt not.
paragraphs.translated: I don't notice you limping.

paragraphs.original:
Were it better I should rush in thus - 
But where is Kate? Where is my love?
How does my father? Gentles, methinks you frown.
And wherefore gaze this goodly company
As if they saw some wondrous monument,
Some comet or unusual prodigy?

Why, sir, you know this is your wedding day.
First were we sad, fearing you would not come,
Now sadder that you come so unprovided.
Fie, doff this habit, shame to your estate,
An eyesore to our solemn festival.
paragraphs.translated: Why, sir, you know this is your wedding day. First we were sad because we were afraid you wouldn't come. Now we're even sadder to see that you've come so unprepared. For heaven's sake, take off that get-up. It's a disgrace to a man of your social position and an insult to this solemn ceremony.

paragraphs.original:
And tell us what occasion of import
Hath all so long detained you from your wife
And sent you hither so unlike yourself.
paragraphs.translated: And tell us what extraordinary occurrence made you so late for your wedding and drove you to present yourself in an outfit that's so - not typical of you.

paragraphs.original:
Tedious it were to tell and harsh to hear.
Sufficeth I am come to keep my word,
Though in some part enforcèd to digress,
Which, at more leisure, I will so excuse
As you shall well be satisfied withal.
But where is Kate? I stay too long from her.
The morning wears. 'Tis time we were at church.
paragraphs.translated: It's a long story - and tough to listen to. It's enough that I'm here according to my promise, though I will have to deviate from it to some extent - for reasons which, when I explain them later, you'll understand completely. But where is Kate? We're wasting time here. It's getting late and time we were in church.

paragraphs.original:
See not your bride in these unreverent robes.
Go to my chamber, put on clothes of mine.
paragraphs.translated: Don't greet your bride in these disgraceful clothes. Go to my room and put on something of mine.

paragraphs.original: Not I, believe me. Thus I'll visit her.
paragraphs.translated: Not me. I'll see her like this.

paragraphs.original: But thus, I trust, you will not marry her.
paragraphs.translated:
But surely you're not planning to marry her in what you're wearing!
marry

paragraphs.original:
Good sooth, even thus. Therefore, ha' done with words:
To me she's married, not unto my clothes.
Could I repair what she will wear in me
As I can change these poor accoutrements,
'Twere well for Kate and better for myself.
But what a fool am I to chat with you,
When I should bid good morrow to my bride
And seal the title with a lovely kiss!
paragraphs.translated: Yes, just like this. But enough talk. It's me she's marrying and not my clothes. Though I expect she'll wear me out more quickly than I'll wear out what I'm wearing - which will be good for her and even better for me! But what a fool I am to stand here chatting when I should bid good morning to my bride and seal the bargain with a loving kiss.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt PETRUCHIO and GRUMIO
paragraphs.translated: PETRUCHIO and GRUMIO exit.

paragraphs.original:
He hath some meaning in his mad attire.
We will persuade him, be it possible,
To put on better ere he go to church.
paragraphs.translated: He must be wearing this crazy outfit for some reason. I'll try to persuade him to put on something more appropriate before going to the church, if it's at all possible.

paragraphs.original: I'll after him, and see the event of this.
paragraphs.translated: I'll go too and make sure that happens.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt BAPTISTA, GREMIO, and attendants
paragraphs.translated: BAPTISTA, GREMIO, and attendants exit.

paragraphs.original:
But sir, to love concerneth us to add
Her father's liking, which to bring to pass,
As I before unparted to your worship,
I am to get a man - whate'er he be
It skills not much, we'll fit him to our turn - 
And he shall be "Vincentio of Pisa"
And make assurance here in Padua
Of greater sums than I have promisèd.
So shall you quietly enjoy your hope
And marry sweet Bianca with consent.
paragraphs.translated:
But sir, you need to get her father's consent as well as her love. And to that end, as I explained to your worship, I'm looking for a man - any man, it doesn't matter; we'll suit him to our purpose - who can pretend to be your father, Vincentio. And he'll guarantee the dowry - for even more money than I've promised on your behalf. This way, you'll get your wish and marry sweet Bianca with her father's consent and with the least possible hassle.
he'll

paragraphs.original:
Were it not that my fellow schoolmaster
Doth watch Bianca's steps so narrowly,
'Twere good, methinks, to steal our marriage,
Which, once performed, let all the world say no,
I'll keep mine own despite of all the world.
paragraphs.translated: If my fellow schoolmaster weren't keeping such a close watch on her, I'd think about eloping. Then it wouldn't matter what anyone said - I'd keep what's mine, whatever the rest of the world said.

paragraphs.original:
That by degrees we mean to look into
And watch our vantage in this business.
We'll overreach the graybeard, Gremio,
The narrow-prying father, Minola,
The quaint musician, amorous Litio,
All for my master's sake, Lucentio.
paragraphs.translated: Don't worry, I'm looking into that too. I'm on top of the situation - monitoring it very closely. We'll outwit them all - that old geezer, Gremio; the suspicious father, Minola; the prim musician lover, Litio - all for the sake of my master, Lucentio.

paragraphs.original: Enter GREMIO
paragraphs.translated: GREMIO enters.

paragraphs.original: Signior Gremio, came you from the church?
paragraphs.translated: Signior Gremio, are you coming from the church?

paragraphs.original: As willingly as e'er I came from school.
paragraphs.translated: As eagerly as I ever came from school.

paragraphs.original:
A bridegroom, say you? 'Tis a groom indeed,
A grumbling groom, and that the girl shall find.
paragraphs.translated: Bridegroom? This guy is more like the groom who cleans the stable - a grumbling groom at that, as the poor girl is discovering.

paragraphs.original: Why, he's a devil, a devil, a very fiend.
paragraphs.translated: No, he's a devil - a devil, I tell you! An utter fiend.

(speaking as LUCENTIO) No, she's a devil - a devil, I tell you. The devil's grandmother.
(speaking as
)
she's

paragraphs.original:
Tut, she's a lamb, a dove, a fool to him!
I'll tell you, Sir Lucentio: when the priest
Should ask if Katherine should be his wife,
"Ay, by gogs wouns!" quoth he, and swore so loud
That, all amazed, the priest let fall the book,
And as he stooped again to take it up,
The mad-brained bridegroom took him such a cuff
That down fell priest and book, and book and priest.
"Now take them up," quoth he, "if any list."
paragraphs.translated:
Why, she's a lamb, a dove, a child compared to him! Picture this: when the priest asked Katherine if she would have him, he answered, "Hell, yes!" and swore so loud that the priest drops the prayer book. Everyone froze, and as the priest stooped to pick it up again the lunatic bridegroom smacked him so hard that the priest and book went flying! Then he said, "Now pick them up - if anyone dares."
Then

paragraphs.original:
Trembled and shook, for why he stamped and swore
As if the vicar meant to cozen him.
But after many ceremonies done,
He calls for wine. "A health!" quoth he, as if
He had been aboard, carousing to his mates
After a storm; quaffed off the muscatel
And threw the sops all in the sexton's face,
Having no other reason
But that his beard grew thin and hungerly
And seemed to ask him sops as he was drinking.
This done, he took the bride about the neck
And kissed her lips with such a clamorous smack
That at the parting all the church did echo.
And I, seeing this, came thence for very shame,
And after me, I know, the rout is coming.
Such a mad marriage never was before.
paragraphs.translated: She trembled and shook because he stamped and swore and carried on as though the vicar were trying to put something over on him. Finally, the ceremony done, he called for wine. "A health!" he shouted, like some sailor aboard ship, carousing with his mates after a storm. Then he chugs the wine and throws the dregs in the sexton's face. Why? Because the fellow's beard looked thin, he said, and it seemed to be asking him for the dregs while he was drinking. Next he slung his arm around the bride's neck and kissed her with such a smack that when they parted the sound of their lips made the whole church echo. That was the limit for me. I got out of there as fast as I could. I know the rest of the crowd isn't far behind me. It's disgraceful! You never saw such a mockery of a marriage in your life!

paragraphs.original: Music
paragraphs.translated: Music plays

paragraphs.original: Hark, hark! I hear the minstrels play.
paragraphs.translated: There go the minstrels. They've started up.

paragraphs.original: Enter PETRUCHIO, KATHERINE, BIANCA, BAPTISTA, HORTENSIO, GRUMIO, and train
paragraphs.translated: PETRUCHIO and KATHERINE enter, with BIANCA, BAPTISTA, HORTENSIO, GRUMIO, and members of the wedding procession.

paragraphs.original:
Gentlemen and friends, I thank you for you
I know you think to dine with me today
And have prepared great store of wedding cheer,
But so it is, my haste doth call me hence,
And therefore here I mean to take my leave.
paragraphs.translated: Gentlemen and friends, thanks for bothering to come. I know you expected me to stay to dinner and have prepared a celebratory feast, but as it happens I'm called away. So let me say goodbye.

paragraphs.original: Is 't possible you will away tonight?
paragraphs.translated: You're not thinking of leaving tonight, surely?

paragraphs.original:
I must away today, before night come.
Make it no wonder. If you knew my business,
You would entreat me rather go than stay.
And, honest company, I thank you all,
That have beheld me give away myself
To this most patient, sweet and virtuous wife.
Dine with my father, drink a health to me,
For I must hence, and farewell to you all.
paragraphs.translated: Not tonight - today. If you knew the reason, you'd understand and would urge me to go rather than stay. Good friends, I thank you all for coming to see me wed this patient, sweet, virtuous wife. Dine with my father and drink a health to me. I have to leave. Goodbye to you all.

paragraphs.original: It may not be.
paragraphs.translated: Can't do it.

paragraphs.original: Let me entreat you.
paragraphs.translated:
As a favor to me?
me?

paragraphs.original: It cannot be.
paragraphs.translated: Nope.

paragraphs.original: Let me entreat you.
paragraphs.translated:
As a favor to me?
me?

paragraphs.original: I am content.
paragraphs.translated: I'm delighted.

paragraphs.original: Are you content to stay?
paragraphs.translated: Delighted to stay?

paragraphs.original:
I am content you shall entreat me stay,
But yet not stay, entreat me how you can.
paragraphs.translated: Delighted to hear you ask so nicely, but I won't stay in any case.

paragraphs.original: Now, if you love me, stay.
paragraphs.translated: Look, if you love me, stay.

paragraphs.original: Grumio, my horse.
paragraphs.translated: Grumio, get me my horse.

paragraphs.original: Ay, sir, they be ready. The oats have eaten the horses.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, sir, they're ready. They've eaten themselves sick.

paragraphs.original:
Nay, then,
Do what thou canst, I will not go today,
No, nor tomorrow, not till I please myself.
The door is open, sir. There lies your way.
You may be jogging whiles your boots are green.
For me, I'll not be gone till I please myself.
'Tis like you'll prove a jolly surly groom,
That take it on you at the first so roundly.
paragraphs.translated: All right, then, do what you like. I won't leave today. Not tomorrow, either. I'll leave when I'm good and ready. The door is open, sir. Feel free to use it. Go on, wear your boots out! As for me, I'll leave when I like. If you're this high-handed to start with, I can imagine how arrogant and arbitrary you'll be as a husband.

paragraphs.original: O Kate, content thee. Prithee, be not angry.
paragraphs.translated: Calm down, Kate. Please don't be angry.

paragraphs.original:
I will be angry. What hast thou to do? - 
Father, be quiet. He shall stay my leisure.
paragraphs.translated: I will be angry. What business is it of yours? - Father, be quiet. He'll stay as long as I say.

paragraphs.original: Ay, marry, sir, now it begins to work.
paragraphs.translated: Okay, now it starts!

paragraphs.original:
Gentlemen, forward to the bridal dinner.
I see a woman may be made a fool
If she had not a spirit to resist.
paragraphs.translated: Gentlemen, on to the bridal dinner. I see a woman may be made a fool of if she doesn't have nerve enough to stand up for herself.

paragraphs.original:
They shall go forward, Kate, at thy command. - 
Obey the bride, you that attend on her.
Go to the feast, revel and domineer,
Carouse full measure to her maidenhead,
Be mad and merry, or go hang yourselves.
But for my bonny Kate, she must with me.
Nay, look not big, nor stamp, nor stare, nor fret;
I will be master of what is mine own.
She is my goods, my chattels; she is my house,
My household stuff, my field, my barn,
My horse, my ox, my ass, my anything.
And here she stands, touch her whoever dare.
I'll bring mine action on the proudest he
That stops my way in Padua. - Grumio,
Draw forth thy weapon, we are beset with thieves.
Rescue thy mistress if thou be a man. - 
Fear not, sweet wench, they shall not touch thee, Kate.
I'll buckler thee against a million.
paragraphs.translated:
They shall go in to the bridal dinner, Kate - they're yours to command. Obey the bride, guests! Go to the banquet: revel, feast, and carouse! Drink yourselves silly toasting her virginity! Be wild and merry - or go to hell. But as for my bonny Kate, she must come with me. No, don't puff out your chests and stamp and stare wonderingly. I will be master of what belongs to me. She is my property, one of my possessions - just like my house and everything in it, and my field, my barn, my horse, my ox, my donkey - anything of mine you care to name. Here she is; I dare you to touch her! I'll sue anyone in Padua who tries to stand in my way, no matter how powerful he is. - Grumio, draw your sword! We are surrounded by thieves. Rescue your mistress! Prove yourself a man! Don't be afraid, sweet girl, I won't let them touch you. I'll protect you, Kate, against a million of them.
shall

paragraphs.original: Exeunt PETRUCHIO, KATHERINE, and GRUMIO
paragraphs.translated: PETRUCHIO, KATHERINE, and GRUMIO exit.

paragraphs.original: Nay, let them go, a couple of quiet ones.
paragraphs.translated: No, let them go. They're certainly a peaceful couple!

paragraphs.original: Went they not quickly, I should die with laughing.
paragraphs.translated: If they hadn't left soon, I would have died laughing.

paragraphs.original: That, being mad herself, she's madly mated.
paragraphs.translated: That since she's mad herself, she's married a madman.

paragraphs.original: I warrant him, Petruchio is Kated.
paragraphs.translated: I guarantee you, Petruchio's going to suffer from his Kate.

paragraphs.original:
Neighbors and friends, though bride and bridegroom wants
For to supply the places at the table,
You know there wants no junkets at the feast.
paragraphs.translated: Neighbors and friends, though we don't have anyone for the bride and bridegroom's places at the table, you know there's nothing missing in the feast itself.

paragraphs.original:
(to TRANIO)
(to
)
Lucentio, you shall supply the bridegroom's place,
And let Bianca take her sister's room.
She shall, Lucentio. Come, gentlemen, let's go.
paragraphs.translated: She shall, Lucentio. Come, gentlemen, let's go in.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter GRUMIO
paragraphs.translated: GRUMIO enters.

paragraphs.original: Fie, fie on all tired jades, on all mad masters, and all foul ways! Was ever man so beaten? Was ever man so 'rayed? Was ever man so weary? I am sent before to make a fire, and they are coming after to warm them. Now, were not I a little pot and soon hot, my very lips might freeze to my teeth, my tongue to the roof of my mouth, my heart in my belly, ere I should come by a fire to thaw me. But I with blowing the fire shall warm myself. For, considering the weather, a taller man than I will take cold. - Holla, ho! Curtis!
paragraphs.translated: To hell with all worn-out horses, all crazy masters, and all bad roads. Was a man ever beaten as much as me? Was a man ever as dirty as me? Was a man ever so tired? I have been sent on ahead to light a fire, and they are coming after to warm themselves. It's a good thing I'm like a little pot and warm up quickly, or else my lips themselves would freeze and stick to my teeth, my tongue to the roof of my mouth, and my heart would freeze in my belly, before I managed to get thawed out. I'll warm myself by blowing on the fire. A taller man than I would catch cold in weather like this. Hey! Curtis! Hello!

paragraphs.original: Enter CURTIS
paragraphs.translated: CURTIS enters.

paragraphs.original: Who is that calls so coldly?
paragraphs.translated: Who calls so coldly?

paragraphs.original: A piece of ice. If thou doubt it, thou mayst slide from my shoulder to my heel with no greater a run but my head and my neck. A fire, good Curtis.
paragraphs.translated: A piece of ice. Trust me, you could slide all the way from my shoulder to my heel taking no more of a running start than the distance between my head and my neck. Start the fire, good Curtis.

paragraphs.original: Is my master and his wife coming, Grumio?
paragraphs.translated: Are my master and his wife coming, Grumio?

paragraphs.original: Oh, ay, Curtis, ay, and therefore fire, fire. Cast on no water.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, yes, Curtis, so hurry up and start the fire. Leave out the water.

paragraphs.original: Is she so hot a shrew as she's reported?
paragraphs.translated: Is she as fiery a shrew as they say?

paragraphs.original: She was, good Curtis, before this frost. But thou knowest winter tames man, woman and beast, for it hath tamed my old master and my new mistress and myself, fellow Curtis.
paragraphs.translated: Well she was, good Curtis, before this frost. But you know how winter tames man, woman, and beast. And it's tamed my old master and my new mistress and myself, my good colleague.

paragraphs.original: Away, you three-inch fool! I am no beast.
paragraphs.translated: Who are you calling "beast," midget. You're no bigger than three inches!

paragraphs.original: Am I but three inches? Why, thy horn is a foot, and so long am I, at the least. But wilt thou make a fire, or shall I complain on thee to our mistress, whose hand, she being now at hand, thou shalt soon feel, to thy cold comfort, for being slow in thy hot office?
paragraphs.translated: Three inches? Really? Your horn is a foot long, and I'm at least that size. Now are you going to make a fire, or am I going to have to report you to our mistress, whose hand, now that she is herself at hand, you'll be feeling soon. You'll find it cold comfort, but that's what you get for being slow with your warming duties.

paragraphs.original: I prithee, good Grumio, tell me, how goes the world?
paragraphs.translated: So tell me, Grumio, how goes the world?

paragraphs.original: A cold world, Curtis, in every office but thine, and therefore fire! Do thy duty, and have thy duty, for my master and mistress are almost frozen to death.
paragraphs.translated: Cold, Curtis. It's a cold world, except for people who have to start fires. Therefore, do your duty and take your reward, because my master and mistress are nearly frozen to death.

paragraphs.original: There's fire ready. And therefore, good Grumio, the news.
paragraphs.translated: The fire is ready. So go on, tell me the news.

paragraphs.original: Why, "Jack, boy! Ho, boy!" and as much news as wilt thou.
paragraphs.translated:
"
Why, Jack boy, ho boy!" and all the news you want.
Why, Jack boy, ho boy

paragraphs.original: Come, you are so full of cony-catching!
paragraphs.translated:
Oh, you're just so funny.
so

paragraphs.original: Why, therefore fire, for I have caught extreme cold. Where's the cook? Is supper ready, the house trimmed, rushes strewed, cobwebs swept, the servingmen in their new fustian, their white stockings, and every officer his wedding garment on? Be the Jacks fair within, the Jills fair without, the carpets laid, and everything in order?
paragraphs.translated: Well, make a fire, then. I think I'm getting delirious. Where's the cook? Is supper ready? Is the house fixed up, the floor covered, the cobwebs swept out of the corners, the servingmen in their new work clothes and the household servants each in his wedding suit? Are all the cups and glasses in their places, the tablecloths laid out - everything in order?

paragraphs.original: All ready. And therefore, I pray thee, news.
paragraphs.translated: Everything's ready. So tell me what's been going on.

paragraphs.original: First, know my horse is tired, my master and mistress fallen out.
paragraphs.translated: Well, first of all, my horse is tired and my master and mistress have had a falling out.

paragraphs.original: How?
paragraphs.translated: How?

paragraphs.original: Out of their saddles into the dirt, and thereby hangs a tale.
paragraphs.translated: From their saddles into the dirt - but that's another story.

paragraphs.original: Let's ha' 't, good Grumio.
paragraphs.translated: Well, let's have it, Grumio.

paragraphs.original: Lend thine ear.
paragraphs.translated: Lean forward.

paragraphs.original: Here.
paragraphs.translated: Here.

paragraphs.original: There!
paragraphs.translated: There!

paragraphs.original: Strikes him
paragraphs.translated: GRUMIO strikes CURTIS.

paragraphs.original: This 'tis to feel a tale, not to hear a tale.
paragraphs.translated: This is to feel the news, not hear it.

paragraphs.original: And therefore 'tis called a sensible tale. And this cuff was but to knock at your ear and beseech list'ning. Now I begin: Imprimis, we came down a foul hill, my master riding behind my mistress -
paragraphs.translated: That's what makes it "sensitive" news. I was just knocking to see if anyone was home. Now, I'll begin: first, we came down a steep hill, my master riding behind my mistress -

paragraphs.original: Both of one horse?
paragraphs.translated: Both on one horse?

paragraphs.original: What's that to thee?
paragraphs.translated: What's the difference?

paragraphs.original: Why, a horse.
paragraphs.translated: Well, the difference of a horse!

paragraphs.original: Tell thou the tale! But hadst thou not crossed me, thou shouldst have heard how her horse fell, and she under her horse. Thou shouldst have heard in how miry a place, how she was bemoiled, how he left her with the horse upon her, how he beat me because her horse stumbled, how she waded through the dirt to pluck him off me, how he swore, how she prayed that never prayed before, how I cried, how the horses ran away, how her bridle was burst, how I lost my crupper, with many things of worthy memory which now shall die in oblivion, and thou return unexperienced to thy grave.
paragraphs.translated:
Oh, tell it yourself if you're so smart. It's too bad. If you hadn't made me angry, you would have heard all about how her horse fell with her under it, how swampy the place was, too, and how she was covered in mud, and how he left her like that, with the horse on top of her, and how he beat me because her horse stumbled, and how she waded through the dirt to pull him off me, and how he swore, how she prayed - this woman who never prayed before - and how I yelled, and how the horses ran away, and how her bridle broke, and how I lost my riding crop, and many other things worth telling, which now will all be lost to memory, and you'll go to your grave ignorant.
me
her

paragraphs.original: By this reck'ning he is more shrew than she.
paragraphs.translated: By the sound of it, he's a bigger shrew than she is.

paragraphs.original: Ay, and that thou and the proudest of you all shall find when he comes home. But what talk I of this?
