Call forth Nathaniel, Joseph, Nicholas, Philip, Walter, Sugarsop, and the rest. Let their heads be slickly combed, their blue coats brushed, and their garters of an indifferent knit. Let them curtsy with their left legs, and not presume to touch a hair of my master's horse-tail till they kiss their hands. Are they all ready?
paragraphs.translated: Yes - as you and the rest will find out as soon as he's home. But why am I telling you this? Get them in here - Nathaniel, Joseph, Nicholas, Philip, Walter, Sugarsop, and the rest. Tell them to slick down their hair, brush their blue coats, and make sure their socks match. Have them click their heels together and don't dare touch a hair of the master's horse's tail till they kiss their hands. Are they all ready?

paragraphs.original: They are.
paragraphs.translated: They are.

paragraphs.original: Call them forth.
paragraphs.translated: Get them in here.

paragraphs.original:
(calling offstage) Do you hear, ho? you must meet my master to countenance my mistress.
(calling offstage)
paragraphs.translated:
(calling offstage) Hey! Does anyone hear me? Hey! You have to come and greet the master and face the new mistress.
(calling offstage)

paragraphs.original: Why, she hath a face of her own.
paragraphs.translated: She already has a face.

paragraphs.original: Who knows not that?
paragraphs.translated: Yeah, so?

paragraphs.original: Thou, it seems, that calls for company to countenance her.
paragraphs.translated: You just said they had to face her.

paragraphs.original: I call them forth to credit her.
paragraphs.translated: I meant they had to give her credit.

paragraphs.original: Why, she comes to borrow nothing of them.
paragraphs.translated: She's not going to borrow money from them.

paragraphs.original: Enter four or five Servingmen
paragraphs.translated: Four or five servants enter.

paragraphs.original: Welcome home, Grumio.
paragraphs.translated: Welcome home, Grumio.

paragraphs.original: How now, Grumio?
paragraphs.translated: What's up, Grumio?

paragraphs.original: What, Grumio!
paragraphs.translated: Hey, Grumio!

paragraphs.original: Fellow Grumio!
paragraphs.translated: My man Grumio!

paragraphs.original: How now, old lad?
paragraphs.translated: So what's the story, old boy?

paragraphs.original: Welcome, you! - How now, you? - What, you! - Fellow, you! - And thus much for greeting. Now, my spruce companions, is all ready, and all things neat?
paragraphs.translated:
Welcome yourself! - What's up with you? - Hey to you! - So much for greetings. Now, my well-dressed friends, is everything ready and in order?
you?
you!

paragraphs.original: All things is ready. How near is our master?
paragraphs.translated: Everything's ready. How soon will the master be here?

paragraphs.original:
E'en at hand, alighted by this. And therefore be not - 
Cock's passion, silence! I hear my master.
paragraphs.translated: Any minute. Probably here already. So be careful, and don't - God! Quiet, I hear him coming.

paragraphs.original: Enter PETRUCHIO and KATHERINE
paragraphs.translated: PETRUCHIO and KATHERINE enter.

paragraphs.original:
Where be these knaves? What, no man at door
To hold my stirrup nor to take my horse!
Where is Nathaniel, Gregory, Philip?
paragraphs.translated: Where are those bastards? Where is the boy who's supposed to help me get off my horse and take him to the stable? Where is Nathaniel? Where's Gregory? Where's Philip?

paragraphs.original: Here, here, sir! Here, sir!
paragraphs.translated: Here, here, sir! Here, sir!

paragraphs.original:
"Here, sir! Here, sir! Here, sir! Here, sir!"
You loggerheaded and unpolished grooms!
What, no attendance? No regard? No duty?
Where is the foolish knave I sent before?
paragraphs.translated: "Here, sir! Here, sir! Here, sir! Here, sir!" You stupid, unpolished dolts! I get no service, no respect, no attention! Where is the fool I sent on ahead?

paragraphs.original: Here, sir, as foolish as I was before.
paragraphs.translated: Here, sir, as foolish as ever.

paragraphs.original:
You peasant swain! You whoreson malt-horse drudge!
Did I not bid thee meet me in the park
And bring along these rascal knaves with thee?
paragraphs.translated: You unwashed farmworker! You bastard workhorse drudge! Didn't I tell you to meet me outside and bring these morons with you?

paragraphs.original:
Nathaniel's coat, sir, was not fully made,
And Gabriel's pumps were all unpinked i' th' heel.
There was no link to color Peter's hat,
And Walter's dagger was not come from sheathing.
There were none fine but Adam, Rafe, and Gregory.
The rest were ragged, old, and beggarly.
Yet, as they are, here are they come to meet you.
paragraphs.translated: Nathaniel's coat was being fixed, sir. And one of Gabriel's shoes had a broken heel. And Peter couldn't find a matching hat. And Walter couldn't get his dagger out of its sheath. Only Adam, Rafe, and Gregory were ready. The rest were just a mess - but such as they are, sir, they're here to welcome you.

paragraphs.original: Go, rascals, go, and fetch my supper in.
paragraphs.translated: Go, blockheads, go, and bring my supper to me.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt Servants
paragraphs.translated: The servants exit.

paragraphs.original:
Singing
Singing
Where is the life that late I led - 
Where is the life that late I led - 
Where are those - Sit down, Kate, and welcome. - 
Where are those
Soud, soud, soud, soud!
paragraphs.translated:
(singing) Where is the life I led until recently? Where are those - Sit down, Kate, make yourself at home. - Come on, come on, come on, come on.
(singing) Where is the life I led until recently? Where are those

paragraphs.original: Enter Servants with supper
paragraphs.translated: Servants enter with supper.

paragraphs.original:
Why, when, I say? - Nay, good sweet Kate, be merry. - 
Off with my boots, you rogues! You villains, when?
paragraphs.translated:
Did I say later? I said now! - Smile, Kate! Be happy. - Get my boots off, you apes! You idiots, now!
now!
now!

paragraphs.original:
Sings
Sings
It was the friar of orders gray,
It was the friar of orders gray,
As he forth walkèd on his way: - 
As he forth walkèd on his way
A servant tries to take off PETRUCHIO's boots.
A servant tries to take off
's boots.
Out, you rogue! You pluck my foot awry.
Take that, and mend the plucking off the other.
Strikes him
Strikes him
Be merry, Kate. - Some water, here, what, ho!
Where's my spaniel Troilus? Sirrah, get you hence
And bid my cousin Ferdinand come hither.
paragraphs.translated:
(singing) It was a friar in robes of gray, who walked along the road one day: - (a servant tries to take off PETRUCHIO's boots) Stop, you moron! You're twisting my foot! Take that, and see you do a better job with the other one. (he strikes the servant) Be happy, Kate! - Bring me some water! Where's my spaniel Troilus? Hey boy, go tell my cousin Ferdinand to get in here.
(singing)
It was a friar in robes of gray, who walked along the road one day
(a servant tries to take off
's boots)
(he strikes the servant)

paragraphs.original: Exit a servant
paragraphs.translated: A servant exits.

paragraphs.original:
One, Kate, that you must kiss and be acquainted with. - 
Where are my slippers? Shall I have some water? -
paragraphs.translated: You'll love this guy, Kate - anyway, you'd better! Where are my slippers? Can we have some water please here? -

paragraphs.original: Enter one with water
paragraphs.translated: A servant enters with water.

paragraphs.original:
Come, Kate, and wash, and welcome heartily. - 
You whoreson villain! Will you let it fall?
Strikes him
Strikes him
paragraphs.translated:
Come and wash, Kate, make yourself at home. Son of a bitch, you spilled it! (he strikes the servant)
(he strikes the servant)

paragraphs.original: Patience, I pray you! 'Twas a fault unwilling.
paragraphs.translated: Take it easy! Please! It was just an accident!

paragraphs.original:
A whoreson, beetle-headed, flap-eared knave! - 
Come, Kate, sit down. I know you have a stomach.
Will you give thanks, sweet Kate, or else shall I? - 
What's this? Mutton?
paragraphs.translated: He's a son of a bitch, a moron, a total jerk. - Come sit down, Kate, I know you must be hungry. Will you say grace, sweet Kate, or shall I? - What is this? Mutton?

paragraphs.original: Ay.
paragraphs.translated: Yes.

paragraphs.original: Who brought it?
paragraphs.translated: Who brought it out here?

paragraphs.original: I.
paragraphs.translated: I did.

paragraphs.original:
'Tis burnt, and so is all the meat.
What dogs are these! Where is the rascal cook?
How durst you, villains, bring it from the dresser
And serve it thus to me that love it not?
There, take it to you, trenchers, cups, and all!
Throws the meat, & c. about the stage
Throws the meat, & c. about the stage
You heedless joltheads and unmannered slaves!
What, do you grumble? I'll be with you straight.
paragraphs.translated:
It's burnt. The whole thing is burnt. You bastards! Where is that moron of a cook? You devils! How dare you serve it to me this way! There, take it all back - plates, cups, the whole thing. (throws the meat and everything else around the stage) You careless blockheads and unwashed slaves! I heard that! I'll deal with you in a minute.
(throws the meat and everything else around the stage

paragraphs.original: Exeunt servants
paragraphs.translated: Servants exit.

paragraphs.original:
I pray you, husband, be not so disquiet.
The meat was well, if you were so contented.
paragraphs.translated: Please, dear, calm down. The meat was fine if you wanted to eat it.

paragraphs.original:
I tell thee, Kate, 'twas burnt and dried away.
And I expressly am forbid to touch it,
For it engenders choler, planteth anger;
And better 'twere that both of us did fast,
Since of ourselves, ourselves are choleric,
Than feed it with such over-roasted flesh.
Be patient, tomorrow 't shall be mended,
And, for this night, we'll fast for company.
paragraphs.translated:
And I'm telling you it was burnt and dried out. I'm not allowed to eat
overcooked meat. It gives me indigestion and that makes me irritable. Very, very irritable.Better for us to go hungry, since we're both hotheaded, than for us to eat meat that's been cooked too long. But don't worry, tomorrow it will get straightened out. Tonight we'll go without food.
overcooked meat

paragraphs.original: Come, I will bring thee to thy bridal chamber.
paragraphs.translated: Come, I'll show you your bridal chamber.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter Servants severally
paragraphs.translated: Servants enter from different parts of the stage.

paragraphs.original: Peter, didst ever see the like?
paragraphs.translated: Peter, did you ever see anything like it?

paragraphs.original: He kills her in her own humor.
paragraphs.translated: He's giving her a taste of her own medicine.

paragraphs.original: Enter CURTIS
paragraphs.translated: CURTIS enters.

paragraphs.original: Where is he?
paragraphs.translated: Where is he?

paragraphs.original:
In her chamber,
Making a sermon of continency to her,
And rails and swears and rates, that she, poor soul,
Knows not which way to stand, to look, to speak,
And sits as one new-risen from a dream.
Away, away, for he is coming hither!
paragraphs.translated: In her room, lecturing her on the virtues of self-control. He rants and rails and swears and she, poor thing, doesn't know how to stand or look or speak. She sits like a person who's just woken up from a dream. Look out, he's coming!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter PETRUCHIO
paragraphs.translated: PETRUCHIO enters.

paragraphs.original:
Thus have I politicly begun my reign,
And 'tis my hope to end successfully.
My falcon now is sharp and passing empty,
And, till she stoop, she must not be full-gorged,
For then she never looks upon her lure.
Another way I have to man my haggard,
To make her come and know her keeper's call.
paragraphs.translated: Well, I've begun my reign with a carefully thought-out plan, and I have every hope of succeeding. My falcon is now hungry and unfed and must not be given enough to eat until she comes to me, for if her hunger is satisfied, she'll pay no attention to the bait. I have another plan to make my bird come to me and recognize her owner's call is to keep her from sleeping -

paragraphs.original:
That is, to watch her, as we watch these kites
That bate and beat and will not be obedient.
She ate no meat today, nor none shall eat.
Last night she slept not, nor tonight she shall not.
As with the meat, some undeservèd fault
I'll find about the making of the bed,
And here I'll fling the pillow, there the bolster,
This way the coverlet, another way the sheets.
Ay, and amid this hurly I intend
That all is done in reverend care of her.
And, in conclusion, she shall watch all night,
And if she chance to nod I'll rail and brawl,
And with the clamor keep her still awake.
This is a way to kill a wife with kindness,
And thus I'll curb her mad and headstrong humor.
He that knows better how to tame a shrew,
Now let him speak; 'tis charity to show.
paragraphs.translated: the way trainers do with young hawks that flutter and flap and will not obey. She had no food today and will have none. Last night she got no sleep, and she won't get any tonight. Just as I did with the meat, I'll make up some problem with the way the bed is made, and throw the pillow one way and the cushion the other, and the blanket over here and the sheets over there. And through all the shouting and fuss, I'll swear that it's all out of love for her. The end result will be that she'll sit up all night. And if she starts to drop off, I'll rant and yell until I wake her up. This is how to kill a wife with kindness. And this way I'll cure her wild and willful nature. If anyone here knows a better way to tame a shrew, speak up, please. It would be much appreciated.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter TRANIO as LUCENTIO and HORTENSIO as LITIO
paragraphs.translated: TRANIO enters, disguised as LUCENTIO, accompanied by HORTENSIO, disguised as LITIO.

paragraphs.original:
(as LUCENTIO)
(as
)
Is 't possible, friend Litio, that mistress Bianca
Doth fancy any other but Lucentio?
I tell you, sir, she bears me fair in hand.

(as LITIO) Sir, to satisfy you in what I have said,
(as
)
Stand by and mark the manner of his teaching.
They stand aside
They stand aside
paragraphs.translated:
(as LITIO) You want proof of what I'm telling you? Stand right here and watch this fellow's "lesson." (they stand off to one side)
(as
)
(they stand off to one side)

paragraphs.original: Enter BIANCA and LUCENTIO as CAMBIO
paragraphs.translated: BIANCA enters with LUCENTIO disguised as CAMBIO.

paragraphs.original: What, master, read you? First resolve me that.
paragraphs.translated: What are you reading, teacher? Answer me that first.

paragraphs.original:
(as CAMBIO) I read that I profess, The Art to Love.
(as
)
The Art to Love.
paragraphs.translated:
(as CAMBIO) I'm reading the book I know best - 
The Art of Love
(as
)
The Art of Love
The Art of Love

paragraphs.original: And may you prove, sir, master of your art.
paragraphs.translated: I hope you're an expert in your field.

paragraphs.original:
(as LITIO) Quick proceeders, marry! Now, tell me, I pray,
(as
)
You that durst swear that your mistress Bianca
Loved none in the world so well as Lucentio.

(as LUCENTIO) O despiteful love! Unconstant womankind!
(as
)
I tell thee, Litio, this is wonderful!

Mistake no more. I am not Litio,
Nor a musician as I seem to be,
But one that scorn to live in this disguise
For such a one as leaves a gentlema
And makes a god of such a cullion.
Know, sir, that I am called Hortensio.
paragraphs.translated: Let me come clean. I'm not really Litio. I'm not even a musician, really. In fact, I refuse to go on with this charade for a woman who would choose a lower-class guy like this over a gentleman of my stature. My name is Hortensio, sir.

paragraphs.original:
(as LUCENTIO) Signior Hortensio, I have often heard
(as
)
Of your entire affection to Bianca,
And since mine eyes are witness of her lightness,
I will with you, if you be so contented,
Forswear Bianca and her love for ever.

See how they kiss and court! Signior Lucentio,
Here is my hand, and here I firmly vow
Never to woo her more, but do forswear her
As one unworthy all the former favors
That I have fondly flattered her withal.
paragraphs.translated: Look how they kiss and carry on! Signior Lucentio, it's a deal. I hereby swear to have nothing more to do with this girl. I formally declare her unworthy of all the attention and expense I have wasted on her.

paragraphs.original:
And here I take the like unfeignèd oath
Never to marry with her, though she would entreat.
Fie on her! See how beastly she doth court him!
paragraphs.translated: And I hereby make the same promise - never to marry her, not even if she begs me. The hell with her! Look how she carries on with him! It's revolting!

paragraphs.original:
Would all the world but he had quite forsworn!
For me, that I may surely keep mine oath,
I will be married to a wealthy widow,
Ere three days pass, which hath as long loved me
As I have loved this proud disdainful haggard.
And so farewell, Signior Lucentio.
Kindness in women, not their beauteous looks,
Shall win my love, and so I take my leave,
In resolution as I swore before.
paragraphs.translated: I wish all her lovers had given her up. Well, to be on the safe side - so I don't go back on my promise - I plan to get myself married to a wealthy widow within the next three days. She's been after me for years - the way I've been for this proud, haughty hag. Farewell, then, Signior Lucentio. From now on, goodness in women, not superficial beauty, will win my heart. I bid you all goodbye. I've made up my mind, and I'm going to stick to it.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original:
Mistress Bianca, bless you with such grace
As 'longeth to a lover's blessèd case!
Nay, I have ta'en you napping, gentle love,
And have forsworn you with Hortensio.
paragraphs.translated: Miss Bianca, may you be blessed with all the happiness you deserve. No, I've caught you out, my dear. You're busted. Hortensio and I have given you up.

paragraphs.original: Tranio, you jest. But have you both forsworn me?
paragraphs.translated: You can't mean it, Tranio! Have you both really given me up?

paragraphs.original: Mistress, we have.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, ma'am, we have.

paragraphs.original: Then we are rid of Litio.
paragraphs.translated: So Litio's out of the picture.

paragraphs.original:
I' faith, he'll have a lusty widow now
That shall be wooed and wedded in a day.
paragraphs.translated: He's going after a young widow. He says he'll court and win her in a day.

paragraphs.original: God give him joy!
paragraphs.translated: Well, good for him!

paragraphs.original: Ay, and he'll tame her.
paragraphs.translated: Yeah, and he's going to tame her.

paragraphs.original: He says so, Tranio?
paragraphs.translated: Is that what he says?

paragraphs.original: Faith, he is gone unto the taming school.
paragraphs.translated: Yep. He's gone to study at the taming school.

paragraphs.original: The taming school? What, is there such a place?
paragraphs.translated: The taming school? Is there such a place?

paragraphs.original:
Ay, mistress, and Petruchio is the master,
That teacheth tricks eleven and twenty long
To tame a shrew and charm her chattering tongue.
paragraphs.translated:
Yes, ma'am. Petruchio runs it. There he teaches piles of tricks for taming a shrew and her tongue.
and

paragraphs.original: Enter BIONDELLO
paragraphs.translated: BIONDELLO enters.

paragraphs.original:
O master, master, I have watched so long
That I am dog-weary, but at last I spied
An ancient angel coming down the hill
Will serve the turn.
paragraphs.translated: Master, master, I've been on the lookout so long, I'm ready to fall down dead - but I've got one, finally! There's a trustworthy old fellow coming down the hill who will do the job.

paragraphs.original: What is he, Biondello?
paragraphs.translated: What does he look like, Biondello?

paragraphs.original:
Master, a marcantant, or a pedant,
I know not what, but formal in apparel,
In gait and countenance surely like a father.
paragraphs.translated: A merchant or a schoolmaster, sir. Well, I don't know exactly, but his clothes are respectable, and to judge from his face and walk, he's old enough to be Lucentio's father.

paragraphs.original: And what of him, Tranio?
paragraphs.translated: And what about him, Tranio?

paragraphs.original:
If he be credulous and trust my tale,
I'll make him glad to seem Vincentio
And give assurance to Baptista Minola
As if he were the right Vincentio.
Take in your love, and then let me alone.
paragraphs.translated: If he's an easy mark and buys my story, I think I can get him to pose as Vincentio - and be as ready to vouch for you with Baptista Minola as the real Vincentio would. Go, take your sweetheart and leave him to me.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt LUCENTIO and BIANCA
paragraphs.translated: LUCENTIO and BIANCA exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter a MERCHANT
paragraphs.translated: A MERCHANT enters.

paragraphs.original: God save you, sir.
paragraphs.translated: May God keep you well, sir.

paragraphs.original:
(as LUCENTIO)
(as
)
And you, sir. You are welcome.
Travel you far on, or are you at the farthest?

Sir, at the farthest for a week or two,
But then up farther, and as far as Rome,
And so to Tripoli, if God lend me life.
paragraphs.translated: This is it, for now. Then, in a week or two, I'll continue on as far as Rome, then on to Tripoli, God willing.

paragraphs.original: Of Mantua.
paragraphs.translated: Mantua.

paragraphs.original:
(as LUCENTIO) Of Mantua, sir? Marry, God forbid!
(as
)
And come to Padua, careless of your life?
My life, sir! how, I pray? For that goes hard.
paragraphs.translated: Killed? Why? That would be a little extreme!

paragraphs.original:
'Tis death for anyone in Mantua
To come to Padua. Know you not the cause?
Your ships are stayed at Venice, and the Duke,
For private quarrel 'twixt your duke and him,
Hath published and proclaimed it openly.
'Tis marvel, but that you are but newly come,
You might have heard it else proclaimed about.
paragraphs.translated: It's a capital offense for anyone from Mantua to come to Padua. Didn't you know? The Duke of Padua has publicly proclaimed it. He's feuding with your duke, and all ships from Mantua are being held up at Venice. It's strange that you haven't heard. There are signs up all over town - but I guess it's because you've only just arrived.

paragraphs.original:
Alas, sir, it is worse for me than so,
For I have bills for money by exchange
From Florence, and must here deliver them.
paragraphs.translated: Oh dear, oh dear. This is very bad, very bad. I have promissory notes from Florence that I have to deliver.

paragraphs.original:
(as LUCENTIO) Well, sir, to do you courtesy,
(as
)
This will I do, and this I will advise you.
First tell me, have you ever been at Pisa?

Ay, sir, in Pisa have I often been,
Pisa renownèd for grave citizens.
paragraphs.translated: Oh yes, sir, I have often been to Pisa - Pisa, City of Wise Men.

paragraphs.original:
I know him not, but I have heard of him:
A merchant of incomparable wealth.
paragraphs.translated: I've heard of him but I've never met him. A merchant of unheard-of wealth.

paragraphs.original:
(as LUCENTIO) He is my father, sir, and sooth to say,
(as
)
In count'nance somewhat doth resemble you.

(aside) As much as an apple doth an oyster, and all one.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
(speaking to the audience) As much as an apple looks like an oyster, but whatever.
(speaking to the audience)

paragraphs.original:
(as LUCENTIO) To save your life in this extremity,
(as
)
This favor will I do you for his sake - 
And think it not the worst of all your fortunes
That you are like to Sir Vincentio - 
His name and credit shall you undertake,
And in my house you shall be friendly lodged.
Look that you take upon you as you should.
You understand me, sir. So shall you stay
Till you have done your business in the city.
If this be court'sy, sir, accept of it.

O sir, I do, and will repute you ever
The patron of my life and liberty.
paragraphs.translated: Oh sir, I accept. And I'll be eternally grateful to you.

paragraphs.original:
(as LUCENTIO) Then go with me to make the matter good.
(as
)
This, by the way, I let you understand:
My father is here looked for every day
To pass assurance of a dower in marriage
'Twixt me and one Baptista's daughter here.
In all these circumstances I'll instruct you.
Go with me to clothe you as becomes you.
Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter KATHERINE and GRUMIO
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE and GRUMIO enter.

paragraphs.original: No, no, forsooth, I dare not for my life.
paragraphs.translated: No, no, I can't, really. He'd kill me.

paragraphs.original:
The more my wrong, the more his spite appears.
What, did he marry me to famish me?
Beggars that come unto my father's door
Upon entreaty have a present alms.
If not, elsewhere they meet with charity.
But I, who never knew how to entreat,
Nor never needed that I should entreat,
Am starved for meat, giddy for lack of sleep,
With oaths kept waking and with brawling fed.
And that which spites me more than all these wants,
He does it under name of perfect love,
As who should say, if I should sleep or eat,
'Twere deadly sickness or else present death.
I prithee, go and get me some repast,
I care not what, so it be wholesome food.
paragraphs.translated: The more I suffer, the more spiteful he becomes. Did he marry me just to starve me? Beggars at my father's door are given money as soon as they ask for it. And if they don't find charity there, they find it someplace else. But I, who have never known how to beg and never had to beg, am starved for food, dizzy with lack of sleep, kept awake with curses and fed with brawling. And what irks me more than all these things put together is that he does it under the pretense of love - as though for me to eat or sleep would bring on fatal illness or sudden death. Please, go and get me something to eat. I don't care what so long as it's nutritious.

paragraphs.original: What say you to a neat's foot?
paragraphs.translated: What do you say to a calf's foot?

paragraphs.original: 'Tis passing good. I prithee let me have it.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, lovely. Can I have some?

paragraphs.original:
I fear it is too choleric a meat.
How say you to a fat tripe finely broiled?
paragraphs.translated:
I'm afraid it will
raise your blood pressure. What do you say to an ox stomach, nicely broiled?
raise your blood pressure

paragraphs.original: I like it well. Good Grumio, fetch it me.
paragraphs.translated: I'd love it. Nice Grumio, bring me some.

paragraphs.original: I cannot tell. I fear 'tis choleric. What say you to a piece of beef and mustard?
paragraphs.translated: I don't know. I'm afraid it will make you too hot, too. What do you say to a piece of beef with mustard?

paragraphs.original: A dish that I do love to feed upon.
paragraphs.translated: A favorite dish of mine.

paragraphs.original: Ay, but the mustard is too hot a little.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, but the mustard is probably too hot.

paragraphs.original: Why then, the beef, and let the mustard rest.
paragraphs.translated: Well then, the beef without the mustard.

paragraphs.original:
Nay then, I will not. You shall have the mustard
Or else you get no beef of Grumio.
paragraphs.translated: Absolutely not. You'll take the mustard or you'll get no beef from Grumio.

paragraphs.original: Then both, or one, or anything thou wilt.
paragraphs.translated: Then both, or one, or anything you like.

paragraphs.original: Why then, the mustard without the beef.
paragraphs.translated: How about the mustard without the beef.

paragraphs.original:
Go, get thee gone, thou false deluding slave,
Beats him
Beats him
That feed'st me with the very name of meat.
Sorrow on thee and all the pack of you
That triumph thus upon my misery.
Go, get thee gone, I say.
paragraphs.translated:
Get out of here, you measly, lying wretch. (she beats him.) You feed me with only the names of foods. To hell with you and the whole pack of you who triumph at my misery. Go on, I said get out of here.
(she beats him.)

paragraphs.original: Enter PETRUCHIO and HORTENSIO with meat
paragraphs.translated: PETRUCHIO and HORTENSIO enter with a dish of meat.

paragraphs.original: How fares my Kate? What, sweeting, all amort?
paragraphs.translated: How is my Kate? Feeling blue, darling?

paragraphs.original: Mistress, what cheer?
paragraphs.translated: Mistress, how are you?

paragraphs.original: Faith, as cold as can be.
paragraphs.translated: Believe me, I've been better.

paragraphs.original:
Pluck up thy spirits. Look cheerfully upon me.
Here love, thou seest how diligent I am,
To dress thy meat myself and bring it thee.
I am sure, sweet Kate, this kindness merits thanks.
What, not a word? Nay, then thou lov'st it not
And all my pains is sorted to no proof.
Here, take away this dish.
paragraphs.translated: Cheer up. Give us a smile. Look, love, see how devoted I am? I've prepared a meal for you myself, and here it is. I am sure, sweet Kate, this kindness deserves thanks. What, not a word? I guess you don't want it. Ah well, all my trouble was for nothing. Here, take away the dish.

paragraphs.original: I pray you, let it stand.
paragraphs.translated: Please, leave it here.

paragraphs.original:
The poorest service is repaid with thanks,
And so shall mine, before you touch the meat.
paragraphs.translated: The smallest service is repaid with thanks. Mine will be, too, before you touch the food.

paragraphs.original: I thank you, sir.
paragraphs.translated: Thank you, sir.

paragraphs.original:
Signior Petruchio, fie, you are to blame.
Come, mistress Kate, I'll bear you company.
paragraphs.translated: Shame on you, Petruchio! You are too harsh. Come, mistress Kate, I'll join you.

paragraphs.original:
(aside to HORTENSIO)
(aside to
)
Eat it up all, Hortensio, if thou lovest me. - 
Much good do it unto thy gentle heart.
Kate, eat apace. And now, my honey love,
Will we return unto thy father's house
And revel it as bravely as the best,
With silken coats and caps and golden rings,
With ruffs and cuffs and farthingales and things,
With scarves and fans and double change of brav'ry,
With amber bracelets, beads, and all this knav'ry.
What, hast thou dined? The tailor stays thy leisure
To deck thy body with his ruffling treasure.
paragraphs.translated:
(speaking so that only HORTENSIO can hear) Do me a favor and scarf it all down yourself, Hortensio. - May it do your gentle heart good, Kate. Eat up quickly, my honey lamb, we're off to your father's house to join in the revelry, where we'll dress as well as the best of them, with silk robes and caps and golden rings, collars and cuffs and fancy frocks and things, with scarves and fans and two changes of clothes, amber bracelets, beads, and plenty of gewgaws. All finished? The tailor is waiting to deck you out in ruffled finery.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original: Enter TAILOR
paragraphs.translated: A TAILOR enters.

paragraphs.original:
Come, tailor, let us see these ornaments.
Lay forth the gown.
paragraphs.translated: Now, tailor, let's see what you've got. Lay out the gown.

paragraphs.original: Enter HABERDASHER
paragraphs.translated: A HATMAKER enters.

paragraphs.original: What news with you, sir?
paragraphs.translated: What can I do for you, sir?

paragraphs.original: Here is the cap your Worship did bespeak.
paragraphs.translated: Here is the cap your Worship ordered.

paragraphs.original:
Why, this was molded on a porringer!
A velvet dish! Fie, fie, 'tis lewd and filthy!
Why, 'tis a cockle or a walnut shell,
A knack, a toy, a trick, a baby's cap.
Away with it! Come, let me have a bigger.
paragraphs.translated: Why, this was modeled on a porridge bowl! It's a velvet dish! No, definitely not! It's cheap and nasty! It's like a cockleshell or a walnut shell, a joke, a prank, a doll's cap. Take it away. Bring me a bigger one.

paragraphs.original:
I'll have no bigger. This doth fit the time,
And gentlewomen wear such caps as these.
paragraphs.translated: I won't have one any bigger. This is the fashion. Gentlewomen are wearing caps like this right now.

paragraphs.original:
When you are gentle, you shall have one too,
And not till then.
paragraphs.translated: When you are gentle, you shall have one, too, and not till then.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) That will not be in haste.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) That won't be anytime soon.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original:
Why, sir, I trust I may have leave to speak,
And speak I will. I am no child, no babe.
Your betters have endured me say my mind,
And if you cannot, best you stop your ears.
My tongue will tell the anger of my heart
Or else my heart, concealing it, will break,
And, rather than it shall, I will be free
Even to the uttermost, as I please, in words.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, I think I have the right to speak, and speak I certainly will. I am not a child or an infant. Better men than you have heard me speak my mind, and if you can't take it, then you'd better plug your ears. I'll express my anger or die concealing it. And rather than have that happen, I'll give myself permission to speak as freely as I like, whatever I may have to say.

paragraphs.original:
Why, thou say'st true. It is a paltry cap,
A custard-coffin, a bauble, a silken pie.
I love thee well in that thou lik'st it not.
paragraphs.translated: You know, you're right. It's a measly little cap, a dessert crust, a plaything, a silk pie. I love you all the more for not liking it.

paragraphs.original:
Love me or love me not, I like the cap,
And it I will have, or I will have none.
paragraphs.translated: I don't care if you love me or not, I like the cap and I'll have it or I won't have any.

paragraphs.original: Exit HABERDASHER
paragraphs.translated: HATMAKER exits.

paragraphs.original:
Thy gown? Why, ay. Come, tailor, let us see 't.
O mercy, God! What masking stuff is here?
What's this? A sleeve? 'Tis like a demi-cannon.
paragraphs.translated: Now, your gown? Yes, yes. Come, tailor, show it to us. Merciful God! What sort of costume do we have here? What do you call this? A sleeve? It's like a cannon.

paragraphs.original:
What, up and down, carved like an apple tart?
Here's snip and nip and cut and slish and slash,
Like to a censer in a barber's shop.
Why, what i' devil's name, tailor, call'st thou this?
paragraphs.translated: What have you done? Carved it up and down like an apple tart? Snip and snip and cut and slash - it's got more holes than a sieve! What in the world do you call this, tailor!

paragraphs.original:
(aside) I see she's like to have neither cap nor gown.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) I see she's likely to have neither cap nor gown.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original:
You bid me make it orderly and well,
According to the fashion and the time.
paragraphs.translated: You told me to make it well and properly and in keeping with the current style.

paragraphs.original:
Marry, and did. But if you be remembered,
I did not bid you mar it to the time.
Go, hop me over every kennel home,
For you shall hop without my custom, sir.
I'll none of it. Hence, make your best of it.
paragraphs.translated: Certainly, I did. But if you remember, I didn't tell you to parody the style. Go on home, sir. You've lost me as a customer. I won't take it. Do whatever you want with it.

paragraphs.original:
I never saw a better-fashioned gown,
More quaint, more pleasing, nor more commendable.
Belike you mean to make a puppet of me.
paragraphs.translated: I never saw a better-designed gown, more elegant and pleasing and well made. Perhaps you think you can make me into some sort of plaything?

paragraphs.original: Why, true, he means to make a puppet of thee.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, that's it! The tailor thinks he can make you into some sort of plaything.

paragraphs.original: She says your Worship means to make a puppet of her.
paragraphs.translated:
She says your Worship thinks you can make her into some sort of plaything.
you

paragraphs.original:
O monstrous arrogance! Thou liest, thou thread, thou thimble,
Thou yard, three-quarters, half-yard, quarter, nail!
Thou flea, thou nit, thou winter cricket thou!
Braved in mine own house with a skein of thread?
Away, thou rag, thou quantity, thou remnant,
Or I shall so be-mete thee with thy yard
As thou shalt think on prating whilst thou liv'st!
I tell thee, I, that thou hast marred her gown.
paragraphs.translated: What monstrous arrogance! It's a lie, you thread, you thimble, you measurement! You flea, you louse, you winter cricket! Disrespected in my own house by a spool of thread! Get out of here you rag, you remnant, you piece of yardage, or I'll measure you within an inch of your life with your own yardstick, and you'll remember your yammering for the rest of your life. I tell you, you've ruined her gown.

paragraphs.original:
Your Worship is deceived. The gown is made
Just as my master had direction.
Grumio gave order how it should be done.
paragraphs.translated: It's not true. The gown was made just as my master was directed. Grumio gave the order for how it should be done.

paragraphs.original: I gave him no order. I gave him the stuff.
paragraphs.translated: I gave him no order. I gave him the material.

paragraphs.original: But how did you desire it should be made?
paragraphs.translated: But how did you want it made?

paragraphs.original: Marry, sir, with needle and thread.
paragraphs.translated: With a needle and thread.

paragraphs.original: But did you not request to have it cut?
paragraphs.translated: But didn't you expect us to cut the cloth?

paragraphs.original: Thou hast faced many things.
paragraphs.translated:
You've
faced many things, haven't you?
faced

paragraphs.original: I have.
paragraphs.translated: I have.

paragraphs.original:
Face not me. Thou hast braved many men; brave not me. I will neither be faced nor braved. I say unto thee, I bid thy master cutout the gown, but I did not bid him cut it to pieces. Ergo, thou liest.
Ergo,
paragraphs.translated: Well, don't face off with me. You have bested many things, well don't try and best me. I will not be faced or bested. I tell you I requested that your master cut out the gown, but I didn't ask him to cut it all to pieces. Therefore, it follows you're a liar.

paragraphs.original: Why, here is the note of the fashion to testify.
paragraphs.translated: Why, here is the order to prove it.

paragraphs.original: Holds up a paper
paragraphs.translated: He holds up a piece of paper.

paragraphs.original: Read it.
paragraphs.translated: Read it.

paragraphs.original: The note lies in 's throat, if he say I said so.
paragraphs.translated: The note is a big fat liar if it says I said so.

paragraphs.original:
(reads) "Imprimis, a loose-bodied gown - "
(reads)
Imprimis,
paragraphs.translated:
(reading) "Item one, a loose-bodied gown - "
(reading)

paragraphs.original: Master, if ever I said "loose-bodied gown," sew me in the skirts of it, and beat me to death with a bottom of brown thread. I said "a gown."
paragraphs.translated:
Master, if ever I said "
loose-bodied gown ," sew me into the skirts of it and beat me to death with a bobbin of brown thread. I said "a gown."
loose-bodied gown

paragraphs.original: Proceed.
paragraphs.translated: Go on.

paragraphs.original:
(reads) "With a small-compassed cape - "
(reads)
paragraphs.translated:
(he reads) "With a half-circle cape - "
(he reads)

paragraphs.original: I confess the cape.
paragraphs.translated: I admit the cape.

paragraphs.original:
(reads) "With a trunk sleeve - "
(reads)
paragraphs.translated:
(he reads) "With a wide sleeve - "
(he reads)

paragraphs.original: I confess two sleeves.
paragraphs.translated: I admit two sleeves.

paragraphs.original:
(reads) "The sleeves curiously cut."
(reads)
paragraphs.translated:
(he reads) "The sleeves carefully cut."
(he reads)

paragraphs.original: Ay, there's the villany.
paragraphs.translated: Ah, there's the problem.

paragraphs.original: Error i' the bill, sir, error i' the bill! I commanded the sleeves should be cut out and sewed up again, and that I'll prove upon thee, though thy little finger be armed in a thimble.
paragraphs.translated: Error in the bill, sir, error in the bill! I ordered that the sleeves be cut out and sewed up again, and I'll prove it in combat even if your little finger is armed with your thimble.

paragraphs.original: This is true that I say: an I had thee in place where, thou shouldst know it.
paragraphs.translated: What I say is true. And if this were a fitting place, I'd prove it.

paragraphs.original: I am for thee straight. Take thou the bill, give me thy mete- yard, and spare not me.
paragraphs.translated: I am ready for you. You take the bill and I'll take your yardstick. Do your worst!

paragraphs.original: God-a-mercy, Grumio! Then he shall have no odds.
paragraphs.translated: God have mercy, Grumio! He won't have a chance.

paragraphs.original: Well, sir, in brief, the gown is not for me.
paragraphs.translated: Well, sir, the gown is not for me.

paragraphs.original: You are i' the right, sir, 'tis for my mistress.
paragraphs.translated: You are right, it's for my mistress.

paragraphs.original: Go, take it up unto thy master's use.
paragraphs.translated: Go, take it away and let your master make whatever use of it he can.

paragraphs.original: Villain, not for thy life! Take up my mistress' gown for thy master's use!
paragraphs.translated: Certainly not! Take off my mistress' gown for your master's use!

paragraphs.original: Why, sir, what's your conceit in that?
paragraphs.translated: Why, what's the problem?

paragraphs.original: O, sir, the conceit is deeper than you think for. Take up my mistress' gown to his master's use! O, fie, fie, fie!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, sir, the problem goes far deeper than you realize. Take up my mistress' gown for his master's use! Oh, that's disgusting!

paragraphs.original:
(aside) Hortensio, say thou wilt see the tailor paid.
(aside)
(to TAILOR) Go, take it hence. Begone, and say no more.
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
(speaking so that only HORTENSIO can hear) Hortensio, tell the tailor you'll make sure he gets paid. (to TAILOR) Take it away. Off you go. There's no more to be said.
(speaking so that only
can hear)
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
(aside to TAILOR)
(aside to
)
Tailor, I'll pay thee for thy gown tomorrow.
Take no unkindness of his hasty words.
Away, I say. Commend me to thy master.
paragraphs.translated:
(speaking so that only TAILOR can hear) Tailor, I'll pay you for the gown tomorrow. Don't be offended at his angry words. Go on, then. Regards to your master.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original: Exit TAILOR
paragraphs.translated: TAILOR exits.

paragraphs.original:
Well, come, my Kate. We will unto your father's
Even in these honest mean habiliments.
Our purses shall be proud, our garments poor,
For 'tis the mind that makes the body rich,
And as the sun breaks through the darkest clouds,
So honor peereth in the meanest habit.
What, is the jay more precious than the lark
Because his feathers are more beautiful?
Or is the adder better than the eel
Because his painted skin contents the eye?
paragraphs.translated: Ah well, my Kate. We'll go to your father's house dressed as we are, in simple but honest clothes. Our purses shall be rich, our garments poor. After all, it's the mind that enriches the body, and just as the sun shines through the darkest clouds, well, that's how clearly honor peeps through even the humblest style of dress. I mean, is the jay more precious than the lark because his feather is more beautiful? Is the snake better than the eel because the pattern on his back pleases the eye?

paragraphs.original:
Oh, no, good Kate. Neither art thou the worse
For this poor furniture and mean array.
If thou account'st it shame, lay it on me,
And therefore frolic! We will hence forthwith
To feast and sport us at thy father's house.
(to GRUMIO) Go, call my men, and let us straight to him,
(to
)
And bring our horses unto Long Lane end.
There will we mount, and thither walk on foot.
Let's see, I think 'tis now some seven o'clock,
And well we may come there by dinnertime.

I dare assure you, sir, 'tis almost two,
And 'twill be supper time ere you come there.
paragraphs.translated: I hate to say it, but it's almost two and we won't get there before suppertime.

paragraphs.original:
It shall be seven ere I go to horse.
Look what I speak, or do, or think to do,
You are still crossing it. Sirs, let 't alone.
I will not go today, and ere I do
It shall be what o'clock I say it is.
paragraphs.translated: It shall be seven o'clock before I get on my horse. Whatever I say, or think, or do, you're continually contradicting it. Sirs, never mind. We won't go today - or any day until it's clear that it shall be whatever time I say it is.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) Why, so this gallant will command the sun.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) I see this fellow intends to command the sun.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter TRANIO as LUCENTIO MERCHANT booted and dressed like VINCENTIO
paragraphs.translated: TRANIO enters, disguised as LUCENTIO with the MERCHANT dressed like VINCENTIO

paragraphs.original:
Ay, what else? and but I be deceived,
Signior Baptista may remember me,
Near twenty years ago, in Genoa,
Where we were lodgers at the Pegasus.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, certainly. Unless I am mistaken, Signior Baptista may remember me from the Pegasus in Genoa, where we both stayed twenty years ago.

paragraphs.original:
(as LUCENTIO) 'Tis well; and hold your own, in any case,
(as
)
With such austerity as 'longeth to a father.
I warrant you.
paragraphs.translated: Of course I will.

paragraphs.original: Enter BIONDELLO
paragraphs.translated: BIONDELLO enters.

paragraphs.original:
But, sir, here comes your boy.
'Twere good he were schooled.
paragraphs.translated: But, sir, here comes your servant. Better fill him in.

paragraphs.original:
(as LUCENTIO) Fear you not him. - Sirrah Biondello,
(as
)
Now do your duty throughly, I advise you.
Imagine 'twere the right Vincentio.
Tut, fear not me.
paragraphs.translated: Don't worry about me.

paragraphs.original:
I told him that your father was at Venice,
And that you looked for him this day in Padua.
paragraphs.translated: I told him that your father was in Venice, and that you expected him to arrive in Padua today.

paragraphs.original:
(as LUCENTIO) Thou'rt a tall fellow. Hold thee that to drink.
(as
)
Gives money
Gives money
paragraphs.translated:
(as LUCENTIO) Good lad! Here, buy yourself a drink on me.
(as
)
He gives BIONDELLO some money.
some money.

paragraphs.original: Enter BAPTISTA and LUCENTIO
paragraphs.translated: BAPTISTA and LUCENTIO enter.

paragraphs.original: Here comes Baptista. Set your countenance, sir.
paragraphs.translated: Here comes Baptista. Places, everyone!

paragraphs.original: MERCHANT takes off his cap
paragraphs.translated: MERCHANT takes off his cap.

paragraphs.original:
Signior Baptista, you are happily met. - 
Sir, this is the gentleman I told you of.
I pray you stand good father to me now.
Give me Bianca for my patrimony.
paragraphs.translated: Signior Baptista, I'm glad to see you. - Sir, this is the gentleman I told you of. I hope you'll be a good father to me now. Give me Bianca for my inheritance.

paragraphs.original:
(as VINCENTIO) Soft son. - 
(as
)
Sir, by your leave, having come to Padua
To gather in some debts, my son Lucentio
Made me acquainted with a weighty cause
Of love between your daughter and himself.
And, for the good report I hear of you
And for the love he beareth to your daughter
And she to him, to stay him not too long,
I am content, in a good father's care,
To have him matched. And if you please to like
No worse than I, upon some agreement
Me shall you find ready and willing
With one consent to have her so bestowed,
For curious I cannot be with you,
Signior Baptista, of whom I hear so well.

Sir, pardon me in what I have to say.
Your plainness and your shortness please me well.
Right true it is your son Lucentio here
Doth love my daughter and she loveth him,
Or both dissemble deeply their affections.
And therefore, if you say no more than this,
That like a father you will deal with him
And pass my daughter a sufficient dower,
The match is made, and all is done.
Your son shall have my daughter with consent.
paragraphs.translated:
Sir, pardon me for what I am about to say. I appreciate your frankness and your brevity. It's true that your son Lucentio here loves my daughter, and she loves him - or else they're putting on quite an act.
Therefore, provided that you assure me that you will treat your son as a father should and offer my daughter a sufficient dowry, we'll call it a match and be done with it. Your son will have my consent to marry my daughter.

paragraphs.original:
(as LUCENTIO)
(as
)
I thank you, sir. Where then do you know best
We be affied and such assurance ta'en
As shall with either part's agreement stand?

Not in my house, Lucentio, for you know
Pitchers have ears, and I have many servants.
Besides, old Gremio is heark'ning still,
And happily we might be interrupted.
paragraphs.translated: Not in my house, Lucentio. My servants might overhear, and old Gremio is still hanging around, so we might be interrupted.

paragraphs.original:
(as LUCENTIO) Then at my lodging, an it like you.
(as
)
There doth my father lie, and there this night
We'll pass the business privately and well.
Send for your daughter by your servant here.
My boy shall fetch the scrivener presently.
The worst is this, that at so slender warning
You are like to have a thin and slender pittance.

It likes me well. - Cambio, hie you home,
And bid Bianca make her ready straight.
And, if you will, tell what hath happenèd:
Lucentio's father is arrived in Padua,
And how she's like to be Lucentio's wife.
paragraphs.translated: This is all very acceptable. - Cambio, hurry home and tell Bianca to get ready right away and, if you don't mind, tell her what's happened: that Lucentio's father has arrived in Padua, and that she's likely to become Lucentio's wife.

paragraphs.original: Exit LUCENTIO
paragraphs.translated: LUCENTIO exits.

paragraphs.original: I pray the gods she may, with all my heart!
paragraphs.translated: I hope with all my heart she will!

paragraphs.original:
(as LUCENTIO) Dally not with the gods, but get thee gone. - 
(as
)
Signior Baptista, shall I lead the way?
Welcome! One mess is like to be your cheer.
Come, sir, we will better it in Pisa.
I follow you.
paragraphs.translated: I'll come with you.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt TRANIO, MERCHANT, and BAPTISTA
paragraphs.translated: TRANIO, MERCHANT and BAPTISTA exit.

paragraphs.original: Cambio.
paragraphs.translated: Cambio.

paragraphs.original: What sayest thou, Biondello?
paragraphs.translated: What is it, Biondello?

paragraphs.original: You saw my master wink and laugh upon you?
paragraphs.translated: You saw my master wink and laugh at you?

paragraphs.original: Biondello, what of that?
paragraphs.translated: What about it?

paragraphs.original: Faith, nothing; but 'has left me here behind to expound the meaning or moral of his signs and tokens.
paragraphs.translated: Nothing. It's just that he left me here behind to interpret his signs and signals.

paragraphs.original: I pray thee, moralize them.
paragraphs.translated: Please, educate me.

paragraphs.original: Then thus: Baptista is safe, talking with the deceiving father of a deceitful son.
paragraphs.translated: Here's the deal: we're safe on the Baptista front. He's talking with the bogus father about the bogus son.

paragraphs.original: And what of him?
paragraphs.translated: And so - ?

paragraphs.original: His daughter is to be brought by you to the supper.
paragraphs.translated: You are to bring his daughter to the supper.

paragraphs.original: And then?
paragraphs.translated: And then?

paragraphs.original: The old priest at Saint Luke's Church is at your command at all hours.
paragraphs.translated: The old priest at Saint Luke's Church is at your command at all hours.

paragraphs.original: And what of all this?
paragraphs.translated: And what of all this?

paragraphs.original: I cannot tell, except they are busied about a counterfeit assurance. Take you assurance of her cum privilegio ad imprimendum solum. To th' church take the priest, clerk, and some sufficient honest witnesses. If this be not that you look for, I have no more to say, But bid Bianca farewell forever and a day.
paragraphs.translated: I don't know, except they are busy with some phony guarantee. So go and put your stamp on the girl. Go to the church: take the priest, the clerk, and some reasonably honest witnesses. If this isn't what you've been hoping for, I have no more to say except that you ought to say goodbye to Bianca forever.

paragraphs.original: Hear'st thou, Biondello?
paragraphs.translated: Listen, Biondello -

paragraphs.original: I cannot tarry. I knew a wench married in an afternoon as she went to the garden for parsley to stuff a rabbit, and so may you, sir. And so adieu, sir. My master hath appointed me to go to Saint Luke's to bid the priest be ready to come against you come with your appendix.
paragraphs.translated: I can't stay. I knew a girl who was married in an afternoon as she went to the garden for parsley to stuff a rabbit. It could happen to you. Farewell, sir. My master has instructed me to go to Saint Luke's to tell the priest to be ready in case you should show up with your better half.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original:
I may, and will, if she be so contented.
She will be pleased. Then wherefore should I doubt?
Hap what hap may, I'll roundly go about her.
It shall go hard if "Cambio" go without her.
paragraphs.translated: I may. I will if she likes the idea. She will be pleased. Then why am I worried? Oh well, whatever. I'll ask her straight out. It will be hard if "Cambio" loses her.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter PETRUCHIO, KATHERINE, HORTENSIO and Servants
paragraphs.translated: PETRUCHIO, KATHERINE and HORTENSIO enter, accompanied by servants.

paragraphs.original:
Come on, i' God's name, once more toward our father's.
Good Lord, how bright and goodly shines the moon!
paragraphs.translated: Come, let's continue on toward your father's house. Good Lord, how bright and splendid is the moon tonight!

paragraphs.original: The moon? The sun! It is not moonlight now.
paragraphs.translated: The moon? You mean the sun! It is not nighttime now.

paragraphs.original: I say it is the moon that shines so bright.
paragraphs.translated: I say it's the moon that shines so bright.

paragraphs.original: I know it is the sun that shines so bright.
paragraphs.translated: I know it's the sun that shines so bright.

paragraphs.original:
Now, by my mother's son, and that's myself,
It shall be moon, or star, or what I list,
Or e'er I journey to your father's house.
(to servants) Go on, and fetch our horses back again. - 
(to servants)
Evermore crossed and crossed, nothing but crossed!
paragraphs.translated:
Now, by my mother's son, and that's me, it will be moon or star or whatever I want before I'll travel to your father's house. (to servants) Go return our horses. -  Constantly contradicted and contradicted, and nothing but contradicted!
(to servants)

paragraphs.original:
Forward, I pray, since we have come so far,
And be it moon, or sun, or what you please.
An if you please to call it a rush candle,
Henceforth I vow it shall be so for me.
paragraphs.translated: Since we've come this far, please - let's continue on. And whatever it is - moon or sun or anything you like - if you want to call it a tea candle, that's what it is as far as I'm concerned. From now on, I promise.

paragraphs.original: I say it is the moon.
paragraphs.translated: I say it's the moon.

paragraphs.original: I know it is the moon.
paragraphs.translated: I know it's the moon.

paragraphs.original: Nay, then you lie. It is the blessèd sun.
paragraphs.translated: Well, you're a liar, then. It's the blessed sun.

paragraphs.original:
Then God be blessed, it is the blessèd sun.
But sun it is not, when you say it is not,
And the moon changes even as your mind.
What you will have it named, even that it is,
And so it shall be so for Katherine.
paragraphs.translated:
Then God be praised, it is the blessed sun. But it is not the sun when you say it is not, and the moon changes according to your mind. Whatever you want to call a thing, that's what it is - and that's what it will always be for me.
is

paragraphs.original: Petruchio, go thy ways; the field is won.
paragraphs.translated: Petruchio, do whatever you like. You've won.

paragraphs.original:
Well, forward, forward! Thus the bowl should run,
And not unluckily against the bias.
But, soft! Company is coming here.
paragraphs.translated: Well, onward, then. That's how things should be - straight and smooth. But, hang on! I hear someone coming.

paragraphs.original: Enter VINCENTIO
paragraphs.translated: VINCENTIO enters.

paragraphs.original:
(to VINCENTIO)
(to
)
Good morrow, gentle mistress, where away? - 
Tell me, sweet Kate, and tell me truly too,
Hast thou beheld a fresher gentlewoman?
Such war of white and red within her cheeks!
What stars do spangle heaven with such beauty
As those two eyes become that heavenly face? - 
Fair lovely maid, once more good day to thee. - 
Sweet Kate, embrace her for her beauty's sake.

(aside) He will make the man mad, to make a woman of him.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
(speaking so that only the audience can hear) He will drive the man mad pretending he thinks he's a woman.
(speaking so that only the audience can hear)

paragraphs.original:
Young budding virgin, fair and fresh and sweet,
Whither away, or where is thy abode?
Happy the parents of so fair a child.
Happier the man whom favorable stars
Allot thee for his lovely bedfellow!
paragraphs.translated: Young budding virgin, fair and pure and sweet, where are you off to? Or where do you live? Your parents are lucky to have such a lovely child. And luckier still is the man who gets to be your husband and share your bed.

paragraphs.original:
Why, how now, Kate! I hope thou art not mad.
This is a man - old, wrinkled, faded, withered - 
And not a maiden, as thou say'st he is.
paragraphs.translated: Why, dear me, Kate! I hope you haven't lost your mind. This is not a maiden, as you say, but an old man - wrinkled, faded, and withered.

paragraphs.original:
Pardon, old father, my mistaking eyes
That have been so bedazzled with the sun
That everything I look on seemeth green.
Now I perceive thou art a reverend father.
Pardon, I pray thee, for my mad mistaking.
paragraphs.translated:
Sir, pardon my imperfect eyes, which have been so blinded by the sun that everything I look at appears
green. Now I can see that you're an elderly gentleman. Do forgive me for my crazy error.
green

paragraphs.original:
Do, good old grandsire, and withal make known
Which way thou travellest. If along with us,
We shall be joyful of thy company.
paragraphs.translated: Do, good old grandfather, and while you're at it, tell us which way you're traveling. If we're all headed in the same direction, we'd love your company.

paragraphs.original:
Fair sir, and you, my merry mistress,
That with your strange encounter much amazed me,
My name is called Vincentio, my dwelling Pisa,
And bound I am to Padua, there to visit
A son of mine which long I have not seen.
paragraphs.translated: Well, sir, and you, witty lady, who gave me quite a turn with your strange talk, my name is Vincentio, my hometown Pisa, and I am traveling to Padua to visit a son of mine whom I haven't seen in a long while.

paragraphs.original: What is his name?
paragraphs.translated: What is his name?

paragraphs.original: Lucentio, gentle sir.
paragraphs.translated: Lucentio, sir.

paragraphs.original:
Happily met, the happier for thy son.
And now by law as well as reverend age,
I may entitle thee my loving father.
The sister to my wife, this gentlewoman,
Thy son by this hath married. Wonder not
Nor be grieved. She is of good esteem,
Her dowry wealthy, and of worthy birth.
Beside, so qualified as may beseem
The spouse of any noble gentleman.
paragraphs.translated: A fortunate coincidence - more fortunate for your son. I can now call you "father" in a legal sense, not just out of respect for your age. The sister of my wife, this lady here, is married to your son. And there's no need for wonder or worry. His bride is well thought of, with a rich dowry and noble birth - a fit wife for any nobleman.

paragraphs.original:
Let me embrace with old Vincentio,
And wander we to see thy honest son,
Who will of thy arrival be full joyous.
paragraphs.translated: Let me embrace the father of Lucentio, and then we'll journey on to see your son, who will rejoice at your arrival.

paragraphs.original:
But is this true, or is it else your pleasure,
Like pleasant travelers, to break a jest
Upon the company you overtake?
paragraphs.translated: Is all this true? Or is this your way of livening up your travels - playing jokes on people you meet on the way?

paragraphs.original: I do assure thee, father, so it is.
paragraphs.translated: I assure you, sir, it's true.

paragraphs.original:
Come, go along and see the truth hereof,
For our first merriment hath made thee jealous.
paragraphs.translated: Look, come along with us and see the truth for yourself. Our earlier joke has made you understandably suspicious.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but HORTENSIO
paragraphs.translated: Everyone but HORTENSIO exits.

paragraphs.original:
Well, Petruchio, this has put me in heart.
Have to my widow, and if she be froward,
Then hast thou taught Hortensio to be untoward.
paragraphs.translated: Well, Petruchio, all this is very encouraging. I'll visit my widow now, and if she proves difficult to manage, I'll know how to make myself impossible.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter BIONDELLO, LUCENTIO, and BIANCA. GREMIO is out before
paragraphs.translated: BIONDELLO, LUCENTIO and BIANCA enter. GREMIO is already onstage.

paragraphs.original: Softly and swiftly, sir, for the priest is ready.
paragraphs.translated: Quickly and quietly, sir. The priest is already there.

paragraphs.original:
I fly, Biondello. But they may chance to need thee at home.
Therefore leave us.
paragraphs.translated: We're off, Biondello. But they may need you at home, so you go on back.

paragraphs.original: Exit LUCENTIO with BIANCA
paragraphs.translated: LUCENTIO and BIANCA exit.

paragraphs.original: Nay, faith, I'll see the church a' your back, and then come back to my master's as soon as I can.
paragraphs.translated: I'll see them safely married first and then hurry back to my master's.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: I marvel Cambio comes not all this while.
paragraphs.translated: I wonder why Cambio hasn't shown up in all this time.

paragraphs.original: Enter PETRUCHIO, KATHERINE, VINCENTIO and GRUMIO with Attendants
paragraphs.translated: PETRUCHIO, KATHERINE, VINCENTIO and GRUMIO enter, with attendants.

paragraphs.original:
Sir, here's the door. This is Lucentio's house.
My father's bears more toward the marketplace.
Thither must I, and here I leave you, sir.
paragraphs.translated: Here is the door, sir. This is Lucentio's house. My father-in-law lives closer to the marketplace. That's where I'm going now, so I'll leave you here.

paragraphs.original:
You shall not choose but drink before you go.
I think I shall command your welcome here,
And, by all likelihood, some cheer is toward.
paragraphs.translated: You must not go without having a drink first. I think I may presume to welcome you, and they're probably preparing some kind of feast to welcome me.

paragraphs.original: Knocks
paragraphs.translated: He knocks.

paragraphs.original: They're busy within. You were best knock louder.
paragraphs.translated: They're pretty busy in there. You'd better knock louder.

paragraphs.original: MERCHANT looks out of the window
paragraphs.translated: The MERCHANT looks out the window.

paragraphs.original: Is Signior Lucentio within, sir?
paragraphs.translated: Is Signior Lucentio at home, sir?

paragraphs.original: What if a man bring him a hundred pound or two to make merry withal?
paragraphs.translated: What if a fellow were bringing him a couple of hundred pounds to toss around?

paragraphs.original: Art thou his father?
paragraphs.translated:
You're his father?
You're

paragraphs.original: Enter BIONDELLO
paragraphs.translated: BIONDELLO enters.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) I have seen them in the church together. God send
(aside)
'em good shipping! But who is here? Mine old master
Vincentio! Now we are undone and brought to nothing.
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) Well, I've seen them married. Good luck to them! Uh-oh. What's this? It's my master's father, Vincentio! Now we're in trouble. Everything's ruined.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Hope I may choose, sir.
paragraphs.translated: I believe I have some choice in the matter, sir.

paragraphs.original: Come hither, you rogue! What, have you forgot me?
paragraphs.translated: Come here, you wretch! What, have you forgotten me?

paragraphs.original: Forgot you! No, sir. I could not forget you, for I never saw you before in all my life.
paragraphs.translated: Forgotten you! No, sir. I could not forget you, since I never saw you before in my life.

paragraphs.original: What, you notorious villain, didst thou never see thy master's father, Vincentio?
paragraphs.translated: Despicable brute! Never seen your master's father, Vincentio?

paragraphs.original: What, my old worshipful old master? Yes, marry, sir. See where he looks out of the window.
paragraphs.translated: My honorable, reverend master? Yes, of course. There he is at the window.

paragraphs.original: Is 't so, indeed.
paragraphs.translated: Is that so?

paragraphs.original: Beats BIONDELLO
paragraphs.translated: He beats BIONDELLO.

paragraphs.original: Help, help, help! Here's a madman will murder me.
paragraphs.translated: Help, help, help! This madman will murder me.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Exit from above
paragraphs.translated: He exits from above.

paragraphs.original: Prithee, Kate, let's stand aside and see the end of this controversy.
paragraphs.translated: What do you think, Kate, shall we hang back and see how this conflict finishes?

paragraphs.original: They retire
paragraphs.translated: They draw back.

paragraphs.original: Enter MERCHANT below, TRANIO, BAPTISTA and Servants
paragraphs.translated: The MERCHANT enters below with TRANIO as LUCENTIO, BAPTISTA and servants.

paragraphs.original: What am I, sir! Nay, what are you, sir? O immortal gods! O fine villain! A silken doublet, a velvet hose, a scarlet cloak, and a copatain hat! Oh, I am undone, I am undone! While I play the good husband at home, my son and my servant spend all at the university.
paragraphs.translated:
How dare I? How dare you, sir? Oh, cruel gods! Oh, clever villain! A silk doublet, velvet hose, a scarlet cloak, and a high-brimmed hat! Oh, I am destroyed, I am destroyed! While I sat counting my pennies at home, my son and my servant have squandered all my money at the university.
you,
?

paragraphs.original: What, is the man lunatic?
paragraphs.translated: What, is the man crazy?

paragraphs.original: Thy father! O villain! He is a sailmaker in Bergamo.
paragraphs.translated: Your father! Why, you scoundrel! Your father is a sailmaker in Bergamo.

paragraphs.original: You mistake, sir, you mistake, sir. Pray, what do you think is his name?
paragraphs.translated: You're wrong, sir, very wrong. Why, what do you imagine his name to be?

paragraphs.original: His name! As if I knew not his name! I have brought him up ever since he was three years old, and his name is Tranio.
paragraphs.translated: His name! As if I wouldn't know his name, I who brought him up ever since he was three years old. His name is Tranio.

paragraphs.original: Lucentio! Oh, he hath murdered his master! Lay hold on him, I charge you in the Duke's name. O my son, my son! Tell me, thou villain, where is my son Lucentio?
paragraphs.translated: Lucentio! Oh God, he's murdered his master! Restrain him! I charge you in the Duke's name. Oh, my son, my son! Tell me, you monster, where is my son Lucentio?

paragraphs.original: Enter an Officer
paragraphs.translated: An officer enters.

paragraphs.original:
Carry this mad knave to the jail. - Father Baptista,
I charge you see that he be forthcoming.
paragraphs.translated: Take this mad wretch to jail. - Father-in-law Baptista, will you see that he's available to appear in court?

paragraphs.original: Carry me to the jail?
paragraphs.translated: Take me off to jail?

paragraphs.original: Stay, officer. He shall not go to prison.
paragraphs.translated: Wait, officer. He mustn't go to prison.

paragraphs.original: Talk not, Signior Gremio. I say he shall go to prison.
paragraphs.translated: Be quiet, Signior Gremio. I say he shall go to prison.

paragraphs.original: Take heed, Signior Baptista, lest you be cony-catched in this business. I dare swear this is the right Vincentio.
paragraphs.translated: Be careful, Signior Baptista, lest you be made the dupe in this business. I could swear this is the real Vincentio.

paragraphs.original: Nay, I dare not swear it.
paragraphs.translated: Well, no, not literally.

paragraphs.original:
(as LUCENTIO) Then thou wert best say that I am not
(as
)
Lucentio.
Yes, I know thee to be Signior Lucentio.
paragraphs.translated: No, I know that you're Signior Lucentio.

paragraphs.original: Away with the dotard! To the jail with him!
paragraphs.translated: Away with the doddering fool! Take him off to jail!

paragraphs.original: Thus strangers may be haled and abused. - O monstrous villain!
paragraphs.translated: Is this how strangers are treated here? You harass and abuse them? - This is unbelievable!

paragraphs.original: Enter BIONDELLO with LUCENTIO, BIANCA
paragraphs.translated: BIONDELLO enters with LUCENTIO and BIANCA.

paragraphs.original: O! We are spoiled and yonder he is! Deny him, forswear him, or else we are all undone.
paragraphs.translated: We're ruined! There he is! Renounce him! Deny you know him or we're sunk.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt BIONDELLO, TRANIO and MERCHANT as fast as may be
paragraphs.translated: BIONDELLO, TRANIO and MERCHANT exit as fast as possible.

paragraphs.original: LUCENTIO, and BIANCA kneel
paragraphs.translated: LUCENTIO, and BIANCA kneel.

paragraphs.original: Pardon, sweet father.
paragraphs.translated: Pardon, dear father.

paragraphs.original: Lives my sweet son?
paragraphs.translated: Dear son, you're alive!

paragraphs.original: Pardon, dear father.
paragraphs.translated: Pardon us, dear father.

paragraphs.original: How hast thou offended? Where is Lucentio?
paragraphs.translated: Why? What have you done? Where is Lucentio?

paragraphs.original:
Here's Lucentio, right son to the right Vincentio,
That have by marriage made thy daughter mine
While counterfeit supposes bleared thine eyne.
paragraphs.translated: Here is Lucentio, true son to the true Vincentio. I have made your daughter mine by marriage while false impressions blinded your eyes.

paragraphs.original: Here's packing, with a witness, to deceive us all!
paragraphs.translated: Quite the conspiracy! We've all been duped.

paragraphs.original:
Where is that damnèd villain, Tranio,
That faced and braved me in this matter so?
paragraphs.translated: Where is that damned wretch, Tranio, who defied me in such a disgraceful manner?

paragraphs.original: Why, tell me, is not this my Cambio?
paragraphs.translated: Say, isn't this the Latin master Cambio?

paragraphs.original: Cambio is changed into Lucentio.
paragraphs.translated: Cambio is transformed into Lucentio.

paragraphs.original:
Love wrought these miracles. Bianca's love
Made me exchange my state with Tranio,
While he did bear my countenance in the town,
And happily I have arrivèd at the last
Unto the wishèd haven of my bliss.
What Tranio did, myself enforced him to.
Then pardon him, sweet father, for my sake.
paragraphs.translated: It was love that performed these miracles. Bianca's love made me trade places with Tranio while he masqueraded as me around town. And now, finally, I've arrived happily at the blissful haven where I longed to be. What Tranio did, he did at my command. So pardon him, dear father, for my sake.

paragraphs.original: I'll slit the villain's nose that would have sent me to the jail.
paragraphs.translated: No, I'll slit the nose of the villain who would have sent me to jail.

paragraphs.original: But do you hear, sir, have you married my daughter without asking my goodwill?
paragraphs.translated: But sir, have you married my daughter without my consent?

paragraphs.original: Fear not, Baptista, we will content you. Go to. But I will in to be revenged for this villany.
paragraphs.translated: Don't worry, Baptista, you'll be perfectly satisfied. You'll see. Now I'm going inside to see that someone pays for this mischief.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: And I, to sound the depth of this knavery.
paragraphs.translated: Me too - to see how far the mischief went.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Look not pale, Bianca. Thy father will not frown.
paragraphs.translated: Don't worry, Bianca. Your father won't be angry.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt LUCENTIO and BIANCA
paragraphs.translated: LUCENTIO and BIANCA exit.

paragraphs.original:
My cake is dough, but I'll in among the rest,
Out of hope of all but my share of the feast.
paragraphs.translated: So much for my hopes! Well, I'll go in and join the others. All I can hope for now is a share of the feast.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Husband, let's follow to see the end of this ado.
paragraphs.translated: Let's follow them to see how this turns out.

paragraphs.original: First kiss me, Kate, and we will.
paragraphs.translated: First kiss me, Kate, and then we will.

paragraphs.original: What, in the midst of the street?
paragraphs.translated: What, here in the middle of the street?

paragraphs.original: What, art thou ashamed of me?
paragraphs.translated: Why not? Are you ashamed of me?

paragraphs.original: No, sir, God forbid, but ashamed to kiss.
paragraphs.translated: Certainly not! But I'm ashamed to kiss, sir.

paragraphs.original:
Nay, I will give thee a kiss. (kisses him) Now pray thee, love, stay.
(kisses him)
paragraphs.translated:
No, wait. I will kiss you. (kisses him) Now please, love, stay.
will
(kisses him)

paragraphs.original:
Is not this well? Come, my sweet Kate.
Better once than never, for never too late.
paragraphs.translated: Isn't this good? Come, my sweet Kate. Better late than never - and it's never too late to change.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter BAPTISTA, VINCENTIO, GREMIO, the MERCHANT, LUCENTIO, BIANCA, PETRUCHIO, KATHERINE, HORTENSIO, WIDOW, TRANIO, BIONDELLO, and GRUMIO, with the Servingmen bringing in a banquet
paragraphs.translated: BAPTISTA, VINCENTIO, GREMIO, the MERCHANT, LUCENTIO, BIANCA, PETRUCHIO, KATHERINE, HORTENSIO, WIDOW, TRANIO, BIONDELLO, and GRUMIO enter, with the servants bringing in a banquet. Everyone stands as LUCENTIO proposes a toast.

paragraphs.original:
At last, though long, our jarring notes agree,
And time it is when raging war is done
To smile at 'scapes and perils overblown.
My fair Bianca, bid my father welcome,
While I with selfsame kindness welcome thine.
Brother Petruchio, sister Katherina,
And thou, Hortensio, with thy loving widow,
Feast with the best, and welcome to my house.
My banquet is to close our stomachs up,
After our great good cheer. Pray you, sit down,
For now we sit to chat as well as eat.
paragraphs.translated: Finally, at long last, we've reconciled our differences. Now is the time - when war is safely over - to laugh at past dangers and adventures. My fair Bianca, bid my father welcome, while I with equal affection welcome yours. Brother Petruchio, sister Katherina, and you, Hortensio, with your loving widow, you'll find no better entertainment anywhere. All of you are welcome in my house. This last course here is for closing up the stomach after great feasting. Now everyone be seated, as this is the part where we sit and chat as well as eat.

paragraphs.original: Nothing but sit and sit, and eat and eat!
paragraphs.translated: All we do is sit and sit and eat and eat.

paragraphs.original: Padua affords this kindness, son Petruchio.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, Padua is famous for this pleasant life, Petruchio, my son.

paragraphs.original: Padua affords nothing but what is kind.
paragraphs.translated: Padua contains nothing that isn't pleasant.

paragraphs.original: For both our sakes, I would that word were true.
paragraphs.translated: I wish that were true for both our sakes!

paragraphs.original: Now, for my life, Hortensio fears his widow.
paragraphs.translated:
Well what do you know! Hortensio
fears his widow.
fears

paragraphs.original: Then never trust me if I be afeard.
paragraphs.translated: Me afraid of him? I don't think so.

paragraphs.original:
You are very sensible, and yet you miss my sense:
I mean, Hortensio is afeard of you.
paragraphs.translated: That's very sensible, but you missed my sense: I meant Hortensio is afraid of you.

paragraphs.original: He that is giddy thinks the world turns round.
paragraphs.translated: He who is dizzy thinks the world is spinning.

paragraphs.original: Roundly replied.
paragraphs.translated: A very candid reply.

paragraphs.original: Mistress, how mean you that?
paragraphs.translated: What's that supposed to mean?

paragraphs.original: Thus I conceive by him.
paragraphs.translated: That's what I conceive of him.

paragraphs.original: Conceives by me? How likes Hortensio that?
paragraphs.translated:
Conceives by me? How does that sit with you, Hortensio?
Conceives by me

paragraphs.original: My widow says, thus she conceives her tale.
paragraphs.translated: My widow means that her remark expressed the way she understood him.

paragraphs.original: Very well mended. Kiss him for that, good widow.
paragraphs.translated: Nice save! Kiss him for that, good widow.

paragraphs.original:
"He that is giddy thinks the world turns round" - 
I pray you, tell me what you meant by that.
paragraphs.translated: "He who is dizzy thinks the world is spinning" - please, tell me what you meant by that.

paragraphs.original:
Your husband being troubled with a shrew
Measures my husband's sorrow by his woe.
And now you know my meaning.
paragraphs.translated: Your husband, being saddled with a shrew, projects his own suffering onto my husband. And now you know my meaning.
