paragraphs.original: A very mean meaning.
paragraphs.translated: A very nasty meaning.

paragraphs.original: Right, I mean you.
paragraphs.translated:
My meaning is nasty, for it's you I mean.
is

paragraphs.original: And I am mean indeed, respecting you.
paragraphs.translated:
And I am nasty when it comes to you.
am

paragraphs.original: To her, Kate!
paragraphs.translated: You tell her, Kate!

paragraphs.original: To her, widow!
paragraphs.translated: You tell her, widow!

paragraphs.original: A hundred marks, my Kate does put her down.
paragraphs.translated: I'll bet you a hundred marks, my Kate puts her flat on her back.

paragraphs.original: That's my office.
paragraphs.translated: Well, that's really my job.

paragraphs.original: Spoke like an officer! Ha' to thee, lad!
paragraphs.translated: Well said! Here's to you!

paragraphs.original: Drinks to HORTENSIO
paragraphs.translated: He drinks to HORTENSIO

paragraphs.original: How likes Gremio these quick-witted folks?
paragraphs.translated: What do you think of these quick-witted folks, Gremio?

paragraphs.original: Believe me, sir, they butt together well.
paragraphs.translated: They certainly do like to butt heads!

paragraphs.original:
Head and butt! An hasty-witted body
Would say your head and butt were head and horn.
paragraphs.translated:
A clever person would say their butting heads had
horns on them.
horns

paragraphs.original: Ay, mistress bride, hath that awakened you?
paragraphs.translated: Ah, our bride has woken up!

paragraphs.original: Ay, but not frighted me. Therefore I'll sleep again.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, but not out of fear. I'll go back to sleep now.

paragraphs.original:
Nay, that you shall not. Since you have begun,
Have at you for a bitter jest or two!
paragraphs.translated: No, you shall not. Since you chimed in, let's see if we can trade a caustic joke or two.

paragraphs.original:
Am I your bird? I mean to shift my bush,
And then pursue me as you draw your bow. - 
You are welcome all.
paragraphs.translated:
Am I the bird you're going to shoot at now? I'll
move my bush, so you'll have to aim at a moving target. Thank you all for coming.
move my bush

paragraphs.original: Exeunt BIANCA, KATHERINE and WIDOW
paragraphs.translated: BIANCA, KATHERINE and WIDOW exit.

paragraphs.original:
She hath prevented me. Here, Signior Tranio,
This bird you aimed at, though you hit her not. - 
Therefore a health to all that shot and missed.
paragraphs.translated: Well, she got away. Signior Tranio, you also took aim at that bird, though you didn't hit her. - So here's a health to all who've shot and missed.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, sir, Lucentio slipped me like his greyhound,
Which runs himself and catches for his master.
paragraphs.translated: Oh well, sir, I was really just like a greyhound that Lucentio let off the leash: I did the running, but the catch was his.

paragraphs.original: A good swift simile, but something currish.
paragraphs.translated: A witty if a cynical reply.

paragraphs.original:
'Tis well, sir, that you hunted for yourself.
'Tis thought your deer does hold you at a bay.
paragraphs.translated:
It's good you hunted for yourself, sir. It's rumored that your deer holds you at
bay.
bay

paragraphs.original: Oh, Oh, Petruchio! Tranio hits you now.
paragraphs.translated: Oh-ho, Petruchio! Tranio got you that time.

paragraphs.original: I thank thee for that gird, good Tranio.
paragraphs.translated: I thank you for that quip, good Tranio.

paragraphs.original: Confess, confess, hath he not hit you here?
paragraphs.translated: Fess up, fess up, didn't that one strike home?

paragraphs.original:
He has a little galled me, I confess.
And, as the jest did glance away from me,
'Tis ten to one it maimed you two outright.
paragraphs.translated: He's made me a little sore, I'll admit. But since the gibe glanced off me, ten to one it hit you both straight on.

paragraphs.original:
Now, in good sadness, son Petruchio,
I think thou hast the veriest shrew of all.
paragraphs.translated: Seriously, though, son Petruchio, I think you have the most thoroughgoing shrew of us all.

paragraphs.original:
Well, I say no. And therefore, for assurance,
Let's each one send unto his wife;
And he whose wife is most obedient
To come at first when he doth send for her,
Shall win the wager which we will propose.
paragraphs.translated: Well, I disagree. But why not put it to the test? Let's each one send for his wife. Whichever's is most obedient and comes most readily shall win the bet that we'll propose.

paragraphs.original: Content. What's the wager?
paragraphs.translated: Agreed. What's the bet?

paragraphs.original: Twenty crowns.
paragraphs.translated: Twenty crowns.

paragraphs.original:
Twenty crowns?
I'll venture so much of my hawk or hound,
But twenty times so much upon my wife.
paragraphs.translated: Twenty crowns? That's a bet I'd make on my hawk or my hound. I'd wager twenty times as much on my wife.

paragraphs.original: A hundred then.
paragraphs.translated: A hundred then.

paragraphs.original: Content.
paragraphs.translated: Agreed.

paragraphs.original: A match! 'Tis done.
paragraphs.translated: Good! It's a bet.

paragraphs.original: Who shall begin?
paragraphs.translated: Who should begin?

paragraphs.original:
That will I.
Go, Biondello, bid your mistress come to me.
paragraphs.translated: I will. Biondello, go and tell your mistress to come to me.

paragraphs.original: I go.
paragraphs.translated: Here I go.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Son, I'll be your half Bianca comes.
paragraphs.translated: Son, I'll stake you half that Bianca comes.

paragraphs.original: I'll have no halves. I'll bear it all myself.
paragraphs.translated: I'll have no halves. I'll shoulder the whole bet

paragraphs.original: Enter BIONDELLO
paragraphs.translated: BIONDELLO enters.

paragraphs.original: How now, what news?
paragraphs.translated: Well, what happened

paragraphs.original:
Sir, my mistress sends you word
That she is busy, and she cannot come.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, my mistress sends you word that she is busy and cannot come.

paragraphs.original:
How! "She's busy, and she cannot come!"
Is that an answer?
paragraphs.translated: What! "She's busy and cannot come!" Is that an answer?

paragraphs.original:
Ay, and a kind one too.
Pray God, sir, your wife send you not a worse.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, and a nice one at that. Pray God your wife doesn't send you a worse one.

paragraphs.original: I hope better.
paragraphs.translated: I'm hoping for better.

paragraphs.original:
Sirrah Biondello, go and entreat my wife
To come to me forthwith.
paragraphs.translated: You there, Biondello, go and request that my wife come to me straight away.

paragraphs.original: Exit BIONDELLO
paragraphs.translated: BIONDELLO exits.

paragraphs.original:
O, ho, entreat her!
Nay, then she must needs come.
paragraphs.translated:
Oh-ho, he requests! Why, then she'll have to come.
requests

paragraphs.original:
I am afraid, sir,
Do what you can, yours will not be entreated.
paragraphs.translated: I rather think, sir, that yours will not grant a request in any case.

paragraphs.original: Enter BIONDELLO
paragraphs.translated: BIONDELLO enters.

paragraphs.original: Now, where's my wife?
paragraphs.translated: So, where's my wife?

paragraphs.original:
>BIONDELLO
She says you have some goodly jest in hand.
She will not come. She bids you come to her.
paragraphs.translated: She says she thinks this is a prank. She will not come. She says that you should come to her.

paragraphs.original:
Worse and worse. She will not come!
O vile, intolerable, not to be endured! - 
Sirrah Grumio, go to your mistress,
Say I command her to come to me.
paragraphs.translated:
Worse and worse! She will not come! It's vile, intolerable, not to be endured! - You there, Grumio, go to your mistress. Say that I command her to come to me.
will not

paragraphs.original: Exit GRUMIO
paragraphs.translated: GRUMIO exits.

paragraphs.original: I know her answer.
paragraphs.translated: I can guess her answer.

paragraphs.original: What?
paragraphs.translated: What?

paragraphs.original: She will not.
paragraphs.translated: She will not.

paragraphs.original: The fouler fortune mine, and there an end.
paragraphs.translated: The worse for me, no doubt about it.

paragraphs.original: Enter KATHERINE
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE enters.

paragraphs.original: Now, by my holidam, here comes Katherina!
paragraphs.translated: By all that's holy, here comes Katherina!

paragraphs.original: What is your will, sir, that you send for me?
paragraphs.translated: You sent for me, sir? Is there something you'd like me to do for you?

paragraphs.original: Where is your sister, and Hortensio's wife?
paragraphs.translated: Where are your sister and Hortensio's wife?

paragraphs.original: They sit conferring by the parlor fire.
paragraphs.translated: They sit chatting by the parlor fire.

paragraphs.original:
Go fetch them hither. If they deny to come,
Swinge me them soundly forth unto their husbands.
Away, I say, and bring them hither straight.
paragraphs.translated: Go bring them here. If they refuse to come, get physical - use a whip if you have to, but get them out here to their husbands. Go on, I said. Bring them here straight away.

paragraphs.original: Exit KATHERINE
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE exits.

paragraphs.original: Here is a wonder, if you talk of a wonder.
paragraphs.translated: This is a miracle, if you talk of miracles.

paragraphs.original: And so it is. I wonder what it bodes.
paragraphs.translated: It is. I wonder what it means.

paragraphs.original:
Marry, peace it bodes, and love, and quiet life,
And awful rule, and right supremacy,
And, to be short, what not that's sweet and happy?
paragraphs.translated: I'll tell you what it means. It means peace and love and a quiet life, supremacy based on reverence and profound respect, and - not to go on and on about it - everything that's sweet and happy.

paragraphs.original:
Now, fair befall thee, good Petruchio!
The wager thou hast won, and I will add
Unto their losses twenty thousand crowns,
Another dowry to another daughter,
For she is changed as she had never been.
paragraphs.translated: May good fortune come to you, good Petruchio! You've won the wager, and I will add twenty thousand crowns to what they owe you. Another dowry for another wife, for, truly, she is so transformed she's like a completely new woman.

paragraphs.original:
Nay, I will win my wager better yet,
And show more sign of her obedience,
Her new-built virtue and obedience.
paragraphs.translated: Wait, I will win the wager more spectacularly, going even further to demonstrate her obedience, her newly created virtue and obedience.

paragraphs.original: Enter KATHERINE with BIANCA and WIDOW
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE enters with BIANCA and WIDOW.

paragraphs.original:
See where she comes and brings your froward wives
As prisoners to her womanly persuasion. - 
Katherine, that cap of yours becomes you not.
Off with that bauble, throw it underfoot.
paragraphs.translated: Look, here she comes, with your ungovernable wives in tow, like prisoners of her womanly persuasion. - Katherine, that cap of yours doesn't look good on you. Take it off and throw it on the ground.

paragraphs.original:
Lord, let me never have a cause to sigh,
Till I be brought to such a silly pass!
paragraphs.translated: Lord, may I never see a day of trouble until the day I let someone treat me like that.

paragraphs.original: Fie! What a foolish duty call you this?
paragraphs.translated: For shame! What kind of loyalty is this?

paragraphs.original:
I would your duty were as foolish too.
The wisdom of your duty, fair Bianca,
Hath cost me an hundred crowns since suppertime.
paragraphs.translated: I wish your loyalty were as foolish. The wisdom of your loyalty, fair Bianca, has cost me a hundred crowns since dinner.

paragraphs.original: The more fool you for laying on my duty.
paragraphs.translated: The more fool you for betting on my loyalty.

paragraphs.original:
Katherine, I charge thee, tell these headstrong women
What duty they do owe their lords and husbands.
paragraphs.translated: Katherine, I'd like you to lecture these headstrong women on the nature of the loyalty they owe their lords and husbands.

paragraphs.original: Come, come, you're mocking. We will have no telling.
paragraphs.translated: You must be joking. There will be no lecture.

paragraphs.original: Come on, I say, and first begin with her.
paragraphs.translated: Do it, I say. You can begin with her.

paragraphs.original: She shall not.
paragraphs.translated: She shall not.

paragraphs.original: I say she shall. - And first begin with her.
paragraphs.translated: I say she shall. - And first begin with her.

paragraphs.original:
Fie, fie! Unknit that threat'ning unkind brow
And dart not scornful glances from those eyes
To wound thy lord, thy king, thy governor.
It blots thy beauty as frosts do bite the meads,
Confounds thy fame as whirlwinds shake fair buds,
And in no sense is meet or amiable.
A woman moved is like a fountain troubled,
Muddy, ill-seeming, thick, bereft of beauty,
And while it is so, none so dry or thirsty
Will deign to sip or touch one drop of it.
Thy husband is thy lord, thy life, thy keeper,
Thy head, thy sovereign, one that cares for thee,
And for thy maintenance commits his body
To painful labor both by sea and land,
To watch the night in storms, the day in cold,
Whilst thou liest warm at home, secure and safe,
And craves no other tribute at thy hands
But love, fair looks and true obedience - 
Too little payment for so great a debt.
Such duty as the subject owes the prince,
Even such a woman oweth to her husband.
And when she is froward, peevish, sullen, sour,
And not obedient to his honest will,
What is she but a foul contending rebel
And graceless traitor to her loving lord?
I am ashamed that women are so simple
To offer war where they should kneel for peace;
Or seek for rule, supremacy and sway
When they are bound to serve, love, and obey.
Why are our bodies soft and weak and smooth,
Unapt to toil and trouble in the world,
But that our soft conditions and our hearts
Should well agree with our external parts?
Come, come, you froward and unable worms!
paragraphs.translated: Girls, girls! Wipe those frowns off your faces and stop rolling your eyes. This disrespectful stance toward the man who is your lord, your king, your governor tarnishes your beauty the way the frosts of winter blights the land. It mars your reputations as whirlwinds shake fair buds. And in no sense is it fitting or attractive. An angry woman is like an agitated fountain - muddy, unpleasant, lacking in beauty. And in this condition, no one - however dry or thirsty he may be - will stoop to sip or touch one drop of it. Your husband is your lord, your life, your keeper, your head, your sovereign, one who cares for you and who, for your ease and comfort, commits his body to harsh labor both on land and sea. Long, stormy nights at seas he stays awake, by day he endures cold while you lie safe and warm, secure in your beds at home. And in exchange he seeks no more from you but love, kind looks, and true obedience - too little payment for so great a debt. A woman owes her husband the same loyalty a subject owes his king. And when she is peevish and perverse, sullen, sour, and disobedient to his honest wishes, what is she but a loathsome, warlike rebel and an ungrateful traitor to her loving lord? I am ashamed that women are so foolish as to declare war when they should plead on their knees for peace, that they seek authority, supremacy, and power when they are under an obligation to serve, love, and obey. Why are our bodies soft and weak and smooth, unfit for toil and trouble in the world, if not so that our soft qualities and our hearts should agree with our external parts? Come, come, you weak, ungovernable worms!

paragraphs.original:
My mind hath been as big as one of yours,
My heart as great, my reason haply more,
To bandy word for word and frown for frown.
But now I see our lances are but straws,
Our strength as weak, our weakness past compare,
That seeming to be most which we indeed least are.
Then vail your stomachs, for it is no boot,
And place your hands below your husband's foot:
In token of which duty, if he please,
My hand is ready, may it do him ease.
paragraphs.translated: My spirit has been as proud as each of yours, my courage as great, and my reason perhaps even better suited to bandy words back and forth and exchange frown for frown. But now I see our weapons are like straws, our strength like a straw's weakness, and our weakness past comparison, so that we seem to be the thing we most are not. Humble your pride, then, since it's useless, and place your hand beneath your husband's foot. As a gesture of my loyalty, my hand is ready if he cares to use it. May it bring him comfort.

paragraphs.original: Why, there's a wench! Come on and kiss me, Kate.
paragraphs.translated: There, that's my girl! Come on and kiss me, Kate.

paragraphs.original: Well, go thy ways, old lad, for thou shalt ha 't.
paragraphs.translated: Congratulations, old pal, you've won the bet.

paragraphs.original: 'Tis a good hearing when children are toward.
paragraphs.translated: It's nice to see children playing well together.

paragraphs.original: But a harsh hearing when women are froward.
paragraphs.translated: But not so nice when women misbehave.

paragraphs.original:
(to LUCENTIO)
(to
)
Come, Kate, we'll to bed.
We three are married, but you two are sped.
'Twas I won the wager, though you hit the white,
And, being a winner, God give you good night!
paragraphs.translated:
Come, Kate, let's go to bed. We three are married, but you two are defeated. (to LUCENTIO) I was the one who won the wager, though you
hit the white. And as the winner here I say good night.
(to
)
hit the white

paragraphs.original: Exeunt PETRUCHIO and KATHERINE
paragraphs.translated: PETRUCHIO and KATHERINE exit.

paragraphs.original: Now, go thy ways, thou hast tamed a curst shrew.
paragraphs.translated: Well, congratulations. You've tamed a terrible shrew.

paragraphs.original: 'Tis a wonder, by your leave, she will be tamed so.
paragraphs.translated: It's amazing, if I may say so, that she let herself be tamed.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.
